No matter if you want to have lunch, buy a snack to enjoy back at the hotel or even to bring back home with you, whether you're looking for an edible souvenir, or just for an amazingly colorful photographic opportunity, the Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria is definitely the place for you!It's colorful, it's loud, it's crowded, but it is, without a doubt, a place that you won't forget visiting in Barcelona.We went there on my Birthday and ate at El Quim de la Boqueria, after which we wondered through the market, picking up fruits we had never tried before, from a stand selling halved fruits from Thailand, that were shrink wrapped and came with a plastic spoon, so that you could eat them straight away.Grab one of the delicious, freshly squeezed juices - there are SO MANY options to choose from, and you know that what you are getting is 100% natural and good for you.We also stopped at a confectionery stand called Ramona where we were handed a bag to mix and choose any of the delicious candy that caught our eye. It was difficult to actually stop ourselves from buying just about everything they had on display, as it all smelled so yummy and sweet, and looked irresistible. Word of caution for future buyers, though - while the fruit-shaped marzipan looks very nice, the taste isn't all that memorable, so, perhaps buy one just to try it out, and stick to the numerous types of chocolates they sell, as those are really good and worth the money!Definitely come here ready to buy a few things, and make sure to bring your camera! The Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria is not to be missed!

Spanish food safari. This is a place not to be missed. The fresh fruit was my favourite but also heaps of seafood, meat and coffeeGreat bargains on souvenirs in the back streets just off the market.We also got cheap clothing here. Just venture past the food stalls.

What a market. This market is directly off La Ramblas ... Perhaps one third of the way down , on the right hand side going down . You must visit it . There is fruit and veg , fish , drinks , small restaurants (tapas ) it is fabulous .. The best I have ever seen and made me wish I was self catering !!!! Lots of my friends had been to Barcelona but missed this somehow ... You must not .

Gorgeous food, vivid colours, great atmosphere.. There is a huge selection on offer in La Boquería. It is full of lovely smells and colours and the best selection of fruits and sweets and seafood, even animal brains??? (I didn't dare to find out which animal). Even just to sit at one of the tapas bars at the back and people watch is very entertaining. Must visit!

Very busy! Plan ahead if you want to get a seat!. If I visit this market in the future, I will need to remember to go earlier. A few of the interesting tapas bars were packed.I settled for a stall i think is called 'Organic Barcelona', ?10 bought a large portion of paella, salad, taco or pita in various flavours... I'm 90% certain it was vegetarian... But I had no idea what i was actually eating...
Beautiful covered food market - but very crowded.. This is a proper working market, but packed with tourists as well. Great atmosphere. Definitely worth a stroll round.

not large yet full of incredible stuff. One of the best markets I've ever been. Isn't huge, every little stall offers great quality goods, fresh (even skinned lamb heads with eyebulls and other parts of animals, I didnt want to see!). Is a bit pricey, compared to markets in smaller towns, that's usual. It's really a must-see. Though the crowd is annoying. Fresh food for snack or lunch.

You'll get some brilliant colourful photos here!. Be prepared, this is another very busy touristy attraction on the main La Rambla street, but if you've got some spare time, it's worth visiting and you won't know which way to look first! For that reason, watch your bag/pocket as it would be very easy to be distracted here and fall prey to those pick pockets everyone keeps telling you about (we never had a problem or felt threatened at all but it's a big city so it pays to be cautious). The photo opportunities here are fab, the market stall holders all display everything so beautifully, it's a shame not to take photos (there was only one stall we encountered that didn't want you to take photos) especially of the more colourful ones selling sweets and fruit. We wanted to eat lunch here having read another review on Trip Advisor (pinotxo) but it was so busy and hot, we ended up leaving in the end without our usual tapas lunch!

A market that's not super, it's fantastic!. Boqueria is a large, traditional spit-and-sawdust market, full of sights, sounds and smells that have vanished from the soulless 'super' markets now used by 95%+ of the population of Western countries, all under a picturesque and ornate stained-glass structure.There is a massive range of food and drink on sale - meat, fish, fruit & vegetables, and packaged foods, and you can sample them yourself at some old-style stand-up tapas bars, cafes and smoothie stalls.It's crowded with tourists, but there is a also good number of locals going about their daily shopping - it's a genuine market... let's face it, a British city-breaker isn't going to be buying themselves a kilo of shrimp or a salted cod are they?You could easily spend an afternoon in here if you're a 'foodie'... or a photographer!

It is just another market but.... If you love food (and I really do) you would love this place. Of course, there is a lot of tourists, but you can go there in the early morning (it is opening at 8 am i think). Also there is a lot of smells, but that is the part of being able to buy fresh fishes and sea fruits. I liked place very much and if I had bigger luggage I would definitely buy at least a few tons of food :) There was everything you need, meat, fishes, eggs, fruit and vegetable, spices and so on...

If I had all the money in the world.... wow I've never felt like I've wanted to buy so much food in all my life! the colours, the smells, the sounds just beautiful!. I had a few juice smoothies which were only 1 euro which were really nice, I also brought some little hand made chocolates had about 12 pieces for 15 euros pricey but worth it!Go visit, take lots of money and enjoy it!
So Much Gorgeous Food So Little Time. A cooks idea of heaven, if only we had this at home. Such a range of fresh produce, meats and fish. I could die a happy man here.

It is just another market. Can't understand the enthusiasm about it - FruitsVegetablesChopped land animalsWhole, and chopped, sea animalsCrowded bar restaurantsTerrible smell all aroundIf you had a market like this in the city you live in, I can hardly believe you'll ever write about.Obviously, my wife disagrees.

Amazing. We walked this market with Foodiesgo.com owner Sonia Blasco and saw a market in a whole new way. There are tow restaurants that are famous, worldwide, and the tuna stand that sells only fresh tuna, no blood added for color, is incredible. Learn about ham, cheese, oils, and an amazing assortment of veggies and fruits. Worth the visit for sure. Give yourself an hour or more.

very nice market, with nice products. if your not planning to buy something there, just go there for the atmosphere or to take pictures.
We went there to buy some things to eat (different tapas) and went picnic'ing on the beach :-)

Colorful Market where everything is on sale. You can find practically any food in the small, sheltered market - it's a thrill just walking through all of the colors, smells and tastes and seeing all the variety around. A recommended stop for any visit in Barcelona.

Colorful and clean market. This food market along La Rambla is a must-see, must-visit market in Barcelona. This market is clean, and very colorful. There are various displays of fresh fruits, vegetables, candies, chocolates, nuts, eggs, meat, and seafood around the market; even rare finds such as horse meat, bull meat, barnacles, and emu eggs are available. I love to shop around this market because they offer a wide variety of food. The place is very clean and organized too with wide walkways for shopping. They have everything here, even spices!Eating here is also a pleasure as the smells and sights and tastes of the food here are appealing to the senses. You have to wait in line though as there are a lot of people and few seats.

Be patient, it's worth the wait!. The Boqueria is a must on any visit but grabbing a seat at the tapas bars requires patience and in some cases perseverance. When you arrive at this place just stand back and observe for a few minutes, you request a seat from someone behind the bar and you need to decide whether to sit at the bar or a high table. If you want to people watch choose a high table. The food is excellent, we chose fish small plates (sardines, clams, prawn salad) and grilled vegetables along with beers and wine. The buzz is excellent and the team are working at full pace to serve you so don't be offended by the lack of chat. This is a special place in one of Europe's most amazing markets, you have to experience this.

A splash of colours and more!. The Boqueria is a food market which cannot be missed in Barcelona. The coloured spectacle of fruit exhibits and the stalls of jamon Serrano are amazine. There are also some bars in there which offer well priced and excellent lunches.

Smelly but Colorful!!!. This market is very colorful. The arrangement of the fruits, vegetables, jamones and other food related ingredients make this place beautiful to your eyes. This can be a photographer paradise. It was a nice place to walk around and get to see how organized every vendor is. It is fun to watch how and where the locals buy for their everyday meals. Also a place to eat some food, but there are so many choices that it is very difficult to hit it right when it comes for eating something here. Unfortunately everything we tried but one was a disappointment. From empanadas, pasteles, juices, chorizo, and jamon. And most things seemed to be overpriced. But it is a nice place to live the experience as a market.

Interesting market. We visited mid afternoon and found that the crowds had diminished. Not every stall was open for business (some of the fresh fish/seafood stalls were closed), but it was easier to walk around and see all the different arrays of food categories on display. The market is a few steps off Las Ramblas...easy to find and to walk through. It is indoors and reminded me of markets we have visited in other major cities (smaller but similar to Mahane Yehuda Market in Jerusalem). We had thought to find a place to sit and have a snack and people watch. But, there are few places to sit and none were conducive to people watching. Planning to have breakfast, lunch, or dinner here would be very limited in terms of choices to sit and enjoy the food. Sit down eating is not the purpose of this market. As a tourist sight...if you just want to see it...go at on off time, walk through, see the displays, buy a snack or two to eat while walking and head back out to Las Ramblas.

Great place for food lovers!. Crowded but so worth it. You can find pretty much anything here. From Iberico Ham to Marzapan, everything is so yummy. There's something for everyone. My only advise: Watch your bags! And...Enjoy the food :)

A must in Barcelona. This is a great place to spend a couple of hours checking out the market. It is cleaner than many of the open air markets in the world. It has a permanent roof over head. Seafood, fruits, vegetables, meat, candy, fresh fruit juices... Located right off of Las Ramblas in the heart of Barcelona. Don't miss this.

Crazy but a must see!. This market is right off Las Ramblas and its is probably full of tourists but it's so cool! It is packed with amazing stalls selling candy, cheese, meats, olive oil and many other things. It's a great place to stop for a snack or to take something back to your hotel room. It is crowded so watch your bags but it is a must visit while you are strolling Las Ramblas.

Just off Las Ramblas is a unique experience.... This market had some of the most amazing displays of fruit, fruit juices, meats, nuts and tourists on offer in Barcelona. This place was visually amazing and the photo opportunities endless. You should at least invest a couple of euros in either the blended juices or the fresh fruit cups. Crowded but worth the 45-second walk from the main entrance off of Las Ramblas.

FAB U LUSS. Need I say more.... the experience of all that food.... fab u luss!!!Go there for breakfast..... lunch..... tea..... and snack in between.So many places to nibble..... and food to buy.... avoid the chocolate stalls.... cheap chocs alongside fish stalls.... not a good mix..... but it truly is an experience.Once you've been there you will never want to buy shrink wrapped food in a supermarket again!!
Seafood, fresh vegetables, vine tasting and more.... Lively market which makes you hungry even if you are not. Go there for lunch and keep on the left side to enjoy various seafood treats.

Sensory Overload in Barcelona. What an amazing market! So much to see, taste, smell and touch. I suggest to carve out a good couple of hours of your day when you go to La Boqueria. Best to go in the morning right when it opens then nibble your way around but be sure not to fill up as you must have a meal at one of the food stalls towards the back. The market can get pretty crowded so keep your personal belongings close to you. It is very easy to get distracted here. You'll find yourself admiring (and drooling) at sight of the colorful and creative displays of food from the fruits, nuts, spices, smoothies, jamon to the fresh seafood. Prices vary and because this is a tourist attraction it can be pricey. If you are a foodie and/or a photo buff, this is a place not to be missed. Leave the dietary restrictions at home or you'll miss out. You have the Sagrada Familia to visit later to repent for your dietary sins.

Love love love, looking for good food ? They have all. I'm a guy who love to eat local food in my trip. As you know a level of food in Spain is very high, I mean, come on, not only jamon but wines, cheese, seafood, sweets, vegetables, if you stays in Barcelona, you need to try local food. I found that Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria is only few minutes walk from my hotel, so why not ? This place is huge food marketplace, you can find bunches of shops at one place. Very lively vibes, fresh, and crowded. I wanted to try many of food but without kitchen and limited time, I had to give up a lot of them (ahahaha). Unfortunately, not many people speaks English, a little hard to communicate with them.

A feast for the eyes..but... This market is situated just off the Ramblas, and throughly stocked with fresh fruits, meat, fish and other produce. Sit-down food bars serving freshly cooked dishes cluster around the edges of the market. The market is a heady mix of sights, sounds, people - photographic opportunities abound around every corner. The downside is that it becomes very, very crowded by midday. It seems likely that the main business is tourist driven, and prices are accordingly higher. Be also aware of your personal belongings - although we didn't personally witness any problems, it would seem wise to be extremely alert amidst the throngs. We never bought any fresh produce from this market, and based on the items we compared, prices were higher than elsewhere. Best time to visit is early in the morning, before the crowds arrive, though once when we walked there at 8 am, many of the stalls were not quite yet functioning.

If it's fresh, you'll find it there...... And, believe it or not....you're actually trusted to have a wine or sangria before noon......Of course there are so many options of tapas and other food items that it becomes an overall tasting experience, as well as a visual delight, and that is only one of many stops that must be made.....

overly crowded with tourists but awesome fruits and fish. I walked through this market which was overly crowded with tourists. There were many touristic food vendors which i tried to avoid. The more authentic fruit and fish vendors had tasty and pricey offerings. Bought great fruits, was worth every single penny.

Buzzing!!. all I can say is that when we return to Barcelona again one day, this will be the first stop!!!it is so alive and fresh and colourful, just a real buzz being there - do not miss it if you go to BCN, and make sure you eat there, everything is gastronomically amazing....its really 6 out of 5
Lunch. What a fun experience...ate at Quim and had cava and their famous huevos con chipirones.....really felt like a local....would go back in a heartbeat...

A Foodie's Dream. La Boqueria is a dream if you love your food. Seeing all the fresh food, fruit, fish on display became a daily ritual for us on holiday. The sights, sounds and smells invite you in from Las Ramblas and you cant help but want to taste a little bit of everything that is on offer.

Colourful Market!. The best reason for venturing down Las Ramblas is to come here and to enjoy the variety of fresh food available. Each stall is a work of art, and you are able to buy wonderful food (and whole strings of chillies too, if that's what you want!). The market includes fruit, veg, fish, meat, cheese, sweets, preserved fruits and spices. Most of the food is in it's natural state, but you can also buy vegetarian food, pies and other treats to eat on the move.

My favorite market!. From the grand entrance right on Las Ramblas with it's ornate iron work, to the hundreds of brightly colored fruit smoothies, to the incredible variety of fresh fruits and vegetables, to the vast nut and candy selections,to the delicious Jamon "cones", all the foods that are ready to eat now, or take home to cook, to the butchers with their rabbits, ducks and wild fowl hanging and waiting to be processed, to vats of every kind of olive you could possibly conceive of, and to the absolute best fish market, ever...this market is AMAZING! My husband and I seriously ate our way through this market, not once, not twice, but three times! Even if you are just here for the day, this place is worth strolling through. The hustle and bustle of all the locals, shop owners, delivery people and tourists is really something to immerse yourself in. I took some of the best photos of our trip in this market. You might be able to get better prices at a grocery store, but you will never get a better variety of fresh products or better ambiance anywhere!We love Barcelona and we love this market!
Go there!. We loved it! We went there every day. The pizza slices were great, the juice was super, the ice cream delicious and the atmosphere was great.

Well organized, but excess of tourists. It's a market, like so many other markets in another places. Yet, it's from 1840, and the iron structure represents a time on the architecture, and that is very pretty. It's well organized, the fruits and vegetables are beautiful and have great flavors, specially in the spring-summer time. But it's kind of expensive, comparing to other places where you can buy fruits and vegetables, because it's considered a tourist attraction. The points of sale at the entrance are the most expensive. If you have a low budget, try to enter inside and find another points of sale that are less exposed. Quality is guaranteed, except for the fruit juices. Fruit juices in all the points of sale are a big attraction for tourists, because they are refreshing and have beautiful colors. But if you are used to drink natural fruit juices, you'll find that those glasses are filled with water and sugar, while the fruit is only a little part of it. But if you're used to drink soft drinks, packaged, bought at the supermarket, maybe you'll not find any difference. There are lots lots lots lots of tourists there, specially at summer, so be patient to walk on crowd and take care with your belongings.

One of Europe's best indoor markets.. Better than Borough Market in Southwark. This place only a few metres from the Ramblas shows we Brits how it should be done. Helped along by the enormous supplies of local fish, agricultural and pastry, it is still impressive to see the volume variety quality freshness and display. Best fish stalls I have ever seen, bustling busy customers, most discerning and buying fresh each day for their own tables. Almost every small aisle interlaced with snack bars, high stools, good wine spirits coffee or soft drinks. An inspiring experience and impossible not to indulge.

A must for foodies. One of my favorite places. I love the smell, colour, hustle & bustle. Go hungry......and fill up while you're there. Lots of places to eat, we walked round first, stopped to eat and then did our shopping of fruit, snacks and smooties.

One of My Favorite Stops!. Although I think this place is mainly open for tourists, it was an incredibly fun stop. There were tons of delicious fruits and juices for sale, as well as places to eat lunch if you'd like. I got a delicious empanada at one of the stands as well. Watch for pickpockets while you're there because some of it is pretty crowded, but it's great fun!

Your taste buds will explode. Wow. This marketplace is incredible. It's easily accessible from la ramblas and it's such a break from the more tourist populated areas. There is something magical about this market. It's quirky and unique and most of all will blow your taste buds away. The best concoctions of fruit smoothies and juices are under this roof. Your eyes will not not were to look with hundreds of juices of all different colours. And they are only 1 euro. You could spend an entire afternoon hear stuffing your face and not even regretting it later because hey face it your on vacation.
Amazing. This market is really amazing!Very colorful and full of life.Great place to grab something healthy to eat.Tasty juices, fruits and sandwishes.

Good fun and loads to see, smell and taste!. We were recommended to find somewhere to eat in the market so popped in when we got to barcelona for lunch.Very busy with locals and tourists....have a wander around the stalls; theyve done a superb job by mixxing the sale of fresh produce from fish to meat to eggs, hams, cheese etc etc, with offering tapas and tasters....great ideaThere's fresh fruit and fruit drinks everywhere....just dive in and sample what you fancy...the spanish as ever are always friendly and helpful.As far as tapas, the restaurants and bars ring around the market stalls so very easy to pick and choose what you fanycGreat fun!

AMAZING whether you are a foodie or not!. WOW! What an experience! We went early morning to try to have less crowds to deal with, but with aisle after aisle of incredible foods, everyone wants to go there. We had planned to try some tapas bars in there, but were totally satisfied having many cooked foods from the stands. I had the pleasure of finally eating things that I had been wanting to try, and they were so fresh! No disappointments at all here, just be cautious with your belongings as there are massive amounts of people. Don't let this discourage you though, it IS a MUST DO while in Barcelona! (I'll probably return tomorrow)! :D

Just Love this place!. Stayed in the Gothic area and La Boqueria was only a good 8 minute walk from our Bed and Breakfast. Though we were only in Barcelona for 2 nights before disembark for our cruise, we've gone back about 5 times for fresh fruits, seafood, turrones to bring home (both alicante and jijona), for lunch, for snacks and etc. I finally had a chance to try the infamous razor clams from there also. Such a great place and a must for me when in Barcelona...

Where to look first?! :D. La Boqueria is a great place to visit when in La Rambla.You really dont know where to look first! Artisan chocolates, freshly squeezed juices, fruits that I have seen for the first time, all kinds of fish and meat, and also great pattiserie and cooked dishes.Me and my friends preffered fresh fruit juices and traditional TURRON to try this time.Visit, you will be amazed!

Lively and colourful.. This is a great experience. The colours and smells are amazing. Avoid Mondays as it is quiet after the weekend (closed on Sundays) and try to get there early in the morning before the crowds. There are some great Tapas bars there. We had a guided tour which was a good way to see and taste what the market had to offer.

Breath-taking. This is a must-see in Barcelona. To really enjoy the market, you should:- keep a close eye on your belongings (the market is very crowed and a perfect place for pick-pockets)- compare the prices before buying anything (there may be hugh differences in price and quality between the stands)- bring your camera and take pictures- plan on having a meal there (there is a great variety of freshly prepared food)The market looks like an extremely touristy place, but the prices are similar to the smaller markets in Barcelona. You will notice that a lot of the locals do their shopping there, too.

Crowded beyond popular but impressive and tasty products. You cannot go inside and leave without anything, this is just impossible. Do not go there if you're hungry and don't plan to buy anything, because you will leave with 6 or 7 different bags of products and eat everything in a public park nearby, I guarantee it.The market is very popular, in may (which is not the high season), it was pretty much crowded to the point of no return, if you stop walking, everyone behind you has to stop too. But it's a festival of colors, smells, noises and tastes that will leave you hungry. From fresh fruits, fresh juices, hams, cheeses, spanish food, sweets, pastries and colored peppers hanging from the stalls, it's a heaven for foodies.Be careful though, it's the perfect place for pickpockets and some merchants are abusing the credulity of tourists by selling sub-part products at a higher cost than their neighbors simply because they're located near the entrance or on the central aisle. Definitely visit the whole thing before buying anything, prices can double between two stalls.

Fresh unique products. If you happen to visit Barcelona and you like fresh food, you must visit this nice place for sure! You will like prices and quality of products they have here. We had fresh juice for 1,5 euros! There are also many different unique types of fish, fruits and nuts, yummy jamon, etc.

Crowed and full of delicatesen. Touristy marked with all you need to spice up your senses. Ham, meet, fruit, spices and lots of it!! The perfect place if you like to bring a small snack to your hotel room.
it's heaven for foodies. you can fin everything from jamon to fresh vegetables, take your time and enjoy the place first, sea food is popular but I recommend jamon and wine. perfect...

In the heart of La Rambla must see and must grocery shopping. Whenever you are in Barcelona and want to have some authentic food shopping or quick lunch not a restaurant type experience go to this amazing market. Not only you can do some good fresh food shopping, but sip a coffee or have a snack with the locals in one of mini bars inside.
A must see if you are in Las Ramblas. Barcelona has many markets and all of them are good, but this one takes it to a completely different level. Well worth visiting to buy some lunch, treats etc.

Foodie paradise. This food market is an assault on the senses! More food, and a greater variety than you can imagine. The smoothies alone are worth the trip. It was hard to find a seat at one of the numerous bars so we walked through and found a table in the sun at the adjoining restaurant. I don't remember the name, but the sangria and tapas were excellent. We stopped into the market a few times in addition to our first trip and stop at the restaurant. Another day we grabbed breakfast, and fruit and snacks to carry us until a late lunch.

Must see. I'm usually reluctant when it comes to 'must see' places like La Rambla where too many tourists gather as well as too many individuals with not the best meanings. However, regardless the fact that the market is next to one of the crowdiest toppers in Barcelona, we discovered this place just now and it is a true highlight! It's a real delight to see what is sold and stroll around. If you like cooking, this is just the place to find inspiration and ingredients!

So enjoyable here.. . I loved this place. The hustle and bustle, the amazing foods, colours and just everything about it was enjoyable. Could have spent hours wondering around.Decent prices for food. We had some lovely fresh fruit for reasonable prices.

Wonderful Sensory Overload. The sights, sounds, and smells within this market were amazing. There are so many different things that will capture your attention. Fruits, nuts, juices, jamon and seafood are just some of the things you can try, and with the reasonable prices you have the opportunity to try many different things.

Must see. This market is a pleasure for the eyes and for the taste. You can just look around, or better, try some of the thins the people are selling. Fruits were very delicious, also the jamon and the sheep cheese.

Touristy Yet Practical and Colorful. Next to the most central pedestrian avenue of La Rambla, this market is certainly a treat for the eyes. It’s better to enter it from backside though, where the fresh fruits, juices and just about everything is a tad cheaper. In my view, it’s not a proper place to have lunch at all, since most stuff is quite expensive and you’d be rushed to vacate your seat asap. Delicacies such as Iberian Ham is easy to find elsewhere, and much cheaper too. Canned goods are better be purchased from small supermarkets. Yet nevertheless, this is a practical choice to find everything at one place if you’re short of time and not of money. We’ve enjoyed it a lot with just fresh fruits at hand, looking at colourful stalls of spices, meats, fish etc.

action packed, colourful and oh so tasty. we could have spent 1/2 our day roaming from stall to stall savouring all the amazing food on offer, a foodies heaven this is my style of eating. The mercat has such a great buzz about it and to see the excitement on people faces about fresh traditional foods is such a pleasure. Very affordable prices, well worth the visit for breakfast or lunch ... or even better, both !!

Explosion of the senses!. We spent a fabulous couple of hours in the market. We had breakfast at El Quim which was brill, really tasty and fun! The colours, smells, sights, tastes of this market are fantastic. Everywhere you looked, there was something bright and interesting to capture your attention. A must visit!

favorite place in barcelona. i love food and i love barcelona. this is, my food mecca.
lots and lots of great food, at affordable price too. i spent 3 hours there and didn't want to leave. what a brilliant food market!

Must go. Good and cheap food. However, very crowded. Take care of belongings. While I was there, heard someone else exclaim he lost his wallet. Not an extremely huge market so it doesn't take long to finish walking through. What could slow you down is the crowd. Try to explore before buying as the food nearer to entrance of market is usually more expensive. Try some Catalan food, called pintxo (similar to tapas but comes with a skewer). There is one stall selling Catalan food and is good and cheap. It's around left back of market.

...what turned out to be the main attraction!. Brillant food market with an enormous variety of fresh foods of all kind. The fish and seafood market has mores species than most european oceanariums. Hosts a few tapas bars, where a normal breakfast is very fresh oysters, octopus salad, omelets and draught Moritz beer. Yay!

Food sensory overload. As a committed foodie and qualified chef words can not really express the edible treasures to be had in these markets. Wether you want to eat, drink or just wander round and take it all in there is a surprise and a delight to be had on every stall. We did learn later that Saturday was not the best day to visit as this is historically the busiest day of the week for the traders but if you enjoy the hustle and bustle you will not be disappointed.One word of note for fellow Australians, whilst we have some of the strictest quarantine laws on the planet you can still take home herbs and spices provided they are properly sealed and packaged. Oh yes and DECLARED at Customs, you may wait another 5 minutes to be processed but when you have only paid $20 for a jar of Saffron that would of cost over $60 in Oz then it's well worth the wait.

Be prepared for the crowd!. We have been here at lunch time and it was mental: it'a not just a place where you can eat,but the city main street market.Empanadas are really good and quite cheap.Suggestion: AVOID the "organic bar" on the right of the market, they want 10 euros for a pita with vegetables and rice.

A must see. No visit to Barcelona is complete without a visit to La Boqueria, just off La Ramblas. This market is a sensory feast with all the best that Spain has to offer. The freshly squeezed juices, so many varieties, are an absolute bargain at €1 each as are the fresh fruit salads. That was our breakfasts sorted. I could while away a couple of hours here trying all the delights on offer. Beautiful fresh produce of all varieties and all under one roof. I would love to have that on my doorstep. Fabulous!
Great local market. This place is a perfect local market. Great tapas, there are multiple bars you can sit at and eat while you people watch in the market.
Nice Place. A collection on colors and smels of vegetables fruit fish meat and pasterie. though very clean, and not less important clean of pocket lifters marketthough to crowded by tourists

Strawberries the size of my thumb. Alright, I have small thumbs, but the fruit and veg on display all seems to be on steroids. In this market you ought to be able to find anything you need to cook up a feast -- every type of fruit, veg, meat (every part of the animal!), spices, oils, nuts etc. Or if you prefer there are plenty of stalls where you can grab a bite to eat. We got some lovely fruit jellies for my gran and also to sample lots of little delicacies as we walked around. Sadly, I got some rather expensive chocolates which turned out to be awful, but the rest of it was awe inspiring. How a market should be!

Fresh produce, daily. Packed produce market off La Rambla. There is a little vegetarian stall at the back right I was interested in trying but it seemed to be shut every time I went (at awkward times). Fruit, veggies, meat and fish. Everywhere.

One of the most beautiful markets of the world.. Very, very beautiful displays on this vibrant market, with lots of vegetables and seafood. Very nice small eating-places too. Come early, for it is getting very crowded here after 11 o'clock.

A must-do in Barcelona. This was one of my favorite experiences from my Barcelona trip. A sensory overload in the best way possible - a huge market with meats, fish, fruit, nuts, candy, and juices. I could have eaten lunch here!

Fresh fruit, fresh meat fresh everything . From a visual standpoint Boqueria is soo pleasing to the senses. The colors of the fruit, the different colors of the flowers, the fresh juices, cheeses and olive oil everywhere are sure to impress. There is nothing you wouldn't find at this market for making a good meal. Taste a little bit of Barcelona and what that great city has to offer by stopping by Boqueria. Ps.. Do not pay more than 1 euro for the fresh juices. I found vendors who went up to 1.50 euros for juices when their competitors offered the same drinks for 1 euro!

Must visit for a foodie.. Love this place. For either buying food., people watching or a snack.Wonderfully displayed vegetable fruit fish and meat. If you are a veggie best avert your eyes at the meat stalls. Fruit drinks at € 1 or up to € 1.5 great. I had razor clams and small scallops at. € 15 each a dish not a cheap breakfast but a wonderful experience. Also try the cones of Pata Negre ham at £ 4.50 euro . Incredible .Even if not that interested have a look.
Don't miss this. We loved the fresh food - fruit, meat, seafood, drinks - and the authentic bartering with the merchants. Did NOT like the beggars and the panhandlers.

Huge food market with everything you would want!. This food market on La Ramblas is a must visit place when in Barcelona. It had everything from fruits, vegetables, seafood, meat,spices, nuts, chocolates, icecream and much more. There are also stands selling ready to eat food. There are a few tapas stands too. The gelatto icecream you get there is good too. The variety of fruits available was amazing!

Wow. We started our visit at a Tapas Bar and that was spectacular food. Then we looked around the whole market and the displays are incredible. In spite of the fact that most vendors do not speak another lanquage other than Spanish, hands and pointing did the trick. We loved it. It's a must if you visit Barcelona.

Interesting & Vibrant Market. The ambience of this market was electrifying, it was jammed packed with tourists marveling at the displays of goods & produces sold and locals doing their daily grocery shopping. It is considered a clean and well kept market, no unpleasant stench at all.There's a few butchers inside the market & many other stalls selling nuts, fruits, chocolates, seafood, poultry, spices etc. There are also a few eating places inside the market. We went to the famous Pinoxto Bar and had some beers with a baby squid dish & a shrimp dish for the afternoon. On the side of the market lines a row of interesting shops selling olive oils & wines. There are also some cafes & restaurants which seemed pretty popular.

Fantastic Market. Wonderful variety of stalls of food and drink. You can buy either fresh uncooked meat and fish as well as cooked meals or sit at bars and have food and drink served. There is also bread, jamon, nuts, cheese and all kinds of other things you can buy and take with you for a picnic or lunch on the run. Although it is right on Las Ramblas you could miss the entrances so look out for the archways. There is a wide range of fruit drinks in interesting combinations at stalls near the entrance. These are discounted towards the end of the day

Grat tastefull variety of foods. Great place tot taste a variety of foods. Take colourful pictures and all of that not having to spend much. Just keep one thing in mind, Its not open on sundays.I say a lot of people going there on sunday to see closed doors. I was lucky I went on a saturday. :)

Bustling. I was put off at first by the scrum of tourists at the entrance of the market all taking photos and rudely not asking permission - these have to be the most photographed stalls and stall holders in the world. When I got through the scrum I found the fish and meat area and the stalls were beautiful with a huge variety of produce - if only we had markets like this in the UK. I would have liked to try the tapas here but the cafes were all so busy I decided to go elsewhere. I thought the stall holders were very tolerant and still managed a smile and a geeting.

You can't miss it!. If you like markets and “feel” all the gastronomic tradition of Barcelona, you must go to the La Boqueria!Located in Las Ramblas, is a labyrinth of stalls where they sell everything, meat, fish, vegetables, fruit ...etcIn La Boqueria you can buy very good quality of cured ham, the famous “Jamón ibérico”!There has also some taverns where you can sit at counter, drink and eat a variety of very good food. There is often a bit crowded at mealtimes.You can't miss it!

Must visit in Barcelona!. Every time I visit Barcelona La Boqueria is always on my way. I can't immagine a day in Barcelona without a walk through this labyrinth of colours and fragrances. If you search a place for a excellent food and affordable prices La Boqueria is the right place!

Fresh, fresh and more........ Undoubtedly the best market in Barcelona. Fresh fruits, fresh juices and of course many types of ham. Everything looks fresh and then those colors! At the ham stall one can buy small portions of tapas, which one can take along to one of the wine bars on the outside of the market. At these bars they sell excellent wines for € 3 per glass. A place not to be missed.

Wonderful. Colourful, vibrant - this is a real 'must' if you are visiting Barcelona. So many different types of food all displayed so beautifully. Taps bars in the middle and round the outside are great - such a fabulous atmosphere.

Amazing!!. Loved it! Market with lots and lots of fresh fruit, vegetables juices, seafood, olives, chocolates, nuts, meat products, cheese. So nice and colourful, a great buzzing place to visit. Just off La Rambla, you can't miss it.

Exotic. It felt exactly like a market should feel like! Smelly (all the seafood) and bursting with colours. There were varieties of fish, fruits, ice-creams, candies, juices, smoothies and nuts/dried fruits! You can't spend too long there as there is only so much you can buy, but it's a great place to stop for some exotic fruits, like the pink dragonfruit!

The Best Market. Visited this market in May 2013, this was the best market that my wife and I have ever been to. The fresh fish and bakery were delicous!!! Not to forget the assortment of chocolates!!!
Scrumptious!. We were introduced to the Boqueria by our tour guide and have been back already. Fresh fruit, juices, salads and Iberian ham. A good place to pick up an inexpensive meal.
Ham, jamon and yet more ham. What a great fresh food market displaying hams of all varieties, fish , meats and fruits. Try a cup of fresh juice from one of the many fruit stalls. Yummy!

Must see in Barcelona. La Boqueria is one of the biggest markets in the world. Seafood a plenty, candy cheese, meats etc. Worth walking through for an hour or so and grabbing some Iberian ham, the best ham in the world!

Oh my God!. This place is unbelievable!! It´s a huge market where you can find all sorts of things: fruits and vegetables, natural juices, chocolates, meat, pork, fish, olives, nuts and so much more! It´s just wondrful to get lost in its alleys, everything is so clean and groomed, and everything looks delicious! We would stop by La Boqueria every morning to get something for lunch later! It is a DO NOT MISS!!

Cheap eats on La Rambla!. Don't want to pay outrageous prices! Come to the market for great tapas and fresh fruits! You can try lots of variety of foods for very cheap. Get real fruit juices for only 1 euro. Fruit cups range from 1-3 euros. Go further inside the market for the best prices. The stalls at the front generally are a bit more expensive.

Absolute must for all food lovers!. Definitely a must see when in Barcelona. Advise you to go in the morning in order to see all the fresh fish & sea food. Absolutely incredible. Just wander around, have a glass of wine at some of the places around the Boqueria or outside of the market and get the feel of this magical place. Absolutely love all those markets and definitely one of my favorite!

Great for lunch and snacking... We enjoying walking around market and taking in all the deliciously looking food and snacks. Buy from different stalls and eat a little of everything. Better than sitting in an expensive tapa place on Las Ramblas.

Fruit paradise. Probably one of the best places to feel the unique atmosphere of Barcelona and to communicate with friendly locals. The great thing is that you can try almost anything (like "turron", chocolate or fruit) before buying it in order to know if you like it. Moreover, it is a great chance to "charge" your organism with vitamins, as there is a huge variety of delicious fresh juices and smoothies for only 1 -1.5 euro. It is also possible to try some local dishes there and to eat in more informal atmosphere , which helps you somehow to "feel" the city better.

Be careful.... We went on our first day. It's nice enough to walk around but very busy. Be aware of your surroundings and keep everything safe. Avoid the stall (in front of you and first on the right as you walk in from la rambla), selling chocolates. They hand try to force bags into your hand even if you are browsing. They looked nice so we chose 5-6 and the seller tried to charge us 10 euros - he then tried to grab me a make a scene (at first I thought he was trying to steal my wallet) when left the chocolates and walked away! Not only a rip-off but disgusting behaviour.Be sure to check prices if they are not advertised - I think this is a sinister way to rip off tourist who would rather pay through the nose than say no.We also bought some lychees from another stall for a very reasonable price - the next day they were all mouldy!!Saying it spoilt our experience is an understatement, we never went back to the market after that!

If you like trying different food this is a Must See!. As we entered the madness we joined the locals in purchasing something scrumptious to eat off a stick and a fruit smoothie as we wandered the market. After gathering our goods from the various fruit and vegetable stands, meat and fish areas, and an assortment of pre-made food vendors we found a small standing table outside a wine bar at the edge of the market to set up our picnic, now complete with a glass of wine.

Can't miss it!. This is a place that will invade all your senses-smell, sight, hearing, taste, and touch. Food is delicious as well as appealing. People come here to take pictures of displays. Vendors are friendly and don't mind all the photography. People are friendly and easy to talk to.

The place to eat. Well, why wouldn't it be when you watch your seafood get delivered straight from the wet fish shop 20 yards away. There are many little restaurants with stools at a bar or a few tables, that fill on a first come first serve basis. Prices vary from high ( but worth it) at the front of the market to lower at the back but all are good. Go in the morning to find a fresh and varied selection of hand snacks to be taken away in paper cones or stop for lunch amongst the bustle between 12 and 3, it's all over by 4. You'll want to come back.

A must if visiting Barca. Fantastic market, full of colour and smells, wander around enjoying fresh pots of fruit and iberico jambon. Buy your picnic lunch here, as its so much cheaper than shops. The bars will have you coming back for more as well, wether its coffee, beer or tapas.

The most amazing mercado en el mundo. This is a great market. It's easy to find - step away from the L3 Liceu metro stop. It's good because it has some of the best food in Barca. An oyster bar that serves the freshest for 1-2 E each, a taco bar, a place that does mushrooms and snails, many seafood places with seafood so fresh that it is still wiggling on the ice. It's also a veggie, meat, olive, condiment, and ethnic food market. I love seafood so I went there several days to view the mariscos. Everything was in abundance: tuna, swordfish, bonito, 8-10 different mollusks, crawdads, lobsters, shrimps-all strictly fresh. I love uni-which is the eggs of sea urchin. It's a japanese delicacy and found in many sushi restaurants. I found fresh-caught sea urchin for 10E per kilo-about 12 pieces. I'd never done this before, but I took the kilo of urchins back to my hotel room and broke them open, scoped out the uni, and ate it with a cold glass of Spanish sauvignon blanc; delicioso. I went online to figure out how to extract the delicate private parts, and not having the recommended scissors, I used the blunt end of a spoon to open the creatures and the spoon part to literally "spoon out" the eggs. Fabulous. You MUST see this market-maybe not the sea urchins.

One of the most beautiful markets. If you're ever in the area, you have to stop at this market. It is amazing. Just off Las Ramblas, stroll the many vendors. Beautiful displays & full of color, just great.

Great fun!. There is so much to see & try in this market. Some of the stall holders got a little bit annoyed when we looked and didn't buy but when there are so many stalls it's impossible to buy from them all. Apart from that, it was a great visit & the food was fabulous.

Get here for late morning and stay for lunch. The Liceu Metro stop is right opposite the entrance. The colours, the hustle and bustle, and the produce all have great attraction and are highly photogenic. Meander amongst the throng of people going about there daily business or the tourists looking for a little bit of something Spanish to take home with them. Stroll in off La Rambla late morning and stay for a drink, or a meal, at one of the cafes alongside the market for lunch. Unmissable.

Sensory delight-visual, aural, gustatorty. Check it out.. You will be strolling along La Rambla sometime during your visit in Barcelona so do yourself a favor and drop into this amazing market. It is on the west side of the promenade just north of the mid-way point. We stayed nearby at the Hotel Montecarlo a couple of block north of La Boqueria; the market was our first stop in Barcelona after we had checked in and freshened up.There has been a market on this site since about 1200, making La Boqueria over 800 years old. It was originally just outside the old city's defensive walls that ran along where La Rambla now lies. It has been an open air market for most of its existence, the current metal roof having been built 100 years ago in 1914. This is a working market catering to the locals and to the restaurants of the area. Meat, vegetables, fruit, seafood stalls are scattered all around. There are bakeries and sweet stalls. It is a bustling place especially at the La Rambla entrance and a little further in. If you go deeper into the market you will leave most of the crowd behind. There are lots of fresh seafood stands offering the maritime bounty of the nearby Mediterranean. Several specialized in salted cod, bacalao, a staple of Catalan cuisine. Fresh meat products were on display, of course, including innards such as lungs, liver, brain, spleen, intestines. The main meat attractions, however, were the jamón and assorted sausage products.As with most attractions a guided visit can only enhance the experience and visiting La Boqueria with a chef would be the way to go; learning about the ingredients, which to buy and why, then using them in the kitchen. The Boqueria has its own culinary school. We took a session with Barcelona Cooking and had a lot of fun; unfortunately our schedule did not permit our joining the morning session which included the Boqueria tour before.The next best thing - or better yet - is to eat at one of the numerous dining establishments scattered around the market. Bar Pinotxo came well-recommended and it is ideally located near the entrance. Both these factors, however, ensured that the seats were continually occupied and we eventually gave up waiting. We continued exploring the market and came upon Bar Central La Boqueria along the main central passageway on the other side of the market. It specialized in seafood tapas and it was great.Definitely visit Mercat La Boqueria when in Barcelona

INCREDIBLE. Go hungry and make sure you 'take a lap before you commit to a location'. This market is not to be missed off Las Ramblas with many fruits, vegetables, meats, drinks, smoothies, chocolates.... the list goes on and on....all fresh and IF I ever live in BCN, this will be my grocery.

A visual feast!. Colourful displays and interesting ware! Its a visual feast for the eyes and your camera. From iberico ham, to fruits, vegetables, seafood, herbs, candies, sweets and fruit salts! I wouldn't think the items here are too cheap, especially if you are Asian and clearly a tourist like I am. They are closed on certain days though, so check out their website or asking about their operating hours before heading down.Also becareful with your pockets and bags, I caught someone eyeing me a couple of times when I was going snap happy at some of the displays and was seemingly oblivious to my surroundings. He eventually slunk away alone into the crowd after I caught his eye.
Both for seeing and eating. Wonderful location, lots of local flavours. A good place to sample the best tastes of the region.Also the best place in town to pick up quality ham and cheese.

Mmmmmm!. So much amazing food is on display in this market, I wanted to eat everything! Every type of food is available, and there are various tapas bars to stop and people watch. Definately worth visiting.

Delicious Scenery. This was the first stop we made in Barcelona after walking down Las Ramblas. Tucked off the side of Las Ramblas this market is a great place to grab some tapas, fruit, vegetables, seafood or pretty much anything that is fresh and delicious. It is great to wander around and see all the food wares for sale. We grabbed a fresh fruit cup for 2 Euros each for a light snack while we walked around. A great food market, would highly recommend if you are a foodie or just looking for a snack while wandering Barcelona.
Fantastic market!. Wow, wow, wow! I could happily get lost in this market. A treat for all the senses. Fruit, vegetables, fish, meat, flowers, nuts, olives, chocolates, etc. etc.

Wow - a visual feast!. La Boqueria is stunning!! The stallholders have created the most amazing displays of fresh produce and products. A whole display of mushrooms, one of chillies, another of eggs - each stall seemed to contain every variety of their product imaginable... plus lollies, fruit, chocolates, nuts... it blew me away! I bought a dish of fresh figs that were the tastiest I've ever had - and only 1 euro. It made me wish we had a kitchen in our hotel room, because I would have loved to have bought some of the fresh seafood and vegetables to whip up a delicious dinner!

If you want to see tourists. It is one of the typical market buildings in barcelona, with fruit and fish and meat and charcutrie and spices and serrano and so on. Everything is neatly arranged in vivid colours and very impressing. But it is also the market with the most tourists by far, there are so many, that it becomes more interesting to watch how the tourits behave than to look at the merchandise offered. The prices are okay, though.I guess, it is pobably okay to go there, if you just stop by in Barcelona—but if you want to focus on the market feeling, than you better go to any of the other markets in the city. They might be a little bit smaller, but not less impressive.Would I take a friend there? - No, I would take him to the market in Grácia instead.

A place not to be missed while in Barcelona. If you go to Barcelona you cannot miss the Boquería, and if you go, I recommend stopping at either Boqueria tapas bar or Pinotxos Bar where the very popular Juanito will serve you their specials. Juanito also makes the best coffee of the Boquería!

Fresh fod market - worth seeing!. An exceptional fresh food market with stalls full of fresh food. You will find fish and seafood, with all kinds of Mediterranean sea creatures. Fruit stalls full of all kinds of fruit, selling fresh smithies as well! Typical fresh meat and Catalonian jamon stalls, a must see place.

A visual delight. La Boqueria is a large food market, located on La Rambla, Barcelona’s iconic tree-lined boulevard. I loved exploring the mix of stalls, shops, and tapas bars. You’ll find a wide range of fresh produce and products available, everything from fish, meat, cheese, fruit, and chocolate. The colourful and beautiful presentation makes the market very photogenic.Bar Pinotxo, located near the front of the market, is great for a quick bite. The Xuixo, a custard-filled pastry, is a great way to start the day, accompanied by a coffee. For a healthier option, you can pick up a fresh fruit salad or fruit juice at one of the stalls, prices starting from 1 Euro. La Boqueria attracts tourists and locals alike, and can get unbelievably busy. I would recommend getting there early when it’s not so crowded. A definite must see.
A must see. The stalls stocked a wonderful array of food ranging from exotic to high quality Spanish fare. Had wonderful strawberries, chocolate and tapas. A great spectacle with a great buzz
Colorful. So many colors, fruits, fish....very interesting, try some food, fish, some local sweets it's forth it!

you can't help but to come here over and over again. LOVE IT!. Definitely one of the cleaner markets in Europe. Mercat de la Boqueria is huge! I don't think we ever walked around the entire market and we went there four times! Every time we were there, getting a juice was always a must! Just a note, the prices are only one euro if you go later during the day! What a bargain. Aside from the juices, we dined here twice for breakfast. Be sure to eat at both Pinotxo Bar and El Quim. Read my reviews for those two restaurants but those are restaurants to not miss!There's a variety of vendors at this market. Everything's so colorful. They sell fruits, vegetables, chocolate, nuts, candy, etc. You can't ever get bored wandering around. Definitely a must visit for any tourist!

So fresh, so diverse and so unexpected. So we were wandering around Ramplas and discovered this market. Sampled fruits we simply do not have in the US, and no one knew what the English translations were. The fish market was interesting with the diversity of fresh fish... Go Hungry, sample and enjoy. It is very clean and safe.Hint - Look for the dried fruit vendor (two women) - they have the tastiest (and expensive) dried fruit. A Special Experience. There is some sort of green citrus they sell that is very good.

Covered food market with nice bars to sample the wares. Just off the Rambla this covered food market appeared to have a great offering of food products but also several bars that also appeared to have great samples of the same produce right there. We unfortunately just had lunch but when we come back to bcn this is where we will have lunch.

oh really nice !. I've been in Barcelona on 29th of december for 5 days with friends.We unfortunately always eat at fast foods and when by chance I saw this place I decided with my friend to eat here something! The atmosphere was really nice and the food was good! THE FRUIT MILKSHAKES WERE DELICIOUS !!!!!!! The banquets were colored, things were all fresh and natural!!REALLY NICE! If I go again to Barcelona I'll certainly come back here!

Must Visit!. If you're in Barcelona, this is a must see. Yes, it is touristy, but it's fun! The food is fresh and colors are amazing. They have a lot of fun bar seating restaurants and a wide variety of fun Spanish food! Sweets, coffee, blood sausage, pigeons, snails, fruit, fish, meat...they have everything here. Some of food is a tad scary if you've never had it before, but most of it is delicious and a fun cultural experience.

Local food galore. Loads of options in terms of food, but try to go deeper into the market for better value, as some of the stalls placed at the entrance charges double the value! Also be watchful of your belongings. I would recommend splurging less here if you are keen on visiting the Mercado San Miguel in Madrid - prices are much more reasonable there! Otherwise, this place is perfect for all the adventurous foodies.

Expensive fun. Most of what you can buy in Boqueria you can also buy in El Corte Ingles just a 10 minute walk away. However, that would mean missing out on an enjoyable wander through the place and the opportunity to marvel at the seafood in particular. The food - especially the smaller portions that tourists are likely to buy - are not exactly cheap but it still gives plenty of pleasure to munch away while soaking up the atmosphere. We ate at the large seafood bar/restaurant in the market itself - rather than the restaurant dotted around the edge - which was excellent quality with the food cooked to perfection.

An explosion of culinary delights. If you are a foodie you must visit this market. The displays are wonderful-even the smallest stall would not be out of place in the Harrods Food Hall. Whether you want a smoothie or tripe (yuck) you can get it here. Lovely little tapas bars are scattered around the market so you get wonderfully authentic food.

Fabulous Market with incredible displays but watch the prices!. We've been shopping at this market since we arrived in Barcelona six weeks ago, and it is always such fun to wander around and see all the fruits, veggies, layers and layers of chocolates in every size and shape, stalls devoted to shellfish or to pork, fowl or beef or innards (some I still can't identify!), cheeses to please every palate, fresh eggs from every type of fowl in all colors and sizes....you can just spend an entire afternoon wandering around here. There is even several tapas bars at the back serving up yummy things all lined up in dishes from which to choose. A warning, tho...the stalls in the front where you enter are pricier than the ones at the back; some stalls don't indicate the price of their things and this is where you get burned. For one unpriced breast of chicken, I ended up paying $7/lb., for one tiny mini-cantaloupe, $8, and for 4 small country link sausages, the insane price of $10.I saw one of my favorite fruits from years when I sailed alone in the Pacific down the Southern Hemisphere, a guanabana, and luckily asked the price before telling him to put it in the bag -- $80! When I challenged him, he said, "Well, it comes from Columbia! The price of the voyage is more than the worth of the fruit."Still, it's fun to shop here and I've just got to remember to ask "how much" before I buy!We also like to go to the Santa Caterina Market which is smaller, has fairer prices and is not filled with tourists altho it does close at 3:30pm.

Great Market - Tip for Israelis inside. A must see market in Barcelona. Very nice to walk around and see all the great foods inside. I recommend buying some cheese or salami. There is a stand of an Israeli woman that sells "Burequitos", stall number 133. She speaks Hebrew and it was very nice to see such a place in this market.

Interesting market to visit. This market is just off the Ramblas street and is an interesting place to visit if you're in the area. This market is similar to all of the other large city markets throughout Spain and is really nothing special but is kind of interesting. About half of the people visiting the market are tourist and the other half are locals shopping for food and it does get very crowded. The market is interesting to just watch the locals buying food and seeing all the different types of food for sale. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit this market but if you're strolling down Las Ramblas street stop in for a visit.

Foodie Heaven. We never miss a visit here, just to see the amazing displays, particularly the fish market in the centre. Everything is so fresh and each stall is a work of art - I could upload so many photos!! Go see it for yourself - its the best market in Europe.

Unsurpassed!!!. Hams,cheese,wine,fruit,sausages,fish,beer.chocolates,spices,oh my god,as the kids say,this place is without a shadow a doubt the worlds premier food market,and I could have spent my whole Barcelona visit wandering the hall tasting and salavting without ever seeing daylight again!
Always amazing. This is one of the nicest markets I have been too, perfect for the hams, fruit juices and so on! One cannot miss if in BCN!

A MUST SEE IF YOU ARE IN BARCELONA. My wife and I were in Barcelona for a few days before our cruise and we had read about the market in the Rick Steves Barcelona Book (and we had seen it mentioned in his TV episode on Barcelona). This place is a cornucopia of everything edible. You don't want to rush your visit, just take your time walking up and down the aisles in (both east and west and then take the north and south ones to make sure you see every bit of it). We decided to get the makings for sandwiches and other treats, plus a bottle of wine, and took everything back to our hotel. Howevrer, you can definitely order something at one of the many sit down or stand up counters and eat there. You can buy prepared sandwiches or even get something to order. The vendors with dozens of different types of olives (many stuffed with rather exotic ingredients) and the many different types of fresh mushrooms were really unique. You will also see all types of meats and seafood offered for sale here. While it can be a little bit hard to find (there are no highly visible signs on the Las Ramblas to show you the way), I highly recommend this market for a visit whether you intend to sample their wares or not. (We asked for directions from a local who didn't speak much English but was very friendly and helpful.) This market is one of the best you will see anywhere in the world.

Boqueria ~ Foodies' Paradise in Barcelona!. It was a dream come true for me to visit and experience Barcelona's Boqueria Market. We toured the market as part of our Cooking Class & Bouqueria Market Tour with Barcelona Cooking School.Our guide was our teacher and Chef. I was so amazed with all the food choices and how fresh everything was!! The seafood was alive! Beautiful fruits from all over the world were nicely displayed. They also sell freshly made fruit juices of all kinds. We found all kinds of meat including some I never thought were edible. If you have a chance to cook while visiting Barcelona, a trip to the Boqueria Market is a must. Also, there is a great & very well established Tapas Bar inside the Boqueria. One cannot go to Barcelona and not experience the Boqueria!
Couldn't find fresher food anywhere. The fruit was so tasty, puts our in the UK to shame,the tapas were so tasty and both were so inexpensive

Overwhelming sensory stimuli. Fantastic collection of stalls overflowing with every kind of foodstuff. It's not immense but so very dense. Makes any American supermarket look very boring. The sensory stimuli and the activity is totally worth watching, hearing, smelling, tasting.

Good Market but Overpriced and Packed with Tourists. The Boqueria was a nice place to walk and see, but very expensive to buy any fruit, vegetables or snacks. A small bag of nuts and dried fruit was 16 euros.However, go to the rear of the market and grab a stool at one of the many seafood restaurants for a real treat. Calamari, octopus, clams, shrimp, cuttlefish and more. All were delicious with a cold beer.

The highlight of our stay in Barcelona. Definitely a place not to be missed. Take the time to sit at one of the food stalls to enjoy freshly prepared fish and seafood and other local delicacies that will excite your taste buds. Try the fresh organic 100% natural fruit and vegetable juices. The market can get busy but it is definitely worth a prolonged visit.

Don't miss!. We came to the la Boqueria about noon. Already packed with people and sounds and smells... The sights and smells were amazing to me. Fruits, vegetables, meats, cheese, bread... every thing you can eat or drink. Get yourselves a pack of pealed tropical fruits and walk around. We did and walked around to the edges of the mercat... At one of the last stands we met a guy fluently speaking 5 languages and making great Italian snacks. His stand is named MOLT BO. Do NOT miss.

Busy & Vibrant. Worth a visit! All sorts of fruit, vegetables, fish, meats and sweets on display. Worth buying one of the fresh fruit drinks from one of the stalls. Can get busy with it being just off Las Ramblas but it is defenitely one of the places to visit in Barcelona.

Beautifull to see but poor goods. It might be an excellent example of a market for non-mediteranian people, but for someone who knows how fresh fish look like and also ecological fruit and vegetable - it is a total disaster. Fruits and vegetbles look so nice, but they are mostly gmo. Fish is at least 5-10 days old, and that is something you do not need to comment any longer. For me, coming from Croatia where seafood has a real taste, and fruits & vegetables are ecological, this is somethinf I WOULD NOT EAT!

Vibrant buzzing market. We were blown away by the meticulously prepared stalls. Foods and spices of all sorts on display. The only downside is that as a tourist you couldn't buy too much because you would not be able to either keep fresh or get home. I opted for a lovely chorizo sausage and a piece of cheese. I found the stall owners both helpful and polite and didn't find the produce over priced at all. However judging by some of the reviews I have read people have lost the art of being able to ask for a price before purchasing which I am sure helps. A lovely market to wander around if you are into food.

Thrilling experience at the market. We read much about this market through browsing the internet, and we were so thrilled when we visited it that we went back there a second time the next day! The only other market that comes close to it is the Central Market in Adelaide, but this one's better. Everything looked so fresh and colorful, the place was clean and people were very courteous and helpful; thankfully, we didn't run into any pickpockets, which would have ruined our great experience. We are lunch at one of the food stalls at the fringe of the market - of course, we ordered seafood Paella. If you're an overseas visitor, some of the nougat and dried fruits are worth buying back for the family and friends at home. Overall, it was simply a delightful experience; this is what going to market should really be like everywhere around the world.

Food, food, food!. You need to visit every day for at least a month to taste all kinds of food that is provided at the market. The marketers are juicy, they talk a lot to you and sometimes sing. We tried jamon and some fruit cocktails.

Colours, smells and flavours. Probably the most famous marketplace in Barcelona. Right in the middle of Las Ramblas. It is absolute must for food lovers. Well worth a visit. So many products, so colorful, so many flavours, various smells, wide range of fresh fruits, vegetables, fresh fish, meat cheeses and many other products all beautifully displayed and most of them ready for consumption. We spent there more than one hour. It is always crowds.

Colour and variety. There seemed to be a bit of everything here and ideal if you are preparing your own food while in Barcelona. It is also interesting for a browse but it is where most tourists flock so can be quite crowded. We found it difficult to find a spot to sit to have a bite to eat (not because of the crowds but there did not seem to be very many "sit down" places). On balance we preferred the less "touristy" places.

Nice to stop by, but don't know what's the fuss about. The market is very colorful with lots of fresh fruits (you have shakes and cut fruit for tourists), chocolate, meat, cheese and other ready dishes.A nice place to stop by for a little while, but a bit too touristic and not what I consider to be "The most amazing market in the world".

Wonderful day out at the market. I always find it interesting to go to local markets, to see what the locals are eating at home. This also has fantastic tapas stalls that you can sample a bit of Spain. Definitely worth a visit

Noisy, touristic, overpriced, most of the vendors were really rude!. Yes, the market was colorful but the food was overpriced.In my opinion the vendors have had enough of the tourists and some of them were rude!Even as an Istanbulite, the Spice Bazaar is most interesting to me!
Vegeterian take away. Organic Barcelona. Great fresh food at the end of the market. Not expensive, and with a variety of vegetables and cooked food.

Abundance is this market. I make a point of going to markets I love them. This one is up there in the top 3. Massive number of stalls with a stunning standard of presentation. A huge range of products...if unicorn was on the menu it'd be sold here. We bought fruit, veg and fish, bread, cheese, Jamon and olives. We also stopped and had lunch at a bar diner there. Sardines, bread, a lamb stew and wine it was inexpensive. It was a great time. Buy what you want or just revel in the sights and meals of abundant food.

A great marketplace. If you want fresh food in Barcelona, you won't get any fresher than the Boqueria market. It's a very cool marketplace with all kinds of foods from fruit to meat to breads and everything in between. It's just off the L3 stop of Liceu, and you can take in Las Ramblas easily from there as well. The supermarkets are pretty good in Barcelona, but La Boqueria has THE best fresh stuff around. I wouldn't buy fruit or meat anywhere else!

A great place for foodies. Visited the market for brunch and was taken aback by the vast array of food varieties and options available - both fresh produce and raw ingredients to buy as well as snack items ready to eat. There are a few cafes/stalls where you can eat meals but the majority are ingredients or small snack items. Id advise sampling a few items from different stalls (i had pastries, savory snacks, ham & cheeses, fried whitebait) all are prieced at a couple of euros.

If you don't go here, I'll be mad at you.. This place rocks. seriously. Delicious & Cheap. Right off La Rambla. We were lucky enough to be staying with a host living RIGHT by here, and we didn't discover it until the second day. Lame. After we discovered it, I felt like any meal I had that wasn't fresh fruit, cheese, and meats from this place was a complete waste of space in my stomach. Don't waste your money on food elsewhere. Eat here. :) You can buy food for takeaway. Exotic fruits, small tapas, or groceries for the week here. Any kinds of weird fruit you can imagine, delicious meats & cheeses. ugh. I'm so sad I can't eat here tomorrow. Please get some mango & dragon fruit for me, will you? thanks!BRILLIANT! I think it was closed one day we were there and I was mortified.

My favourite place in Barcelona . Smack bang in the middle of La Rambla. You have got to visit here for a walk around. Looking at all the stalls and sampling the food is the best il bed it here. Make sure you visit here for any stop in Barcelona.
Main Attraction in Barcelona. Beautiful mixture of colors, smell and flavors... Love it this, best Parma ham and seafood ever, looking forward to my next visit in this December 2013

Well worth the visit . So much for the eyes and the taste buds to feast on! Cones of jamón and cheese, fresh fish, fruit of all sorts and colours and so much to savour. Make sure you're hungry when you go!

Colorful, raucous fun. Beautiful displays of fruit, produce, meat, fish, flowers and baked goods. Bought some empanadas to snack on, had a brunch of curry tacos from the organic foods vendor, drooled over pastries, watched crepes being made (savory not sweet) and had a really nice time.
great for fruit. The Mercat is very important to see,great place to buy and eat fresh fruit and juice, you will see and can buy any sea food you want its perfect Market.

a must see in Barcelona -- GREAT marketplace. We loved our exploration of La Boqueria -- it might get missed if you aren't paying attention walking on las ramblas HOWEVER don't miss it! There are fun looking tapas bars through the market, great stops for fruit & cheese & meats. We all left the market with purchases. Very reasonable prices. A great market. Would most definitely return on next visit to Barcelona.

A must see while in Barcelona. I felt like I could have spent our entire vacation budget in this one spot. This market had the largest variety of fruits, vegetables, meats...pretty much everything I have ever seen. We bought some fruit, olives, and chocolates while we were walking around. They were all delicious.Also, highly recommend eating at Quim and Universal if you decide to go for lunch. We ate at both on separate days and the food was out of this world. You may have to wait for seats to open up, but the wait will be worth it.

A culinary feast for the eyes and the stomach!. I always try to go here when I'm in Barcelona. I've only ever managed to eat lunch here once though, as it's always so busy but that was a while ago and I can't remember which counter I ate at. When I say lunch I mean between 2pm and 3pm though not 11am or midday...On my last trip I came away laden with so much fresh meat and cheese, I thought I'd be chased down the road by dogs! An experience not be missed when walking down Las Ramblas and there are some real characters running the counters; keep an eye out for Juan Bayen of Bar Pinotxo, with his characteristic double thumbs up!

Great place for food lovers. Best place to buy Iberico ham is at Marcos! They have everything food lovers will want to buy. Restaurants are located at the back of the market where you can savor delicious paellas. A visit to Barcelona will not be complete without visiting this market place!

Quite a let down- Excellent fruit display. Having read such great reviews about the market I made time to visit it. It was about 11am and only about 20% of the stalls were open. They were mostly fruit stalls and few meat stalls. The display was fabulous but stall after stall it was all about fruit juice and fruits. Very touristy. Lacked the buzz and energy of a real market. Asia boasts of several markets in different countries which are actually trading centres and hence to me this seemed very staged
So much to explore. We had an amazing time here trying different fruits and meats. We found a nice restaurant in the far back on the right with excellent service too.

Mesmerizing. This is a scene that Americans do not experience often. The market is enormous and captivates ones attention. The various stalls with so many different food items. I am sure the FDA would shut it done within minutes but apparently it works for the Europeans. It was a fun experience and one I would repeat

Don't miss this on your trip. Unfortunately my friend and I only had a few hours in Barcelona, we discovered this Market as we walked up Las Rambla from where the coach dropped us off on Ronda Litoral. What a mesmerising sight, we found the Chocolate stall and had great difficulty in leaving again. It has everything, brilliantly coloured fresh fruit, vegetables, fish and meats (Try the freshly made fruit smoothies) Make a picnic and take it with you as you walk through this wonderful city.

Oh my God, do not miss this place if you love food!. The beauty of food is the highlight of this amazing market - anything and everything, beautifully displayed - only the freshest and most gorgeous abounds here. Avoid the crepe guy - He has displays of crepes, but what you actually get is his ego as he prepares the crepe and a result with no taste that contains half the ingredients he shows in his display. GO FURTHER into the heart of the market to the Kiosko Universal, a square bar set up inside of which is all the action: cooking, preparing, etc. Adorning the counters of the bar are trays of some of the most gorgeous mushrooms - 0-12 varieties, waiting to be sautéed to perfection with Spanish olive oil and garlic...and a splash of sea salt - (Salteado setas) ummmmmmmmmmmmmm......we also had a plate of roasted vegetables (surtido verduras), equally superb......and a plate of grilled gambas (shrimp) - big ad beauty! With 2 beers from the tap, total cost only 40 Euros! Outrageously cheap for such quality! I was tempted to return again and again, forgetting there was so much more to see (and eat) in Barcelona!

Don't Miss!. Located off the Ramblas, this is an exciting market in Barcelona, well worth the visit.
