Once inside the market you will instantly feel the hustle and bustle that this busy market has to offer to locals and tourists alike. Whether you want to people watch, have a wonderful lunch at one of the tapas restaurants or purchase one of the many food products offered at this market, you don't want to miss the Boqueria. While visiting the market we purchased some colorful candy, delicious olives, refreshing fresh fruit and smoothies! Please make time in your visit for this colorful market! Enjoy!

Well worth the visit. El Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria, also known simply as La Boqueria, is right off La Rambla and is a do-not-miss in Barcelona. Fresh fruit, vegetables, meats, poultry, fish and shellfish, eggs, cheeses, a plethora of mushrooms, a wine shop, candies and chocolate, you name it, La Boqueria has it, including a couple of tapas stalls where you can sit at the counter (if you can find a spot) to enjoy tasty bits of finger food with a copa de cava, de vino, or a glass of beer, or even a cup of coffee.The colors, the textures, the smells, the sounds, everything is boisterous, extravagant, and cheerful. It is worth a visit just to immerse yourself in this sensory extravaganza. Bring your camera! (Although some stall owners have a "No foto" sign.)Another excellent way to enjoy this wonderful market, is to go to buy some bread, some cheese, some jamón (dried cured ham) and other delicacies, along with a bottle of good Spanish wine and find yourself a spot for a picnic, or eat back in your hotel room.An unforgetful experience!

what can i say that so many have not already stated? FANTASTIC!. as a professional chef who has been involved in every aspect of the food & beverage/hospitality business i have spent a lot of time shopping both professionally and as a home cook in many fresh markets, Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria is the best so far. they all have that hustle and bustle, they are all a riot of colors, aromas and sounds, but this one seems to raise the bar to a higher level ... the fact that it is near the ocean and has not only the standards fruits, veggies, dairy/cheese, meats and poultry that so many others do, for me, however, the abundance of fresh fish and seafood is what sets this market above and beyond so many others ... in my 2 weeks touring Barca i returned to this market several times. i ate there 3 times (Kiosko Universal), and shopped there every visit ... where else can you get "ice cream cones" filled with Iberian ham? LOL ... the spices i bought and took home with me will not only compliment the foods i will be cooking, but they will help me to remember and relish the hours spent in Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria ... i am a foodie who sets aside most of my travel budget for food and i willingly far exceeded what i thought i would be spending in Barca. to be able to purchase goods that cost 3, 4 or 5 times as much at home, and have them be so fresh too, was a major highlight of my trip to this market ... to be able to sit in my room, after going to this market, while working online (someone has to pay for these trips LOL) and enjoy the local food at a cheaper price was also a pleasure ... although some of the folks in the market seem a bit weary of tourists, most know they are a big part of their business and so they are very cheerful and helpful. not everyone speaks English but all you need to do is point at what you want, they put it on the scale until you say stop, and its a done deal ... its also one of the best photo-ops you will ever encounter.

A Magnificent Market. This market is located on Las Ramblas. The sights, sounds, and smells will stimulate your senses. We observed one couple who had the right idea: they purchased a fresh baked baguette, then went to an adjacent stand and bought some fresh cut jamon, followed up by a bottle of local red wine that they purchased from another nearby stall. It was obvious that they were ready for a simple yet fresh lunch.We ate at one of the food stalls located inside the Boqueria where we indulged on succulent fresh grilled seafood: calamari, mussels, clams and a variety of other seafood.It was obvious that the vendors here take great pride and care as each stall was clean, and their food items carefully stacked and placed with great precision. We also found some lovely gifts for friends at this vast market-so a trip here can eliminate some gift shopping for you as well.The bottom line: Take an hour of your time when strolling down Las Ramblas and visit the market Boqueria, peruse the vendors and their well-stocked stalls, and grab a quick bite to satisfy your appetite. The choices are endless and you will not go away disappointed!

Mecca for foodies. For individuals who love to eat and cook it's like visiting a museum of food art. It is a cornucopia of visual delights & appetizing smells. The colors of the different vegetables, the display of meats, sausages, hams, fresh fish, creative candies, baked goods, chocolates, take out foods are all part of this lively marketplace. Watch the expert carvers cut and vacuum pack the ham into wafer thin slices.
Make sure you visit this market!. Try and eat at one of the tapas stalls at the back of the market if you can get a seat.Great for photos and presents.

la Boqueria. Busy and bustling local food market just off La Rambla.We took our time walking round all the different stalls, soaking up the atmosphere, different smells and vibrant colours before sampling and buying various foodstuffs and taking them away for a picnic lunch. Fresh fruit smoothies cost from 1 euro, delicious deep fried cod balls 3 euro for three (very filling), olives from around 60 cents per bag and various breads from around 1 euro.For anyone who is a bit sensitive - beware there are sheep heads, skinned rabbits, brains etc on show in the butchers stalls. If you want to see the fishmongers avoid a Monday as there are only a few open on that day.

VISUAL AND FOODIE PARADISE. This market is just off La Rambla. It is a foodie paradise. Spices, fruit, vegetables, fish, jambon, etc etc.. Photo ops galore. Purchased some saffron and paella spice mix. Packed with tourists and locals at lunch hour. Various food stands for lunch. ANOTHER MUST SEE IN BARCELONA.

Unmissable. What a place! For foodies everywhere this is a must. Granted it's usually full of visitors to the city and takes an age to get round but check out the butchers, sellers of cured meat, the fruiterers and the fishmongers in the central area. There are quite a few tapas bars within the area of the restaurant and it's a very atmospheric place to eat

Colors and tastes. If you wanna feel the real flavours, colors and tastes of Barcelona, visit the market Boqueria!!!It is an amazing place with hundreds of goodseverything you wanna buy, can be tasted with no problem.We bought lots of the famous Catalonian chocolate, good pieces of jamon, olive oil of extra class, fantastic honey with pieces of fruits in the bottle, cheese of various sorts, and sausages!!!! Boqueria is a real paradise for those who value good food and like traditional markets.But be careful of your pockets and bags!! The place is always overcrowded so it is a paradise not only for visitors but also the thieves

Great photo ops. Just a few short blocks from our hotel which made for a quick visit. Make sure you walk through the market before deciding what you want to snack on. Price vary considerably and there are no real bargains. Go lunch time and snack your way thru and have a tapas lunch! We took amazingly colorful pictures. Mostly tourists were causing the crowds.
Worth wandering around. We visited the Mercat whilst stroling down Las Ramblas. Very interesting and vibrant inside - well worth a look at the produce and stall holders.

The real reason to visit las ramblas!. If you love food and atmosphere then go...end of story! You will find everything needed for a picnic of epic proportions here (maybe in park guell?) all at good prices. You can buy everything from a mouthful to a whole fridge full...a vibrant and bustling foodie heaven with everything from pink crab burgers, colourful marzipan fruits, twisted salt bread, local thick hot chocolate with dunkable churros and pint mugs of sweet, strong ruby red sangria! My dreams are made of this!
Food market. A feast for the eyes and a feast for a photographer. Abundance of colours, textures and smells - well worth a visit!

enjoy your time. sea food, fruits, candies... Advised to have a lunch at El Quim or Barceloneria.Little squids (chipirones), green fried peppers (pimientos), patatas bravas (kind of french fries with a good souce), fried prawns with garlic is a must to try

Fresh fruit at a good price if you venture deep inside. We picked up all our fresh fruit here at great prices.The atmosphere was busy so avoid going at lunch time if you want to shop.Venture deep inside the market for better produce at even better prices.

No longer superb nor good value, still holds some gems, but sadly now is often a ripoff for tourists. My vibrant memories of shopping at (and simply experiencing) this once-superb market were dismissed this time around as a result of several dishonest (or simply greedy) purveyors who charge travelers much higher prices than they charge non-travelers. The days of La Boqueria offering good value are gone. Best tips: Entirely avoid the merchants by the main entrance, and instead do all your shopping deeper inside. Never purchase from a vendor whose prices are not displayed. Skip prepackaged items, or candies that look handmade or artisanal but are not. Better yet, skip La Boqueria entirely, and hit one of the city's many other fresh markets, where value is great and travelers are not disrespected by being misled or overcharged.

What a grand Market!. This was a market that tantalizes the senses. The fresh foods and displays are awesome. I purchased fresh fruit, dried fruits and even lunch at this market. The food at the back was so yummy and even vegetarian at the stall I choose. The thing to do is purchase a beverage at the little bar aside of the market and eat your fresh lunch there. The aisles are close,though I've never had a problem with pickpockets, always keep money in a safe place when ever there are close people. Try a tasty delight and enjoy the colors and aromas. If you go a little later in the day you might hit a bargain of buy one, get one half off. The fruit cups we purchased that way, just head further back in the market for these finds.

Worth a visit. Crowded place but worth a visit for lovely fresh fruit juices and all the sights, sounds and smells of a working market. I had lunch here one day from a veggie place, but at EUR10 to stand and eat at a counter I thought it was quite expensive, so maybe shop around if you actually want to eat here. Fresh exotic juices were EUR 1.50 a cup, delicious.

Don't eat before you go there.... There is a lot of interesting food to try at the market, from juices to their traditional ham. The food is always fresh and the environment is quite familiar. The staff is very friendly.

No market like you've ever seen before!. This was an incredible market to visit whilst in Barcelona! It's extremely colorful and all the produce is so fresh, delicious and cheap! If you have an apartment while you stay here it's definitely the place to get some food and cook it up for dinner. We had fruit, juice, chocolate, lollies, lunch and we will be back for some more delicious food tomorrow.Very crowded but u make your way through

My favorite!. I realize this market is mainly for tourists, but it is my favorite market in the world. I love the colorful displays of fruit, veggies, candy, etc at the front of the market that draw you in visually, but the real gems lie further in. There are excellent, old school tapas places nestled in the back, excellent butchers and iberico ham vendors. Don't snap a few photos and leave! Take time to wander all the aisles and enjoy all the market has to offer!

Crowded yet inviting. Off Rambla, away from the 'zombie crawl,' this market has every fresh food item imaginable. Even though it is shoulder to shoulder with tourists, it is ideal for a fresh food stop away from the 'strip.' Eat there or take away...but be prepared to queue for the few counters offering great looking tapas or seafood.

Travel Bazaar. Tourist market, but pleasant to travel on it.Natural juices in portioned cups, fruit servings for tourists, interesting shops and retail shops.All this is not to buy, because it is very expensive!

Well Worth A Visit. The market was suggested to us before our visit as a must see, now we can only recommend. Impressive was the vast amount of traditional market stalls selling fresh fruit, meat, sweets almost everything at a cheaper price. We had a good shop around & returned with quite a few items.

A BEAUTIFUL EXPERIENCE. This food market in Barcelona is spectacular! An array of fresh fruit juices welcome one and all right by the entrance, after of course, the 2 stalls on the right and left side just outside the main entrance, selling all kinds of jamon. (Tip: Do not buy your ice cold fresh juices from the first stand when you walk inside the market. These are more expensive than those sold in the interior stalls.)Pinotxo, a well-acclaimed food sanctuary just to the right upon entering La Boqueria, was closed for renovation when we were there last week of August/first week of September so my husband and I checked-out Kiosko Universal for breakfast. This is an equally very well-rated resto/bar - at the corner as you turn left upon entering the market. One must try their grilled seafood mix of shrimps, navajas (razor clams) and almejas (clams)!Only in La Boqueria have we seen such wide variety of meat of all kinds and forms - errrr... at times gross too, like Criadillas Ternero (bulls' testicles) and Conill Tendre (conejo tierno or skinned whole rabbit, lamb's head and all types of entrails!Fruits and fresh seafood were also aplenty! Name any spanish deli, spice or what-have-you's, they have it there at La Boqueria...Made us feel we wanted to try and buy everything which was of course, impossible!A must-visit place when you're in Barcelona!We're definitely coming back to this place on our next visit!

La Boqueria, a Foodies Paradise. This market is a foodies paradise, so much on offer, it was definitely on my to do list whilst in Barcelona having seen it on various cooking programmes. Everything is well displayed, they put effort in to making everything look inviting. You can get tapas from Bar Pinotxo situated right at the front, unfortunately when we visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was closed. The seafood displays have many varities of fish/shellfish and all looked oh so fresh, stores that carry Jamon Iberico that comes from the Black Pig, proudly displayed, and if I remember correctly it was 300 Euros a kilo, we bought just a little to try, and yes very good. There is everything available from Fruit/vegetables! Fruit juices freshly squeezed, Cheeses, Meat to much to list! the children are taken care of with stalls of sweets. La Boqueria is situated near Las Ramblas, and is definitely worth a visit.

the hart of Barcelona. wonderful colours, fruits, smells, tapas, drinks, people. You can restore with freshfruit drinks at only 1,50 euros, eat some delicious tapas for less than a 2 euros each. It worth spend more than 1 hour first time to check all shops and next times take what you need for tasting

Food, glorious food!. Absolutely loved this. It was all the food you could imagine contained in one market. Shoppers waiting for fish to be unloaded so they can get the freshest, baby kids, shellfish of every kind, great slabs of beef, hams looking absolutely glorious, local cheese, brains and guts and offal, shiny bright fruit and vegetables and absolute mountains of splendid mushrooms, all beautifully arranged!

Grear atmosphere shopping. Grear atmosphere old shopping market with wide variety of food such as fresh fish, serrano hams, fresh fruit, spices and many more. Not as expensive as expected. Great location near La Rambla. Was there in March 2009.

An explosion of colours, tastes, sights and sounds!. Visiting this market was the highlight of my trip to Barcelona. I absolutely loved the explosion of colours and there were so many different things to see and try! Essentially, it's a market selling pretty much all kinds of fruits, drinks, jamon, seafood, sweets, chillies etc you can imagine. Would recommend that you have lunch at one of the many tapas bars scattered around the market then wander around, trying the fruit drinks or eating some of the yummy fruit salads on sale! The tapas bars seem to be crowded all the time but you just have to bide your time and grab any seats as they become available. Most of the vendors do speak a little English but worst case scenario, just point to what you want or ask the local sitting next to you!!! :) If the tapas bars are not your style, there are plenty of restaurants surrounding the market.If you love taking pictures as I do, then this is definitely a place not to be missed. The stall selling all kinds of sweets, in particular, lends itself to many a colourful photo, as you would have no doubt seen already.It can get very crowded though so once again, please be careful of your belongings.This market was my absolute favourite part of Barcelona and I'd strongly recommend that you do not leave Barcelona without visiting this market at least once. Loved it, loved it, loved it!

More than just a market. The sights, smells , tastes of Spain all under one roof. From fruit and veg, fish to sweets. Shouting and banter from all around to go with the sights make for a real fun , free experience. Plenty of tasters available to try too !!

Fantastic atmosphere and the crepe stall is superb. This is an absolute must on any trip to Barcelona.
Great atmosphere and great fresh food.
Search out the crepe stall and watch your crepe being made by a really funny guy. Crepes taste delicious and well worth the expense.
Highly recommended.

I could live there. Stooped for a fresh fruit juice everytime I walked past. What a great market. If it wasn't for the kids not feeling too great about the fresh "animal produce" on show I would have spent even more time there.
Sights, sounds & smells. Divine - fresh fruit, veg, meat, fish, cheese, nougat, wine, eggs - anything fresh you can think of it was so wonderfully presented, affordable and delicious!

A taste of Spain all at once. Fruit, nuts, shakes, spices, fish, meat, vegetable, jamon at all price levels! Crowded, but definitely worth a visit if in the La Rambla area. For 1 Euro glasses of freshly squeezed/pressed fruit juices - too many types and varieties to mention, but all tasty!

Not to be missed!!!!!!!!. Sorry for the review being a little late. We were in Barcelona starting off our 2 month holiday/vacation for 5 days before our 24 day cruise and went to the famous La Boqueria!!! It scores a 10 on everything. The displays were beautiful with all the fresh produce, and the fish and Jamone! Please do not miss this place. The people and food are wonderful.
Amazing. Tis is an awesome market with so much to see and do it is a shame to classify this attraction as shopping. It is a cultural and social experience that is part of the history of Barcelona

boring.... After having seen some of the best, most unique and exciting markets in the world, in Israel, the UK, and more, this is a small, expensive, repetitive food market. It's nice and colorful, but I cannot see the excitement (or attraction) in looking at regular, run-of-the-mill and very expensive meat, fish and fruit stands that sell the exact same things. Would definitely give it a miss, unless you seriously like to tick things and say you've been. It also seems like the perfect place for pick-pocketing so be ware...

Get fresh fruit juices !. Oh i liked this market more than gaudi. I went the market twice a day - morning and evening - to get fresh juices ! And every time i tasted 2+ different juices. Simply impossible to resist the variety of colors. So delicious and cheap. Just 1-1.5€ The sellers are honest. The price sign was a bit confusing that I thought the berry juice was 1.5€, but the owner returned me 50 cent coin immediately. Quite impressive considering all the notorious barcelona thief/ scam warnings on the internet !

Neat market, worth a visit, just be vigilant. I had a wonderful time each time I went to this Market, all fresh food at great prices. I had a seafood grill in one the food stands and it was delicious and affordable at $35 Euro with beer for two. I had a wonderful conversation with a young couple from Germany. A fresh juice for $1.50 was also wonderful. They take pride in their presentation and cleanliness. I wish I lived there so I could come daily to buy fresh fish and vegetables, cheeses and fruits, wines and candies, spices and herbs. Just be careful of petty thieves looking for a distracted tourist. Never let your bag or wallet out of your sight. Keep your bag on your lap and your wallet (and valuables) in a front pocket, never in a backpack, and never hang your bag on the back of a chair anywhere.

Great location and a super place to wander. This marketplace is right off Ramblas and we spent hours here, tasting little here and there, having fresh juice and lovely wine. I recommend it especially if you are not in a rush. It is a delight for all senses and you can even buy some edible souvenirs :)

A must see!. La Boqueria has something for everyone! There is fresh fruit, candy, chocolate, nuts, fresh fruit juice, etc. I did not walk through all of La Boqueria due to the smell of the meat (I'm a vegetarian) so I can not comment on that part. Don't be afraid to walk through and compare prices as some vendors sell their items for 2 euro more than other sellers do in the back. I enjoyed a pineapple and coconut smoothie mix for 1.50 euro and I wish I could have one right now. It was absolutely delicious! This really is a must see. This is located along La Rambla. Items are also very affordable and not expensive at all. Don't miss it!

A sensory delight. Loved walking around this market and to be honest, the price of the produce wasn't that expensive either, when you consider it's right off the Ramblas. The colours and smells are amazing and you have to visit one of the tapas bars in the market - the ones at the back were just as good as the more 'must-visit' ones which people usually head for. A lovely experience - be prepared for the crowds though !!

My favourite place in barcelona!!!. If you are a Foodie you MUST come here....right away!! The smells, colours and piles and piles of fresh food and tapas to grab while walking around blew me away. The atmosphere is fantastic but be prepared for crowds. I wish I had something like this back at home!

A real buzz. Love this market could wander around all day, just watching and seeing all the fabulous local produce and customers. Had a lunch time drink at the bar by the main entrance which was treble what we had paid a 15 minute walk away so be aware. Well worth it though to just sit and watch, its hard to explain , its a vibrant place to be selleing fish, meat,spices fruit and wine and many many other products. worth a visit every time

Colorful and very vibrant atmosphere!. I loved this market! We came here 2 mornings in a row for breakfast. If you get here early, there are much fewer people and tourists than later in the day as well. There are fruits, pastries, seafood, and the list goes on. This is a very fun and colorful market that is absolutely amazing. You’ll love walking around, enjoying the smells, admiring the food, and taking pictures of all the color around you. Oh also, some of the food/drinks in the back are a little cheaper than those in the front! I highly recommend making a stop here if possible (preferably in the morning).

Vibrant, tasty and interesting place. I'm so used to the overpriced Borough Market in London that this place was a breath of fresh air.We ate our way around the different stalls, trying juices, fruit, ice cream, catalan sausage, deep fried cheese to name a few...and most items won't set you back more than a few euros. Pick up lunch here then head back for mid-afternoon snacks, and breakfast!Such vibrant colours and sounds you'll leave buzzing. Enjoy!

It’s very colourful, you cannot miss it. This place is always crowded by both local residents and tourist. Everything displaced beautifully and very commercialised place. It was amazed that so many variety of grocery was available. There are few bars on the Market. You can eat flesh seafood.Toilet facility is available for 0.50 euro coin.

La Boqueria market. I like this place. It is so lively. Went there almost every day. The place is busy. Many interesting food. Wow the ham is fantastic. You can get many sorts of local food there. The price is reasonable. It is along La Rambla. A busy pedestrian street. So lively in the summer and full of people even at 10pm. Like this place very much.

Foodies Paradise. Easy to find being close to La Rambla means there is no good reason not to visit this amazing food market. It's a foodies delight and strolling through the undercover market is mind boggling. We snacked on luscious peaches, fresh juices and just looking at the range of food from nuts, meats fruits, herbs and spices, chocolates, fish, cheeses.....and the list goes on!Not to be missed!

Lively market, excellent food, colorful walk. This market is right next to La Rambla. Very accessible. Not all the stalls are open the whole day. The best time to visit is probably between 10AM-2PM.
The market has raw fish and meat vendors, fruits, cooked food, and some restaurants. We mainly purchased cooked food and food drinks.

Colourful, bustling breakfast. We stumbled upon this place close to our hotel when we were out looking for breakfast the first day. The market is a colorful mixtures of stands of delicatessen. A great photo opportunity. There are several bar stands where you can sit and eat on bar stools. We ended up going here for breakfast as a routine. It might get busy at times, but food quality is always high and it is a nice way to socialize.

Interesting foods!. For those who do not live near farmer's markets, this is a sight to see. The variety of foods is perfect to pick up something to either snack on or buy for souvenirs. Tip: cut fruit and juices go half off or better at precisely 7:30 pm

its a market, and gosh darn tasty place. if you have spent the evening, the night and well the wee hours of the morning at one of Barcelona's clubs then you must heat to the market for some fresh fruit juice, a great breakfast and all the other ingredients to have a picnic on the beach. the market is nothing speal or crazy, but its a great place to grab a few things and just have a wonder around. buy a little taster from a couple of stalls for a great "tasting platter" for lunch/ Brunch.

amazing. we had breakfast at the market, it was very good, the variety of the produce was mindblowing. fresh fruits was cheap, also the variety of seafood, i have never seen before. there was spices, meat, fish, also chinese food stalls.

Boqueria market in Barcelona. historical market with a large variety of fruits,nuts, shakes and meats available .placed neatly and covered crowded but is worth visiting the place .closes around 7 pm and at this time you can get maximum discounts specially on shakes ,etc

A Must-Do. Located right of La Rambla next to Dunkin' Doughnut stand. An epicurean's delight--plan to spend some time here!! Fresh fish, tapas galore, snacks of all kinds, candy, fresh produce, spices (buy your saffron here), etc..etc! We basically snacked our way through the place! One of the more memorable experiences in this wonderful city!

This isn't about shopping is about experiencing Spanish life. It's just on La Rambla opposite Plaza Real. It has great fresh juices for €1, seafood to die for & lots of everything else in between. It does have lots of tourists but also old "nonas" going about their shopping. You can eat in there to. It's just so wonderful to see fresh produce in this age of massive supermarkets

Favorite attraction in all of Barcelona. I only had a few days to see Barcelona this summer after a business trip. My excellent hotel was walking distance from this market and I love markets so I knew this would be at the top of my list. This is one of the best markets I have been to - huge, tons of really well-kept, clean booths and amazing food. I could have wandered through here and snacked all day! I nibbled on anchovy wrapped olives, fresh fruit smoothies, fresh manchego and some tapas with rose at the Bar Pinotxo - open air tapas bar on the edge of the market. When I go back with someone (I was alone) I will definitely go back, stock up on snacks and drinks and find somewhere in a square nearby for a picnic. This market was full of fresh everything, bright colors, amazing smells and friendly shopkeepers. Definitely my favorite attraction in all of Barcelona! Even if you only have a day or two, definitely make time for La Boqueria!

Local Flavour. Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria is a covered market, mostly selling food just off La Rambla. We popped in here to get some stuff for lunch. It costs nothing to get in, there is real atmosphere and you can pick up a bargain (we bought cherries for €1.99/kg). If you are visiting La Rambla it is worth spending a few minutes wandering among the colourful and well presented stalls.

A definite must!. This is a great bustling market right on the La Ramblas. You will see every type of fresh sea creature known to man. So fresh that some are still moving. There is an impressive variety of fresh fruit, poultry, ham, sweets, nuts, dried fruit, spices and fruit smoothies. I highly recommend having one or more of the fruit smoothies. It's hard to pick just one kind. The cost for one is 2€. So fresh and so delicious!
great place to grab a great meal. This market is stunning, great food,drink and also many stalls selling clothes, jewellery etc. A must to visit when in Barcelona.

Quite an assault on the senses of eyes and noses. Had been to Barcelona twice previously but on our third trip finally visited this market. It really is a great place to see - the produce was colourfully displayed and the range of foodstuffs etc. quite spectacular. Even the fish counter seemed to be a work of art.Would definitely recommend.

Good and attractive array of fresh produce!. Went on a walk in la rambla and went in seeing a lot of the other tourists turning into the market. Pleasantly surprised at the display of fresh produce in such a neat array and the vibrant colours are so inviting that they make you feel like exploring the market more. Fresh juices lined up! It's 2 euros in the stalls at front - 1.50 on the inside! Fresh sea food! Tried some of the fresh food and absolutely loved it! Good place to try the food - you will not regret.

Hands Down the Cooliest Market!!!!!!!. One VERY COOL Market!!!!!!!It was very clear to a tourist like me, that the vendors at la Boqueria take a lot of pride in their stands!! There are many many stands with many different product offerings!! It fun to walk around the market and check it all out!! I personally really enjoyed the candy and fruit displays!! So many colors!!Highly Recommended!!

Definitely worth a visit ...... My husband and I went to this market twice, it was so amazing. The amount and choice of fruit,veg,sweets, juices,fish and meat. The colours were magnificent and very inviting. We had breakfast there the secound time and it was very nice. I would recommend a visit to this market. Also I would say, go into the middle of the market It certainly made me feel how little choice we have in foods here in Dublin.

An Amazing Display of Sights and Smells. Visited early in the morning as the vendors were setting up. Watching them carefully place their fish, meats, fruits, vegetables, spices, nuts, candies, sweets and breads as if they were artists creating edible sculptures was a delight. Took hundreds of photographs of colors, shapes and textures while the vendors just smiled with only one scolding for taking pictures. SInce we were full from breakfast and we were setting out for a morning of touring we did not stop to purchase anything. It is almost enough to move here to frequent such an amazing daily market.

Great market - Don't miss it!. When you go to Barcelona, even if you're going for few days, you should not miss this market. You can spend from 30min to 2hours there. There are many stands selling fruits/juices, fish/sea food, meat and chicken. Most of them sell snacks ready to eat like a box of fried calamaris or tacos, etc.There's no entrance fee, you can look or eat and drink.Tip: Try the fresh natural juice, they are delicious and are sold for 1 euro only! They have many exotic fruits like papaya, kiwi, mango, etc.Go there before noon, food will be fresher and colder and the market cleaner.

Great vibe. Awesome market to visit while in Barcelona as out of this world with offerings and the vibe. It's very touristy so if you feel like a local experience checkout the other local markets where you will have a better Spanish experience with locals buying their everyday food.Make sure to take time and to enjoy the markets as they are an integral part of a Barcelona experience

Amazing open market!. I'm starting to catch up on my reviews. I tried to do them as I went along but I guess, like homework, it's one of the last things you want to do. Luckily I took pictures of everything I saw and ate!All I can saw is WOW!If I was a big time shopper, this would be a great place to come to. If we were staying closer and not still wandering around looking at sites, I would've bought more food to bring back. This place is so colorful! The people are friendly and really want you to purchase their wares. However, they're not pushy like some. I did get some candy for later. If it was closer to the hotel, I would've been down here everyday!Do watch your purse and wallets...it does get a little crowded and anything can happen.

smells, taste and see. Most colourful place ever. I was walking in La Ramba and turn to small street as it was some kind of street art. On the way back I realised it is some nice smells coming my way. I turn my head and I saw so many colours I have never seen before. You can find here everything. Amazing selection of fruits and fresh squeezed juices, sea food I have never seen in my life before, sweets and oils, meat and eggs. I would love to have this kind of market close to my home it would be my best place for shopping :) Go and see yourself!!!

A must do in Barcelona. An amazing experience and must do when visiting Barcelona. Best to go early as to beat the crowds! Lots of "fresh juices" but carefull, they're not all that nice unfortunately..
Un mercat super sin supermercat. This is a nice, colorfull, tasty, rich and enjoyable place to see in Barcelona, from fish to frut, from candy to candle, from chorizo to chocolate...
A must-see in Barcelona. Wonderful, crowded, food market with so much to taste, see and smell! Fantastic fruit, lots of fresh fish, and delicious treats!

Try the best smoothies in the world!!!. We find the central market in the middle of Barcelona, in the walking street of the city.The market has a lots of things to offer, bred, fruits, fish and meet, pero, what i loved at most, was the fresh juices, witch they are selling for 1.5 - 2 euro. If you going in the evening time /8-20/ sunday close, you can try them for 1 euro each. this kind of smoothies, are really fresh, self made, and they mixing a lots of really different fruits together, in the end those smoothies are incredible good!!!You could see, all of the tourist been there, to try them, and everybody loved them! I try most of those smoothies in 3 days staying, nothing happend to me /diaria or like that/ so you should dont miss them!!!

You just can't get enough. From all types of dried sausages, to cooked paella, empanaditas, tapas,and fresh juices, and sliced fruits ready to eat. It is just an amazing place to spoil your palette, savour the flavors you will never find elsewhere in barcelona, admire the colors of fruits/vegetables of sunny spain. The best stop was the jambon bellota and pata negra...took home a lot ! This covered market has everything ! A good place to find something for the family to taste a bit of barcelona, rather that buying them figurines/or keychains as souvenirs !! again, it could be crowded, so be careful when you are travelling with little kids..

Mercado La boqueria uma maneira diferente. Spain:The Boqueria Market, as it is known today, has been through many phases of life. On the following words I'll try to give a faithful description of that rich history as we understand it. Where this market comes from is uncertain, what we are sure of is that it was born as a travelling market, placed in the Ramblas of Barcelona. La Rambla acquired growing importance as a pedestrian lane, and the market was set in the best place to attract the large numbers of passers-by and local inhabitants. Its location was threatened many times. In Catalunya, towns and cities have been founded around markets and the same rings true for La Boqueria. It originated as an open-air market, in front of one of the gates of the old city wall (Pla de la Boqueria) where fruit and vegetable traders from local towns and farms nearby would sell their products. The spaces inside the city at that time were too small to establish a big market of the current Boqueria kind and it was necessary to set them outside the walls. http://andreroque.photoshelter.com/search?I_DSC=barcelona&I_SDATE[MM]=&I_SDATE[DD]=DD&I_SDATE[YYYY]=YYYY&I_EDATE[MM]=&I_EDATE[DD]=DD&I_EDATE[YYYY]=YYYY&I_CITY=&I_STATE=&I_COUNTRY_ISO=&I_ORIENTATION=&I_IS_RELEASED=&I_IS_PRELEASED=&_CB_I_PR=t&_CB_I_PU=t&_CB_I_RF=t&_CB_I_RM=t&I_SORT=RANK&I_DSC_AND=t&V_ID=&G_ID=&C_ID=&_ACT=search

A Playground for the Senses. The colors, noises and aromas of the market will put you in sensory overload. You can buy anything from smoothies, to fresh produce. from local foods to wines. The stalls are decorated beautifully and all of the sellers' wares are stacked to perfection. You can spend hours here taking in the sites. There is also a wine bar inside of the market which is great place to sit, relax and people watch!

Very fun place to visit!. We didn't know exactly what to expect when we came to La Boqueria but i'm so glad we took the time to walk through. What a cool experience! The place is filled with tons of local vendors selling beautiful fruits, veggies, fish, meats - anything you can think of! It was so tempting to buy things but realistically when you're a tourist there is only so much of this type of stuff you can buy which is unfortunate because everything looked delicious! However, there are also lots of small restaurants lining the aisles and streets around the Boqueria you can stop and eat at. I would definitely recommend this to anyone traveling to Barcelona. It is something to see! On a side note, everyone had told us to be careful of pick pockets here - we personally had no problems but I would pass this tip along just in case as it can get very crowded and I can see how easily it could happen.

Three times in five days. After we found these markets, we just couldn't help ourselves... We visited three times, to see, taste and soak up this colourful place! Make sure you stop and have some fresh seafood tapas and a couple of €2 wines.

Best market I've ever seen!. Until recently, the Spice MArket in Istanbul, St. Lawrence in Toronto, Granville Island (Vancouver) and Pike Place (Seattle) were on the top of my list; now there's another at the top of that list: I’ve seen La Boqueria in a couple of Travel Channel shows, and it didn’t disappoint. It’s been here since around 1840 (with some modifications since) but the market itself dates back to the 12th century in this spot, in one form or another… It’s very crowded (so hold on to your valuables) but definitely worth a walk through. There’s also a couple excellent tapas places within; we didn’t get to try them this time around, but looked delicious: El Quim de la Boqueria (I hear it’s hit or miss depending on how busy they are, but general reviews are very positive), Bar Pinotxo, Bar Boqueria, or Kiosko Universal. They are all good, overpriced (this is a prime tourist spot, after all), but offer an authentic on-the-go breakfast/lunch experience. If you don’t want to sit, grab a jamón cornet from any of the butcher shops, or a refreshing fruit smoothie from the fruit vendors.For a few cool pics and a full account of the experience, check out my trip report:http://disdatdudder.blogspot.com/2013/08/barcelona-2013-part-2.html

Such a colourful experience!. We stopped here on our way to find a place for lunch today and decided to not leave, we wandered around sampling calamares and prawns as well as the local meat empanadas and fruit juices. My boyfriend loved the pizza place at the back of the market. Make sure you go and experience it! But beware if you don't like fish, as there is a lot going on there!

Amazing Sights, Smells and Tastes. Its been a few years since I visited but was just recommending this to someone who is visiting next week and was having fond memories. In fact I have photos in my kitchen from my visit a few years ago. I've never seen produce, candy and other kinds of foods displayed so beautifully. Never thought a market like this would be so memorable but it was. Its in the heart of the tourist district so don't miss it when you visit Barcelona and walk Las Ramblas.

Felt like a local. The busy, local food market was packed with tourists and locals alike. It was interesting to see and sample the local foods and sweets. Gave you an idea of what the Catalan people eat and not what the touristy restaurants serve.

It Will Leave Your Mouth Watering!. La Boqueria is a must see in Barcelona. This open air market is unlike any other market. The food is displayed in a state of art that will leave you speechless. You dont have to be a food lover to appreciate La Boqueria, it will steal your heart, indulge all your senses and let leave your mouth watering. There is vast selection of delicious local and imported goodies from nuts, fruits, cheese, meats, and seafood...It doesn't take all day to walk through the stalls, seat down, grab a plate of tapas in one of the bars within the market, emerge yourself in the chatty atmosphere. This place is quite charming!

Local market experience. What a nice market. Such colors and energy! I really enjoyed visiting, great place if you like taking photos, and if you are a food and flavor aficionado then it's a must to visit. Amazing fish sections and the meat part is insane, heaven for hams and cheese lovers!!We sat for a bite at the bar central ... A bit pricey but if you love fish and seafood fresh / grilles / fried or cooked in any way you want then this is the perfect place. Very hectic place but it gives you a good feel of what locals enjoy!!!Good idea to buy food from the boqueria market and go have picnic in some nice park !5 out 5 in my rating scale

Must stop in. Must see- it's a feast for the senses if you don't mind the crowd, the sometimes pushy tourist and the fish! go earlier in the day or afternoon. We stopped in several times- once for a late afternoon snack and once for breakfast. Most stall owners/workers are so friendly and want to chat. Food was fresh, the candy and fruit are just beautiful. Nice spot for a quick bite or drink or souvenir. It was one of the first stops on our list after our previous visits.

Try them!. Edible art everywhere, unusual food combinations and displays. Temptations in all directions. I tried some fish cookies and fruits and I had to go back and ask for more. Go there hungry and try them! If you don't, you will feel really sorry after.

Fun place to visit and snack. My vote is to make a visit if you are in the Ramblas area and want to see something different from the typical tourist shops. Definitely worth a visit. This place is a real marketplace selling mostly edible items. The juices were delicious although, the entire time we walked around, we never saw anyone make them. Made me wonder if what I was drinking didn't come out of a commercially-made aseptic container somewhere in the back. A whole cup of dragon fruit juice for only 1 Euro? Really? How'd they do that?Tip: if visiting around closing time, some vendors will "bundle" their products at discounted prices. We got some juices, fruit salads and calzone pizzas at super cheap prices during closing.

Not to be missed!. Our group ranging in age 25 - 62 went to this market just off the Las Ramblas to have breakfast, we enjoyed every minute walking around and every thing we ate and drank! The market is clean, had no smells and the products looked fresh and appetizing, so beautifully displayed, looked like art works! Not to be missed when visiting Barcelona.

WOW. This was on our to do list and boy i am so glad we did. It is sensory heaven the smells, sights, tastes etc are out this world. An array of colours , displays , variety feast your eyes and makes this not just a shopping trip but an experience. I loved it, i cant write anything that hasnt already been said you must go and experience it for yourself especially if you are a bit of a foodie n this kinda stuff floats your boat.

Yum yum yum!. We found this on accident while wondering around the city because we had some time to kill before the travel bound free walking tour which is also amazing and fell in love with the market! Lots of colors and delicious juice and fruit and finger and more substantial foods! Dont eat before coming so you have room for it all!

Nice Colorful Market. It was a colorful and large market, every type of food you could imagine. The kids favorite was of course the candy selection ;) I loved all the different seafood available. A nice stop in Barcelona :)

FUN. Colorful and lively is a feast for your senses. Our first steps in Barcelona were inside this market (our hotel was literally around the corner). We had a tapas lunch at Bar Boqueria and had the opportunity to mingle with residents buying groceries and with tourists going crazy with their cameras. Simply a great place to spend an hour smelling and tasting local foods.

For both locals and tourists! Try the coffee, tapas and juices!. A wonderful colourful market right on La Rambla! Very crowded, especially in July between 11am and 3pm! We often went around 10am for a coffee at the back, followed by a fruit juice. Juices are 1 euro at the back, 1.50 at the front (I suspect they are all from the same place and have sugar added - but they are still very good)! We then returned in the afternoon for lunch. There are nice tapas and empanadas from the cafes at the back. Beautiful photos. WC at the back, 50 cents or free with a receipt from a market stall. Definitely recommend!

Fresh flavours. True Catalanya cuisine. These markets are easy to find and are a must-see destination. Be sure to wander to the most authentic stalls which are at the back of the markets. Sadly the stalls nearer to La Rambla are a bit touristy. The markets off an excellent selection of chorizo, morcilla, Spanish cheese, bacalao, etc etc. enjoy this rustic and simple food market

A Barcelona Tradition. The la Boqueria Market is right on Las Ramblas so it is easy to find, but also crowded from the tourists spilling in from Las Ramblas. The market offers a wide variety of fresh fruits, fish, meats, cheese, etc... On the outskirts of the market, there are a few tapas bars where you are able to sit and order food - if you can find a seat. Take the time to walk down each aisle and check out the stalls in the back of the market - great wine shops. My husband and I always hit outdoor markets like this when we travel and we really enjoyed la Boqueria. Just be prepared for crowds and a tight squeeze among the aisles.

Must see in Barcelona. Great food market, enter to smell & see hundreds of diffent kind of fresh foods: fish, shellfish, many kinds of meat, colorfull fruit & veg from around the world...Some food stalls are too touristic and expensive, but there's still many very interesting ones: one that only sells diferent kinds of eggs, some selling nuts... Its an experience overall. Must see!

A vibrant place. We spent about an hour or so walking around the market looking at the various items the traders had for sale. It's always an interesting experience in a foreign country and gives you an idea of what locals like to eat. It reminded me a lot of Borough Market in the UK! There are a lot of tapas bars in and around the market itself, so when the walking around has made you tired and hungry there are lots of places to stop and eat. It's located along the La Ramblas so it is easy to find. The market is pretty crowded - both with locals and tourists - so do be careful with your belongings.

Must go to. We only went on our last day which was such a mistake. The juices (strawberry and coconut is what I had) are amazing and cheap. You can find some great food here and it's freshly made by the locals. Definitely go if you're in Barcelona.

Wonderful food everywhere!. What a treat, in more ways than one. A sensory overload of noise, crowds, smells, and food of every imaginable kind. Markets like this are always high on my list to visit whenever I’m overseas and if you are even slightly interested in foods, they are a must see experience. Be sure to make you way to the back and outside edges of the market where you can buy tapas and many different freshly prepared foods, sit and people watch. There is also a great wine shop that sells wine and sangria by the glass. A real treat!

Quality, choice and tourists. This market is the biggest and most well known in Barcelona. To me it was also the most convenient as it was just across the street or so from my hotel.There is a lot of kiosk selling fruits, juices, vegetable, cheeses, meat, poultry, fish, ham, nuts...even some tapas place. The quality is excellent and depending on the stall, you can also have a lot of information on the products and their difference. You can even try a few sample first before buying... I had a small kitchen in my room so i went a few times to buy cheese, ham, bread, sausage, chorizo...I tried several things and receive great information as well. The Iberico ham even if it is pricey was much more affordable than in restaurant. In the market, you are also sure of the quality since it is packed in your face...I felt that in restaurant, a lot of the time, the iberico ham could have been some cheaper mass produce stuff...Since it is known, cited in every guide book and right off the ramblas, it can also be very crowded especially at the end of the afternoon or beginning of evening. I usually went in the morning. Less, crowded, more time to look and asked questions... A bit ''safer'' as well i imagine...

Colorful market. As an Asian, I am used to seeing the exotic fruits, but it's still a very vibrant place full of colors and smells. So going there once for me is enough. Just make sure you check out several places before buying a product because there could be considerable difference in prices. But overall, they are reasonable and the fruits are very delicious and well-riped.

Fun, fun, food. Ok, so this place is a market. However, it is actually a bit more than that. You can easily come here (I suggest 10 a.m. When it will be crowded, but all stalls will be selling or about 2 p.m.) and have a huge do it yourself fresh food brunch or afternoon tapas.1. There are lots of fresh fruits that are either made into juices or served in ready to eat bowls.2. There are a wide array of local meats and seafood. Just the sight of the fresh fish and venison is impressive. 3. Tucked in the market toward the back, as well as around the sides are places where you can have tapas and freshly prepared foods. In the market the service is generally at a counter with or without stools, while on the sides there is restaurant style seating at approximately 6-8 places.4. There is a nice wine shop on the north side of the market that offers wines and sangria by the glass for 2 or 3€. They have a knowledgable English speaking staff that can help you pick a nice bottle of Spanish wine or cava.

Market Place Visit. Went there after the 11.00-13.00 rush hours, but still, very crowded. The main entrance was occupied by fruit store selling fresh fruits and in particular juices. Well, juice were all ready mde and I tend to believed that they added sugar to them, my friend's kid tried them and both said that they were simply too sweet, unnatural. The store keepers kept piling ice to keep the juice 'cold', unfortunately some ice fell to the ground and made the floor wet, slippery and dirty. Otherwise, shops are ok, not that much variety though, but enough for tourists. Worth visit as it is well publicized by the touring community.

A vibrant market for your daily need. I suppose giving an "average" rating is not fair because I am a Chinese frequent local wet market, so there is nothing there really surprise me. To others, I am sure this could be an interesting place to be. If you stay in an rental apartment like us did, then this market is a must visit on your 1st day. Not only to sight seeing, but also to stock up on your daily supply. Do pay attention to their business hours because some shops close in afternoon while others close early in the evening.Eggs and ham are in good quality and less expensive than other shops we visited. If you fancy making pasta for dinner, you'll find all the ingredients you need including exotic spices! One thing that may interest you is the traditional Turrón you can find here. It is a traditional candy consume by locals during x'mas time. Made with honey, it is very sweet and tasty. Make sure you stop by the candy stalls and give it a try.

Amazing place to visit. Tons to see, eat and smell. Our hotel was really close to the market so we stopped by everyday. Once as it was opening, once as it was closing and once in the middle of the day. You must stop and get something to eat here. I suggest Tapas so you can sit and people watch as you're eating. There are other smaller markets throughout Barcelona (better deals if you have an apartment and cooking for yourself) as this place is a bit expensive. Nonetheless highly recommend even a walk through.

Should be 1st on everyone's list. La Boqueria is a must when in Barcelona. Although a little crowded at the entrance, venture in and you will enjoy the sounds, smells and tastes of Barcelona. Take some time to wait for a stool at one of the many tapas bars and enjoy a cold beer or glass of wine, fresh tasty food, and chat with the traveller beside you. Seafood dishes especially good. Overall, 2 hours well spent, will cost the same as a tour or entry to one of Barcelona's many attractions..........and you get a "free" lunch!

THE TASTE OF BARCELONA. If you wish to taste, smell, feel Barcelona then go to La Boqueria market. Easy to find-going down La Rambla on your right hand- and so vibrant, this market will absolutely stimulate your senses. I'm not sure why, but while I was looking around I was filling happy and careless. Don't miss to try a fresh juice. There is a big variety of them.

Barcelona MUST go place and MUST EAT and DRINK. You're a tourist and walking up and down La Rambla. The Barcelona HEAT is getting to you. You're all sweating and sticky. You have to visit this Market. Located 1/3 way down from Catalyuna. Make sure you grab a fresh juice. A Coconut/Kiwi/Pineapple or whatever you fancy. Cool yourself down first and find a nice place to sit inside the market. Grab a beer or a Sangria and indulge yourself the fresh food that Barcelona has to offer. Watch the people walk pass and enjoy your stay. You'll have a big smile on your face. I did and my wife thank me for it.

DO NOT MISS!. A very fine market with all the fresh produce of the land and the sea! You may buy some jamon or dried mushrooms and other products. You may also eat in the small tapas bars inside. Try mixed mushrooms, gambas, calamari etc. Then buy some fresh fruit or juice from the stalls. Very good value for money!

So much to see!. As our hotel was very close we came here a few times and every time there was something we had missed the time before. The fresh juices are delicious and so cheap. We didn't get to try much of the food as it was always crowded but just being in the market is an amazing experience- so many locals buying there weekly groceries and such fresh produce. Great experience.

My favorite spot!. Each time I visit Barcelona, this is my first stop! We just love the food and the fish displayed, the lively atmosphere and the vibrant colors. Make sure to pick up couple of mangos or dragon fruits before you leave, especially if you don't see them often in your homecountry

Who needs supermarkets!?. This is a must see when visiting Barcelona. You don't need more than around an hour to take in all it has to offer, but it is well worth the trip. The market is located just off La Rambla, so it's easy to find. Fresh fruit, vegetables, meat, fish etc all available here. The colours and wonderful and the atmosphere is buzzing. There are clearly a lot of tourists at the market, but there are plenty of locals as well. Elderly women push their bags out in front of them to clear a path for themselves; it's all great to see. Just watch out for your ankles ;)Make sure your hotel room has a refrigerator to store the samples of everything you buy to take back home.Tip: after 2pm, several stalls start shutting down. Try to get there early if you want to see everything.

Don't miss the market to enjoy the culture of this city!. Our guide included a visit to the market on our tour and it was one of our favorite stops! What a great window into the culture of the city and its inhabitants! It was beautiful to see the displays of fresh food and the crowds of people. Made me long for something similar in the US, where our weekly farmers' markets fall far short of this one!

FABULOUS!!!. If u really wanna have good and i mean reallllly good food then visit this market. At first you will feel as if you have come to some vegetable/meat market but keep going. You will have all sorts of variety here. I opted for tacos and burritos....mmmmyummm. In 4 euros you will overload your stomach with all kinds of topping....hot liquid cheese, rice, guacamole, chicken salad, and a large pork rib. if you've already had your fill then buy a glass of fresh juice and refill your senses.

A must. The Boqueria is definitely a must see in Barcelona, get there early in the morning (before the legions of tourists arrive) and have breakfast at one of the food counters... no better way to experience the local culture. Food is fantastically fresh and there is definitely no shortage of options/variety to fit any taste.

awesome but be careful of pickpockets. I have not seen a wet market this awesome. YOu can buy your jamons, anchovies, olives, empanadas, sardines, candies and other Spanish goodies here. It was sad that we came here the last day, otherwise we would have just eaten here rather than restaurants. They have tiny stores that serve food. If you looove Spanish cuisine, you must visit this place so you can bring with you delicious food souvenirs rather than magnets or keychains. Everything I bought here was awesome! While you are enjoying the market, please be careful of your belongings. There are a lot of pickpockets here, Ramblas is know for that.

One of the best food market!!!. This market is amazing! wow.. Crowded market with fresh ingredients to inspire any cook. An assortment of things to see, eat, and discover. A cultural experience you will not want to miss.Do head toward the very back and start your journey there. Things are cheaper, friendlier and less crowded. I visited twice and just love going to every stall and pick up something interesting or try a local flavor...I understand tourist are being warned of pickpockets, hmm myself and spouse are pretty careful and keep things close, so its really safe.

Awesome. A veritable cornucopia of delicious cured meats, fruits and fruit juices, chocolates, and other savory and sweet items. So many vendors to choose from selling similar items. Always packed. If you love jamon iberico then you need to stop by here; it's sliced fresh straight from the pig's leg. Stopping by near closing time will likely allow you to take advantage of the fruit vendors trying to sell off the their remaining daily inventory.

Don't miss this one!. Prepare to be bewildered by a profusion of fruits, fruit juices and freshly prepared fruit. Coffee bars, spice stalls, more varieties of eggs than you imagined, sweets and ice creams. A paradise for photographers. A feast of sea food awaits you with shellfish I had never seen, rich tuna that begged to be cut into bite size chunks and cuttlefish out of 10,000 leagues!Really good espresso at the Pinotxa bar and reasonably priced, too.

Amazing market bustling with activity.. This market is simply fantastic! I could not stop taking pictures - everything looked so fresh and appetizing and all beautifully presented. It has stalls selling all kinds of food: very expensive jamon, chocolates, sangria, cheese, spices, produce, etc If you don't like crowds, this market might not be for you as it's extremely busy. They have restaurants here too but we already ate beforehand so didn't get to try them.

Foodies and photographers will love this!. The food includes fresh fish, seafood, fruit, vege, breads, fresh juices, fruit salad cups and iceblocks made of varied fruits and flavours such as Sangria, berries, coconut, dragon fruit or mango. There are hot foods, tapas bars, dried fruits, gourmet chocolates, oils... The list is endless. There are great photo opportunities - stall owners were happy for us to snap some photos - we tried to buy something from the stall or ask first though to be polite. Watch your bags here - we had no trouble but you will be in close quarters with many others. It's closed all day on Sundays. Metro stop 'Liceau' is directly outside the markets. We bought a variety of goods (not cheap but delicious) and had a picnic near the Olympic stadium.

"Must do" for a food nerd when you are in Barcelona. Great place to see all these fresh vegetables, fruit, meat , fish and much much more. We had breakfast at Bar Central la Boqueria with scallops and fried green peppers. A closer explanation of hedonistic lifestyle does not exist for me.With this review I plea to add the Mercat de Sant Josep to the UNESCO Heritage list to prevent this place to prevent losing this palce for our children and grandchildren.Hope to be back soon in Barcelona

Get your camera and taste buds ready!. I went for the people watching but came home with food and wine in the tummy and also in a market sack. had planned o come to only make photos, but the smells and sight of all levels of acorn fed hams, fresh poultry and picture perfect fish kept me happy. Wish I had a kitchen in which to cook, but the vendors have picnic ready servings of all sorts of things. There is even Spanish wine for a taste.

Amazing. At home, I am not a market lover. Far from it. But on instruction from my dad I visited the must see La Boqueria Mercat - WoW!!!! I'm glad I listened.(although we did get lost en-route getting off the tour bus wayyyy to early and at first ended up in a dirty smelly rag market lol)This is the most vibrantly coloured and neatly presented market I have ever seen in my life. With every array of fruit, veg, meat, egg, spice, tapas, olive, fish - you name it is there neatly stacked and picture perfect. Even some sort of Animals heads eyes and teeth included :/If visiting Barcelona this is a must see! I would certainly return.

Going shopping has never been this amazing- even if you buy nothing!!!!. This is like a farmers market on steroids. The food is literally so fresh it is still moving! The crabs are snapping, lobsters antennae fishing, snails slinking, there's brains and fruit and pastries and cheeses and go hungry! Because you can also sample all sorts of interesting foods, juices, chocolates and coffees. My husband usually hates shopping- he LOVED this experience and we didn't buy a thing ;-)

Market Shopping. I have never seen so much in one place. The food goes on and on.Every knd of FRESH fish, seafood, lamb, beef,vegtables, ham, candy , flowers, And just STUFF! you can walk for hours just to browse.

The best market In the world. A couple of steps from our hotel (oriente) - this fantastic market was the very best - and I live in France! The mushroom stall and the chilli pepper stalls were amazing - cheeses, fresh fruit - ready juiced and on ice, tasting selections of cheeses and hams, takeaway pies and pastries, salads - open all week too!

wild!. Amazing to walk through. All of the different foods from fresh fish, meat, fruit, etc. are just incredible to take in all at once. It is crowded and bustling. A colorful collection of just about every type of food. Oh, and there is a Dunkin Donuts literally as you walk in to the market.

YUMMY!. It is nice to go round the market and buy especially the very tasty smoothies and also salamis which are very good. The chocolates were a bit expensive and also the sweets. Some of the sellers were very rude and that put us off a little.

Overpriced. We went here and found it to be unbearably expensive. Spent double our next highest charge for breakfast. Santa Caterina offers the same quality at half the price and is convenient to many tourist destinations.

As Expected. 4 day trip to Barcelona with college daughter studying in Italy.She had heard of this market as a must see.I am from New York, so it was really nothing special and amazing to me. it was just alright. there was nothing that really caught my attention as a "must have".Looked like it was in the middle of Spanish Harlem to me.Overpriced. Touristy. Noisy.I would consider this for traveling friends who are just enjoying each other's company and making the best of it all regardless of the venue.

Overwhelmingly Amazing. The market is full of fresh meats, vegetables, fruits and candies. It is a very busy place, so watch your belongings. One can spend hours in this market, wandering from stall to stall, each having their own specialty. Don't miss this one!

Yummy. I wish I had a market like this here. All sorts of fresh foods for sale. If I go back to Barcelona I'm staying in a place with a kitchen to buy fresh and cook up some of the foods available.We ate in one of the food stalls by the fish section and it was some of the best food I have ever eaten. A bit pricey through.Most certainly worth a visit.
Wow. Even if you do not want to purchase fruit/seafood/meats you have to experience this beautiful market.One of my best photography experiences.Do not miss this market!

Overwhelming!. We stopped by to visit the La Boqueria while we were strolling along Las Ramblas on a Saturday afternoon. I was immediately overwhelmed by all the crowds of people, the heat, and the smellsfrom the different foods. We walked up and down several aisles and then it was time for me to leave. It was an overwhelming experience for me and although unique I was not prepared for it.

una paradiso! dont miss it:). its a living paradise! a semi open market full of differnet banches and sellers who sell allmost everything from sweets to meat and fish. in that wonderfull place you can buy and taste local food and sweets. you can find all the kind of herbs.the highlight for me was the shops with fresh fruits/fruitsalads. you cant go there and dont have one of these! :) so many colors...you just cant get enough of it. plus the market is surrounded by restaurants and other stores. amazing..dont miss it! its in the heart or the famous la rambla street.you will easily find it.

SPECTACULAR (intentional caps). If I could add another star I would. This market is a little hard to find although it is right next to Ramblas. Inside this covered marketplace are foods that beggar your adjectives. Ham, Fish, Vegetables, Fruit.... all are available. It would be easy to wander the isles for hours. Near the back are places to eat, and although small, offer unbelievable food for a reasonable price. Our group ate there for breakfast and lunch we were in the area.DO NOT MISS THIS!!

This is a must.. The Mercat de la Boqueria is a wonderful place, with delicious local foods, several handmade chocolates, fruits of all kinds imaginable ...The place is similar to the "free-trade" markets that we have in Brazil, though - different from what we do here - there you can not touch the fruits and items that are exposed (before learning it we paid almost 3 euros in an apple). However, the experience of walking among the local people and taste freshly made foods (such as a wonderful shrimp in a stik) is really a must.

Amazing food market - pick up breakfast or a snack too. If I had to visit one place in Barcelona, it would be Boqueria market every time! I love food and anything to do with cooking. And love people watching. This market fits the bill perfectly on all of these! A real feast for the eyes, as well as an education in what parts of animal bodies can be eaten (referring to the offal stalls). The market gets very crowded and you need to be aware of pick pockets. We visited at about 11am on a Monday morning in June, to find the market was closed; don't know why this was and there were disappointed crowds of people arriving. We went back the following day.Tip: pick up a pastry for breakfast or a sandwich for snack / lunch from the bakery stall "Forn de Betlem" left from centre towards the back of the market. Really fresh and tasty, at a fraction of the price of hotel food. We also stopped off on our way home, instead of buying food at the airport.

Taste of Barcelona. Going to this market is an experience you can't miss. I was astounded at the wonderful selection of fresh fruit and vegetables, and then there is the huge selection of fish, seafood, and meat.....not to mention the cheese, breads, pastries, spices, etc. Plenty of pre-cut fruit is ready to buy and eat as well as all kinds of fruit juice and juice mixes in cups ready to go. If you want more to eat, there are tapas bars inside the market, but the stools were full and very crowded when we were there. Around the outside are restaurants where you can go, but they tend to be on the pricey side because of the location.Looking at the meat counters is an education in itself. We saw stalls selling heads (complete with eyes), tongues, feet, and every other organ possible. We saw a few things that I have never seen sold before. That is what makes exploring different cultures interesting.The market is very crowded in the morning, but more is available then. In the late afternoon, prices drop on many of the fresh items like juice because they must sell it. Any time you go, it is worth a visit. I loved it!

MY FAVORITE FOOD MARKET IN THE WORLD :). You have not truly experienced Barcelona until you have spend a day here! It is truly magic....you will see things you have never seen before...WOW! Plan to eat meals here....many different choices + there is no better place to meet & talk to the people of Barcelona! The seafood is astounding....a Foodie Paradise!! Make this your #1 destination while in Barcelona!

Wonderful display's of food. One of our favorite places in Barcelona, this market is wonderful. Our hotel was a 5 minute walk from here and we visited everyday for 5 days. The selection of fresh food amazing, the displays of juices, fruit, vegetables, meats, hams hanging from the stall ceilings, seafood, breads, pastries & chocolates wonderful. Tapas bars in the market as well as around the market square, we loved the food, the atmosphere, the whole place buzzing with activity.

Food everywhere. I saw many pictures of this market prior to going to Barcelona; seeing pictures and seeing it in person are 2 different things; you definitely need to see it in person to experience this market; if you are hungry you will find a wide variety of foods: seafood, fruits, fruit juices, vegetables, olives, tapas, candy, nuts, and places that cook food to order. I wish we had a market like this near my house. my family loved it.

Amazing selection of food!. If you're visiting Barcelona, do yourself a favour and head to this market. My family and I came to this market a number of times during our stay for breakfast and lunch, the selection of fresh fruit and juices was like nothing we've seen. There is something for everyone from wines, tapas, pastries, cured meats, sweets and so much more. If you are able to cook it would be great place to get some fresh fish, vegetables and meat. Tip- don't buy from the stalls at the entrance of the market, if you wonder a little further into the market you can find stalls selling the same or similar food and drinks for less.

Food galore!. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Barcelona...the food on display smelt and looked great! Plus you can grab some of the fresh seafood on offer in one of the many tapas style restaurants around the edges of the market! A must see (and eat experience)!

If you love food and want to cook in Barcelona, visit here. Yes, Boqueria market is packed with people, but this makes for the atmosphere of the attraction! We lived in an apartment nearby, and decided that we should make use of the opportunity to buy fresh seafood from the market and to cook it in our apartment.We didn't go wrong- the seafood and fruit was fresh and reasonable (no tourist rip-offs here with the prices displayed on the items). We ate at Pinotxo bar (go for it!) and nibbled on jamon when exploring the market. We visited Santa Caterina Market, and felt that it lacked the atmosphere of Boqueria (and it was more expensive). As with travelling in Barcelona, be very careful with your belongings i.e. no open handbags, keep your bags in front of you etc.

jamon, turròn, cheese and fruit. if you are looking for some fruit salad on the go or some foodie souvenirs to bring to your loved ones at home, you will find it here. lots of stalls, very busy, so make sure you go later in the afternoon. fantastic selection of fresh produce.

good food market - not unique. an historic market, downtown located.Not cheap and flooded with tourists...difficult to walk.We lunched at PINOXTO but it wasn´t as perfect as other TA reviews said: good food, great wine, but by paying prices of a restaurant.Pinoxto is just a balcony inside the market, expensive for what it is...I have eaten in restaurnats for the same price
Universal Kiosk . We ate lunch here and the food was good but pricey. The men behind the counter put on an excellent cooking show that makes it worth the price!

A Must-See . You've never seen an open market until you've seen this. Get a fruit juice. Go early in the day. Go for breakfast. If possible, be prepared to buy some fresh produce. This is like what you see on Anthony Bourdain.

Great fun. We visited this market about 4 in the afternoon, so missed most of the seafood, meat and fruit, but there was still a real buzz to this place. There were some butchers open selling sheep heads, tongues and various other offal. Also some wonderful fruit stalls, with figs, fruit and vegies arranged in artistic ways. There were stalls selling spices, some with many different types of chillies. There were sweets, nuts, chocolates and other nibbles for before or after meals. Lots of delis with cheeses, jamon and other items. And lots of other stalls too for icecreams, fruit smoothies, fruit salads, takeaway baked products, breads etc. Around the outside of the market, under the columned portico, were a number of bars and cafes. The food here looked wonderful. The market is open till 8 in the evening.

Visit. Walk through the market, admiring the fresh veg and fish on display, the fresh meat counters, and the smoothies and fresh fruit that seemed very popular with tourists, visit just for the atmosphere, just off la rambla on the left heading upwards, the locals buy their food from here, all fresh and inviting, we bought pastries from a counter laden with all shapes and sizes, very popular, and they were delicious served in a paper bag, also have a few counters with seats for tapas for you to sit at but so popular had to have the pastry instead, a must see :)

Amazing market place full of fresh seafood and fruits...must see!. This place is awesome! It has so many stands packed with endless variety of seafood! Since Barcelona is right by the coast, it has access to the different varieties of seafood. Aside from the seafood, there are many butchers, cheese shops, deli shops, and fruit stands. I recommend taking a trip here and exploring the markets and see the variety of fresh goods. If you are hungry there a bunch of restaurants inside La Boqueria. Except to pay a bit more since you are at a tourist attraction. There's a good bar/tapa joint behind the market called Papitu (I reviewed this separately).

Great place for a colourful photo.. A busy market with a colourful mix of fruit and veggies,meats and cheese. Fresh juices for breakfast and a container of cut up fruit to take for the day. Probably more expensive than the locals would pay but it was still a taste of Barcelona.
Brilliant market. The colours and variety of fruit, vegetables, meat and fish were amazing. Had a real buzz. The little plates of food were really good.
Tourist attraction. The market has become one big (and expensive) tourist attraction. Still you must visit. We ate at one of the corner bars and the good was below avarage.

A real treat for the senses!. This was the highlight of our stroll down Las Ramblas, and it was a fun experience to see, smell, and hear (unfortunately, we did not taste anything!). Everything was so colorful from the produce and flowers to the fish and meat. It was interesting to see the different types of Watch where you step, though, as we found all kinds of fish guts on the ground!
Buy anything. This is what makes me want to live in Spain. Endless fruit, fish, spices, meat and everything in between. Flooded with tourists but then who can blame them its great!

A Favourite Market. Wherever we go we head straight to a market. It tells us about what is in season and therefore what to choose in local restaurants. Markets also reflect the economy of a town, and allow us to explore samples of local specialities and try a few simple sentences of local languages. I reckon market stall holders are generally incredibly tolerant and helpful and in Barcelona things are no different. This is a vibrant and colourful market with such a range of food that I only wish I had had a kitchen available to cook some of the produce. You don't need long here but it is really worthwhile especially if you relax with a tapas lunch in one of the restaurants.

freash and fabulous. stalls filled with every kind of fruit, veg, fish and meat, nuts, cheese you can imagine. I wish I had a market like this at home, I would never be away. great looking stalls with enticing foodstuffs.
