Amazing food market. Maybe if you live in Barcelona this market is nothing special for you, but as I was only visiting it looked amazing. The amount and variety of fresh fruits, seafood, meat, and tapas is superb. Definitely a place worth checking out while in Barcelona.

One of the best bits of Barcelona. We go to the market every time we come to Barcelona. A phenomenal place to wander around in awe of the sort of fruit and veg that grows in Spain. Delicious and beautiful - visit!

If you love food - this is heaven. A market of fresh fresh food with a variety of producers - meat, cheese, seafood, fruit, vegetables, sweets, spices .... its all here. Some amazing sizes, shapes and colours to intence more sences than just of taste.If you have the ability to buy and take with you to consume - DO IT!A couple of options within the market to sit and eat and enjoy the amazingly fresh food on display.

yummy breakfast. The market has a buzz about it, a slice of the local life. Good to spend a morning walking around and eat breakfast on the go picking up small portions at the numerous stalls.The food is yummy and you can get the most freshest of fruits, cheese,meat, fish and even freshly cooked breakfast and coffee. El Quim, a cafe, in the market is a good choice, great character. Awesome meals for a great price and lots to bring back home.If you choose just to visit, it is very lively and colorful.Note that it is shut on Sundays.

Foodie heaven. I'm a first-timer in Spain, so what do I know....but this place took my breath away. I ambled, I ate, I ate more, I went several times. Stunning displays of fruit, veg, fish and other goodies. The crush became impossible, but still I got served. The food at Pintxos was some of the best I've ever had and I dream of coming back for their food.

The best olives in the World. We live near the meditteranean coast in Israel and swear by the Mediterranian diet so olives are a big deal for us. I have never tasted as tasty olives as the ones we bought in La Boqueria - Ieven persuaded my better half to go backthere so I could buy some to bring home - for that alone it was worth the trip - olives aside the quality, the presentation and the smell of the fresh produce is simply divine -

A Foodie Dream Come True. Sigh. I love food. This was a once in a life time treat. It made Whole Foods look like a Piggly Wiggly. Rent an apartment. Bring cash. That's what I did and my experience was heart-breakingly real.I still tell people I lived in Barcelona. (I did.. for 8 days.)

Convenient location, and an amazing experience.. Right off Las Ramblas, you can experience local foods and drinks in the most amazing open market atmosphere. Fresh fish, cheese, and meats. Especially amazing if you are renting an apartment while traveling to barcelona, you can go to this market to get the most amazing food and wine for your travels!
Excellent market, must see!. Busy, vibrant and colourful, spend some time at this market and enjoy the range of produce on offer. Full of tourists and locals, well worth a visit.

Must Visit. A terrific market, everyone travelling to Barcelona must visit. 2 or more hrs easily spent wandering around looking at all the fresh foods then some more time sampling them if your able to score a seat on one of the few food stalls.

The Best Market!. This is the best food market I have ever been to. The fruits, cheeses, vegetables, fresh coconut and fruit to go, smoothies and all the take away food available is simply amazing! You can easily get food here to have a picnic. The food is always fresh and of the highest quality. There is nothing that you cannot find here! The best part are the homemade smoothies for 1 Euro and the freshly cut coconut for 1 Euro. I also love the little stalls selling food to go such as pizza, salads, wraps, crepes, and much more. This is definitely worth going! No matter when I go, I always leave with a bag of goodies!

Great local flavor and people watching. Walk around a bit and take it all in before you decide what to buy. I wish I had bought more to bring home. The fruits and candies and jamon and cheese and fish are all beautifully displayed and tempting. Dive in, enjoy!

Feast for the senses!. Fruits, vegetables, meats, cheeses, seafood, and much more are available at this market. It was a visual feast with so many things to take in. A traveller would have no problems cobbling together a high quality picnic of meats, cheeses, breads, and fresh produce for bargain prices and/or the street food stands offering already prepared foods at great prices can be taken advantage of as well. The market is closed on Sundays.

Authentic. I prefer this over its posh counterparts in Madrid: Mercado de San Miguel and Mercado de San Anton. In my opinion, it also seems a lot more authentic as it still remains and functions like a market.

Color, food, fun!. Unassuming from the front off of Las Ramblas, amazing in the inside. If you have ever pictured a large, fresh food and drink, European market in your mind, this is the place to see it turned into reality. There is so much to take in here, you could spend way too much of your precious travel time inside. Chocolate, candy, fish, cheese, meats, pepperspepperspeppers, fruits of all kinds, bread, pastries...amazing. Grab a bowl of fresh, gorgeous fruit for your breakfast and wander a bit before heading out to the other Barcelona sights...and maybe some meat, cheese and bread for a snack later!

Truly worth visiting. Beautiful, enormous market just off the famous LaRambla strip. Mind-boggling, eye-popping array of fresh food, fruits and vegetables. The fruit stalls tempt with cut fruits in plastic cups and fruit juices (and even lollies) at very reasonable prices. The fish market carries an amazing selection of fish - including octopuses and huge squids, and stalls dedicated to just selling all types of shellfish! There is also a stall selling all types of eggs (even ostrich!). You can sample the various hams, eg iberico, serrano and there are breads, cakes, tapas, candies, chocolates, preserved fruits.... the list goes on and on...And, there are the little stalls and restaurants on the side serving delicious seafood cooked to order. We ate at El Cochinillo Loco, a small restaurant along the side of the market - great seafood platter at a very reasonable price. Nice place to visit and have lunch.

Best market ever!!. Just on La Rambla is the gem of a market place. Great if you want to grab a snack. We bought as all pots of assorted fruits to munch on as we walked around the market. The sights and smells of all the produce incredible. I didn't think that there were so many types of fruit and veg available - makes the UK markets look pretty dire. Stalls also selling sweets, chillies, peppers, fish and meat. Not to be missed.
Easy to see, fun and colorful. This is an easy, free way to meander. Get some tasty juice. It's on the Rambla, so why not?!I think we went through a couple of times!

You'll see things you've never seen before. Huge market. So many different booths, you're bound to see some unusual things. You don't have to buy anything, just walk around. I recommend the delicious fruit smoothies by the entrance off La Rambla. Several places to eat, but we chose the handmade pizza guy. Pick your toppings and he makes it right there. Delicious!

Colours, colours everywhere!. What a spectacle! If you are a fan of great raw materials for your kitchen, and want to really envy the Spanish for all the good stuff you will never be able to get at home - this is just about the perfect spot to be at.Fruit, vegetables, meat and fish out of this world - beautifully presented to please your eyes.This place is crowded, and not only by tourists, we saw several 'locals' getting their groceries here.

A wonderful market - hard to beat!. This is a great market. It's located right next to La Rambla and it's packed with people. One might think now that this is the ultimate tourist trap. But the truth is the complete opposite.Not only tourists walk this market....lots of locals can be found eating and shopping here too. And that's a good sign! Countless vegetables and meats can be found. Fish, spices, sweets, desserts and much more. Some stalls sell Tapas and / or meals. We enjoyed very much the "Universal" (see my review), with great great seafood! And then there's the butchery "Can Vila" ... specialized on Ham (Jamon). We tried a package of the 5 year old Iberico for 150 Euro/kg. Just great....hard to describe....like candy...but it's meat! You really could spend hours strolling around here....looking at things...trying things. It's also a great bad-weather option because the whole market is covered with a massive roof.If you're into food, then this market is a MUST! We loved it....Wanna know more about my trips? Check my profile (where you'll also find my website).

Best place for tapas. Of course the market is a great place to wander round , with great displays of fruit and veg and also fish and meat stalls.But for me the best attraction are the numerous food stalls serving a wide variety of tapas and more substantial dishes.It really is THE place to go for tapas.The choice is amazing and so much more authentic than the numerous tourist restaurants on the Ramblas serving horrificly awful paella/tapas/sangria.We ourselves stopped this time at Bar Kiosc Modern 364-368.Let yourself be guided by the friendly staff (they aren't trying to rip you off but just be helpful!)Order small quantities to begin with - you can always order more as you go along - that's the fun of tapas!A nice glass of wine of a cold beer - what more could you ask for?

Stunning colours and displays of food. This food market is worth a visit. We tended to go later in the afternoon when it wasn't at it's busiest but still enough going on to enjoy the atmosphere. If you're a photographer then it's a dream. Stall holders don't mind you taking photos. The colours of the food displays are incredible. Fruit, veg., nuts, chocolate, hams, spices etc etc. The seafood was amazing and very interesting. If seeing all the food makes you hungry there are plenty of stalls where you can buy food to go. Stall holders prepare the fruit for natural drinks and the colours are like a rainbow.

Beautiful!!. La Boqueria was an overload of taste and vision! Each vendor offered an artistic array of fruit, veggies, meats, candies - anything and even some things I had never seen before! There are several places to get tapas and other delights. We had a lemon/sugar crepe and it was out of this world! The 'crepe maker' puts on quite a show while making your crepe, too! We also had bruschetta that was wonderful! Do not miss walking through this market - I so wish we had something like this nearby.

Delicious and Fun. La Boqueria is delicious experience that both foodies and non-foodies would enjoy. It is a packed food market where you can buy food for the house or go and eat your way around it. there are so many different food stalls - mostly focused on spanish food and snacks. on the edges of the market there are tapas bars and beer stalls. a must do in Barcelona (also very conveniently located in La Rambla st.)

Simply Amazing. I have been there several times and must say it is a place you MUST visit when in Barcelona. We ate at a restaurant at the back for lunch, it was one of the best meals on our whole trip. Great extensive menu, cheap prices on food and drinks,and the flavor was....well you can only imagine!

Stupefyingly beautiful. I would move here just to have access to this stunning market. Mountains of beaches, papaya, artichokes, mango, peaches, lettuces... Everything you can honestly imagine as far as fruit, vegetables, fresh sea food, fine meats, candies and chocolates, the works. It's like walking around inside a kaleidoscope. Another delicious world in there..!
Colourful place with delicious things!. Nice place to buy some yum things to take home!!All sort of fruits, in juice and in pieces ready to eat as well...and only one euro...you better try them!

Colors. This is a beautiful market! All the market stalls are very well decorated: the egg stalls, the sweet stalls and specially the fruit stalls! You can buy fresh juice, or fruit salads to go, which is delicious and refreshing in a hot afternoon.
There's also lots of sanduiches and tapas to try! I loved this place!

My favourite haunt in Barcelona. Unquestionably full of tourists but for good cause! What a phenomenal place for any foodie or visitor. The enormous variety of fresh and beautiful food on offer here is awe inspiring. Don't just look at it - this is a place to sample fresh fruit, incredible Iberico & Serrano ham, cheese, freshly baked bread and all manner of prepared foods at the bars throughout. The vendors make it easy to put your own take away meal or snack together. The bars offer some of the finest tapas we had in Barcelona. This s where the locals eat breakfast. We went every day of our stay.
Worth the visit!. A great market, everything regarding food, you can get it here. Several "bars" to enjoy various food. Fish, meat, poultry, chocolate, fruit, vegetables etc. Great to wander around.
Worth visiting . What a fascinating place. Well worth going out of your way to visit. We went on a Saturday and it was very busy. Full of fresh produce & interesting places to eat.

A feast of the senses. They say that this, the oldest of the 42 markets in Barcelona,may be the best market in the world. It is certainly the best market that I have ever visited. Almost every type of fruit, vegetable, meat, fish, fowl and confectionary us available in this market. The colours were amazing and the food that we bought was very fresh. I'm glad we had a guide becaus there were many things for sale tha I did not recognize. Go early and be prepared for the many people who are there only to window shop. And don't touch the food - they don't react kindly I've heard....

My idea of heaven. The colours of food from around the world. I went back every morning to soak up the flavours and the atmosphere- this is truly a foodie haven and heaven. It is a must ot stop at El Quim and enjoy the best tortillas, roasted artichokes, asparagus wrapped in spainish bacon, sautéed wild mushrooms all washed down with a glass of spainish sparkling- Cava! Oh I want ot go back right now!

<3 <3 <3 ! One of the world's greatest markets!. Every time I travel to Barcelona, I make it a point to stop here! A feast for all the senses! Meats, seafood, fresh produce, spices, ice cream, candies...you name it, they've got it. Roam around and work up a good appetite then stop at one of the markets many restaurants. My favorite is Bar Boqueria! I grew up between Philadelphia & New York & yes there are markets. This county's best in fact. They however pale in comparison and make me as an American shudder at our county's inferior quality of REAL FOOD!

A riot of colour and atmosphere. Busy, vibrant and an enormous array of fresh produce. The fruit was just amazing, if you are not an early morning person, go around lunchtime and buy a container of beautiful fruit, cut up and packaged in take away containers, even includes a fork. All sorts of fresh fruit juices, sweets, chocolate, etc. and you have a great picnic!

A feast of the senses. Food, delicious food. Fruit, veggies, meats, chocolates, iberian ham, seafood and restaurants, you name it, its there. I forgot the name of the place but you sit at a bar like counter and order whatever is available on the black boards. Their best dish in my opinion is the mushrooms. Tens of different kinds flash cooked in some oil and fresh parsley. Washed down with cava or beer. Note: If you have not been there before; do not stand around waiting for diners to leave and jump for a seat. You need to get a number from the cashier. They will call you.

When to Go?. La Boqueria is our best food market! Actually many restaurants proudly use it as advertising "fresh fish from la boqueria daily...". Please don't be affraid of the tasty fresh fruit delicious juices...About breakfast, tipically as you know you might go to Quim /PetitQuim or Pinotxo...yet there are som extra good ones around...but mind that you will do what we call "fork breakfast" meaning...almost a lunch :P In La Boqueria I love that you find all our traditional food, from "turrons" to "menuts" (all those things from the animal you would usually throw...).As an experience it's not only about eating, or watching that wonderful painture of colourful fruits, spices; it is also about being part of the busy comings and goings of people in the right profession strives to buy and sell. Actually they are great marketing lessons! Whenever I go I alsways end up with unexpected shrimp or cod..."look at those shrimp my dear you have never eaten such fresh fish... so how many do you want?". Just a few tips: Avoid going there on Monday (not a good day for fresh fish); If you are a REAL early bird hit there at 6-8am (in weekdays) and see the last uploading and market arrivals and the workers of the neighbourhood having breakfast. I insist not to do that on weekends because the experience turns into being surrounded by drunk tourists and party teens! Schedule: MONDAY-SATURDAY 08am to 8:30pmSubway: Green Line to LICEU -also walkable 5minutes from Plaça Catalunya (down on your right).Did you know? Until a few years ago there used to be an amazing shop with deep fried in chocolate...insects!! Wonder why they closed...History: It started as an open-air market, in front of one of the gates of the old city wall (Pla de la Boqueria) where fruit and vegetable traders from local towns and farms near by would sell their products.

Best breakfast in Barcelona. Get out of your hotel for breakfast (especially if you can avoid paying for it) and come here. While I have a great fondness for the Pinotxo Bar, I'm sure you'll find your own approach for coffee, super-fresh juices of all kinds, super-fresh fruit of all kinds, pastry or something cooked if that's your thing - and you'll do it in one of the most spectacular "open air" markets in Europe.You will likely come to the Rambla your first or second day anyway, so I encourage you to start here. It's fun to wander around this clean well-lighted place, the cost/value is excellent, you'll get a great start to the day and you're quite close to whatever you're doing next (probably walking, or jump on the metro).And you may want to give the Pinotxo Bar a try - it's just to the right as you enter from the main entrance.

Foody heaven. We visited here on aour first afternoon in Barcelona as it was quite close to our hotel. It was raining and as the market is covered it was rammed with tourists with the same idea of getting out of the rain.Two days later we got there early and had breakfast at one of the stalls. What an experience. we watched out choices being prepared and then sat on stools to eat at the counter surrounded by shoppers and stall holders in this Aladin's cave of the highest quality produce of every type and variety. Outstanding quality in terms of food and experience. You must visit and try the food. Foody heaven.

Clean Market with Fresh Produce. Since we were in Barcelona during Semana Santa, it was good that the day we chose to visit the Boqueria, it was open! As we visited the following day, it was closed because it was Easter Sunday! Imagine how disappointed we'll be if we decided to postpone our visit. Great market with great finds. If I can just lug all of these fresh produce back home, I will be one happy momma! The sausages, the cheeses, the seafood, etc. Amazing! If I can just gorge into buying and cooking it...the cost of eating in a fancy restaurant can just be spent in this market.

I could have spent all day here!. Next time I go to Barcelona - and I really hope there is a next time - I'm going spend much more time at La Boqueria. It's a delight for all the senses and you could just wander around for hours looking at all the gorgeous food for sale, having samples, buying snacks, talking to vendors and sitting at one of several bars in the market enjoying some cava and tapas (which unfortunately we didn't get a chance to do).For more information and photos, please visit our blog post about La Boqueria: http://kimpluscraig.com/2013/04/23/la-boqueria/

Best market in town!. Loved this market. Easy to get to as on La Ramblas. Just food here. But the best array of chocs and marzipan fruits etc . I always ask before taking pictures but it was granted with a nod and a smile. The smoothies were delicious and SO many flavours. They were not expensive at full price, but we seems to be there about 6pm when they were selling them for E1. Bowls of fruit too. Ice lollies made with fresh juice.The meats and the fish stalls were an education. And lots of tasters in the cakes and bread stalls.Very busy but great atmosphere and we went every day for a smoothie.dont miss this!

Just look at my pictures and you can smell the freshness! WOW!!!. Wow! that has got to be the best ever display of colourful fruit, veg & fish I have ever seen! You could pass it by as you go down Las Rambalas and just think it was a normal indoor market, and you would be so wrong it was a work of art from all the stall holders. Go there have a look and try the good priced food, Lovely.

verdadera delicia para los sentidos!!. Colors, Aromas, Tastes, Sounds: the Boqueria is intense delight for your senses. Bring a LARGE shopping bag. A credit card. Some euros. An appetite. A pair of comfortable shoes. Plan to stay in the area at least for the afternoon. Preferably the whole day. Plop down at any one of the many zinc-topped bar/cafes, and enjoy the fresh tapas offered with the vino regional or a copa de cava. We only had forty-five minutes, hardly enough to savor all this market, over 700 years old! had to offer, and yet, we loaded up on some jamon iberica y chorizos (get them vaccum packed and wrap them tight in your check-in bags and pray the dogs don't sniff them out in US Customs!!) and savored a plate of tapas with a vino tinto regional before our group headed off to the Gothic section across from la Rambla. Since this is a very touristy part of town, make sure you keep your cards and cash securely hidden. You are packed cheek to jowl with everybody. Be prepared to make a Anglophile friend or two; I got an invitation to stay in a house in Montserrat after a couple noticed my NYT crossword puzzle and let me practice my Spanish in exchange for some English. You will never want to go home again after seeing this wonderful place and meeting the friendly people. We are already planning the trip back.

The best market I've ever seen!. Our B&B owner recommended this place and I'm glad we went there. It was packed with tourists and local people. They've got everything there! It's full of fresh produce and so colourful... Check price before you purchase anything (it can be a bit confusing) and don't let anyone to force you into buying more than you want. They are a bit pushy especially when they see tourists.Must see!

Make sure you visit this market.. A must when walking down Las Ramblas. The displays of fresh fruit, vegetables and other foods are bright and inviting. Make sure you buy a fruit smoothie and a tub of fruit salad. So fresh!!

Feasting at the farmers market in Barcelona. Las Ramblas is the pedestrian shopping area that runs through the center of downtown Barecelona, between Barri Gòtic and the Christopher Columbus Monument. If you walk down Las Ramblas, you will see the netrance to the huge farmers market called La Rambla de Sant Josep Boqueria. Any tale of roaming around Barcelona must include a stop for snacks at the La Rambla de Sant Josep Boqueria which was definitely open for business two weeks before Christmas.This is quite a bit more than just a street market (it won the prize for the best market in the world, awarded by the World Markets Congress held in 2005 in Washington DC.) so you find fruit and meat and nuts and candies and drink and spices and things you never imagined might be edible in December.Even early in the day in the winter, the crowds were growing and the lines were long.The many fruit vendors were irresistable, especially the row of berry sellers with their luscious wares set out in small serving trays, with personalized forks, clearly just waiting to be eaten by hungry tourists. Everything was delicious, affordable and beautifully presented.

Great experience!. Our group (2 teacher and 13 students) made a point to stop here so our students could experience a Spanish Market. We made a "photo" Scavenger hunt, so the kids had 1 hour to find all the items on our list (We created the list based on photos on the Boqueria's Website). The kids loved it!

Worth a visit. If you are on La Rambla and pass by it don't hesitate to pay it a visit. It's very nice and crowded with lots of fruit and meat shops. Try the natural juices they sell but don't buy from.the first rows as they're 50 cents cheaper if you walk 10 metres more. However, the restaurants there are a bit expensive.

so much fresh fruit!. This market is amazing! We heard about it through a friend who studied in barcelona and so we thought we had to try it. We came around lunch on a saturday and wandered and ate, wandered and ate. We literally went up to practically every booth to try something. Since we had 5 in our group this was pretty easy to do. I loved the fresh fruit juices. I think after a week of traveling through spain and eating very few vegetables relative to meat the site of all the fresh colors was a welcomed. I really wanted to go back the next day but we decided to try another area. Highly recommend a visit if you're near by.

Brilliant and fresh. What a great experience for a foodie or not. We arrived first thing in the morning and could not just see the spectacular colors, but smell the fresh fruits and vegetable. We saw just about every kind of protein available and artfully displayed.

Unique food experience. The boqueria market is located on the ramblas on the liceu metro stop. It is quite interesting and filled with unique exotic seafood, fruits , meats , vegetables. You can select fresh foods from the ,market and have it cooked in front of you in the many restaurants in the market itself..
Wow. Lovely sight. Food fresh and beautifully presented. Treat yourself to an alfresco lunch. A feast for your eyes as well as your taste buds.

Pretty cool market. We visited the market two different mornings for breakfast. There was definitely an intriguing array of food - meats, cheeses, produce, etc. There were definitely a lot of people there, even at the very beginning of the day, so I'd recommend visiting early. It's a cool place to visit, especially in light of the history of the market. I'd say it's a good place to visit and maybe pick up some fresh fruit for breakfast, but I wouldn't necessarily spend too much time here.
Full of tourists. What was once the main market for Barcelona, is now a market basically for tourists, we went on a Monday morning couldn't even walk too many people, difficult to see the stalls.

A feast for the eyes, nose and mouth. This is an amazing market with more fruits, vegetables, fish, meat, cheese and everything in between you can imagine! Everything is beautifully displayed and tempting. Come early before it gets super crowded. We arrived around 11:00am and it was shoulder-to-shoulder full of people and difficult to move. Be sure to get a crepe from the "crepe guy", originally from Argentina he is hilarious while he makes your choice of dessert, meat or vegetable crepes. There are fresh juices of every variety - its just a marvelous place. Don't miss it.

Delightful market, very busy, fun to shop. We stayed in an apartment while touring Barcelona, so we had a kitchen to work with. We enjoy cooking and enjoy shopping the unfamiliar markets when we travel. The hard part is that we have to purchase in very small quantities compared to at home. The market stalls are very well suited for buying a couple hundred grams of this-and-that, although they would, of course, prefer to sell by the kilo. On Saturday afternoon, we were aware that grocery stores are all closed on Sunday, so we made a point of heading out to the Boqueria to shop for paella makings. We purchased a small package of spice mix, a tiny box of saffron, 200 grams of rice and half a kilo of shrimp at various market stalls. A friend of the lady who sells spice advised in halting English that chicken, rabbit and seafood are correct for paella, but chorizo is not used here. Chorizo is, surprisingly, an Iberian (not Mexican) type sausage. It's clear that regional differences will occur, and our version will feature chorizo, as we like that in our Jambalya at home. The merchants are putting their leftover fish back on ice and shuttering their stalls by 4 pm, despite the big crowds of shoppers blocking all aisles.The market sells hundreds of species of fish, some of which we have photographed while scuba diving, so it looks gruesome to see pitiful dead cuttlefish, octopus, squid, piles of little whelks, wild-eyed fin fish. The skinned rabbits and lamb heads, with eyeballs and teeth, perfectly white and no plaque, piglets with eyes decently closed, dead chickens with legs, heads and beaks, all hard to look at. More cheerful are the brightly colored fruits and vegetables and candy.

My favourite place in barca. This is one of the main reasons I come to barca every year. Great food offers and always something different to see at different times of the year. I can't remember the name of the place but there is a good tapas bar t the rear of the market, even if the owners are grumpy! About 30 euros will buy you a few drinks and a great plate of freshly cooked seafood. It doesnt get much fresher than that. I also always buy my smoked paprika from the lady who sells the spices at the back of the market. The meat stalls are also v interesting...lots of balls and guts and stuff!!

A must see when you visit Barcelona!. The market is a wonderful way to mix with the locals and experience a world of fresh foods. Seafoods, meats, sweets, chocolates, fruits, etc. The egg stand is amazing! Just thought and care goes into the presentation of the food... You just want to take photo after photo, as its so beautiful! I was so wrapped up in the whole thing, I stopped at a stall selling fudge, sweets, nuts, etc and a very pleasant young guy offered to put some into a bag and I said yes to the fudge and then was offered a sample to try... almond in Catalan chocolate with cocoa dusting - delicious! I soda yes I'd have some and I was then told 38 euro for a bag of fudge and a small bag of almonds!!!!! I nearly died, so they took some of the almonds out and brought it down to 28 euro... Be careful!!! Ask first! Super place to visit and just off the central La Rambla... Metro right outside!

Awarded Best market worldwide in 2006!!. This market was awarded with The Best World Market Award in the Market Biennal World Congress of 2006 celebrated in Washington. Nothing else to add. Judge by yourself!. Impeessive variety of foods from every single corner of the world.

One of the best open markets in the world!. We all been to food markets here and there, but this market is one of it's kind. We have never seen such a colorful place and yet so clean and organized. I hope our local market near home would learn how a market should be appealing to it's customers :)

Better than Cork!. This is a vibrant market, selling foods and wines. it is better than the English market in Cork. The atmosphere is similar, but better. The range of food is better and value is fantastic. There is a wine shop/stall selling wines/cava by the glass, which is very relaxing and romantic. it is well worth a visit, but be careful of handbags/pockets!

Superb array of culinary delights. Just off La Rambla lies the markets of La Boqueria tempting you at the entrance with a delicious display of the worlds best hams. This is only the beginning as you enter and find all things fresh and artisinal food creations by the thousands. Seafood, meats, hams, salami's, exotic fruits, condiments and spices provide eye candy to all fine food lovers. Who can resist the chance to buy some Pata Negra ham or select from a range of over 50 chilli's. We didn't and ate our way around the markets and took home a number of treats.It is a bustling food paradise not to be missed.
Amazing food. We had such a great time and very good steaks in the beutiful restuturant of Diego, the kind owner of the resturant. The fillet os very recomended.
Hustle and bustle. First thing that strikes you is the vibrant colours. Stalls well presented, facinating seeing different kinds of fish presented.

Fun, colorful, DELICIOUS. This is definitely one of the highlights of Barcelona. Go inside deeper into the market for better prices :) It's fun to explore the different food each stand has to offer. Also you can eat while inside!
Color . This is one of the most colorful places I ever visit! Everything is sooooo live and gresh. Just amazing to visit. Really worth

Great Experience and the best JAMON SERRANO. If you like "different" places to go sight seeing, and enjoying new things, you must not miss La Boquería. This place is an old market, where you can find the very best variety of spanish-food-on-the-go, salads, the best and most fresh spanish ham and very easy going people.I would definitely go back to this particular place and I definitely recommend it!!!

One of the best markets in south Europe. The market is a great variety of different foods, everything you can desire in fruits, vegetables, meats, fish, nuts, delicacies, etc. The markets opens at 8 in the morning, you really should do yourself the benefit of getting up early and go there before 10am. Between 8am and 10am the stalls are being loaded with all the goods and there's mostly local people at that time. After 10 it is crowded with tourists and it can be difficult to get around and enjoy the beautiful and colorful things.

Simply the best!. This is the best market, of any type, that I have visited and it happens to be located in an exciting/vibrant and beautiful city too. The atmosphere in the market is wonderful, as is the huge selection of meat, fish and produce available. Be sure to stop at any of the plentiful tapas bars within the market (if you can find a seat!) and sample some of the best local dishes available, along with a cool beer. Can't be beaten.

Teases the Senses. A must visit. So many colours and smells with fresh produce literally everywhere.Tried the oysters which were amazing and the stalls are arranged so well.Tip- watch your personal belongings, such a crowded area brings the pickpockets.

Must-visit marketplace for anyone who loves good food. Amazing. Just amazing. From Jamon Iberico de Bellota (which I purchased slices of to snack on while taking in the market) to some of the best tapas I had in Barcelona to cheap Spanish saffron, this was the spot I couldn't stop returning to on my trip. Belly up to a tapas bar, ideally one that you have to wait a bit for such as Cafe Pinotxo, and take it all in while you're here. Good lord, I have to make it back to this market some day.

Great Photo Ops. Barcelona is a city loaded with photo opportunities.From the awe inspiring Sagrada Familia to the hustle and bustle of Las Ramblas,this city is a photographer's playground.Yet,in looking back at our Barcelona photos,the most visually spectacular ones were taken at the St Joseps market.Be sure to look at and try to capture the spectacle of the various areas here.You'll be pleased with the visuals when you reflect back looking at your pictures.Seize this opportunity,you won't be disappointed.

Excellent food market! Get there early!. A great and colorful place to watch and taste all the different meats, fruits, fish and breads. When you first get there, it is a lot of tourist stopping in the main entrance, so if you just get passed those people, it is less crowded. Don't miss out on trying some food samples and the great fruit juices they sell there. I would get there early if you want to look at the fish and to avoid a lot of tourists.

I love this place. Brakefast at the hotel? I don't think so. Ho here and buy fresh fruit just cut as well as fresh bread - best Barcelona brakefast ever!Besides brakefast, this market has everything you could want: fresh uncit fruit, vegtebles, meat, fish, chocolate and a buns of other snacs. All I can say is that I love this place!

Historic freshfood marketplace, great for people watching. Wonderful mixture of locals and tourists at this market place which is reputed to be over 200 years old! Set off La Rambla, this is a culinary experience with fresh fruit vegetables and fish, set in an indoor setting, and a great place to people watch! Try the smoothies made from the fruit you choose, or try some local wine/cava for a glass at 2 euro. Lovely way to spend an hour!

Lots of beautiful food. The Boqueria market is just off Las Ramblas and you must stop here on your stroll down the Ramblas. Even if you don't want anything to eat it is fun to check out all the food stalls. There is just about anything you could imagine; fruits, candies, fish, prepared food stalls, and of course Iberico ham. We had some lunch there and it was very delicious. The food there isn't too expensive.

The most vibrant place in Barcelona - La Boqueria!. If you want to enjoy Barcelona with all, primarily vision and taste, I recommend you tovisit the Boqueria Market. If you start from square Catalunya through La Rambla, market will be on the right side, after 200 m. So many colors and flavors in one place! Most remarkable fruits, exotic spices, fishes, seeshells, crabs, cheese, prosciutto (jamon) hanging from the ceiling, all in one place. The best part is that you can immediately taste all of it. I recommend the place "Bar Pinotxo" (Pinocchio) because there you will be served by the owner, the famous chef, very charming and funny. Be sure to try the prawns (gambas) or lobster (langosta), chick peas (garbanzos), brioche and cappuccino and of course, white wine (vino blanco). Not cheap, but because of the atmosphere and freshness of the food, it's definitely worth it. Very colourfull experience!

Even if you don't buy anything try it as a window shopper. We wandered around the whole market as window shoppers the same as crowds of other tourists staring at stalls with fresh fruits, vegetables, juices and smoothies. The choice of food is tremendous and the quality is amazing. Seafood is fresh savouring of seaweed and cucumber lying on ice. Many restaurants buy products here for their menu.It was the first place in my life where I saw heads of lambs with eyes on shopboards!
unbelievable. Fantastic atmosphere.Colours and scents.Fruits- vegetables-sea food- cheese-jamon.don-t miss it.mixed of new and old-touristic and local alltogether.

Not to be missed but watch your toes!. Organic and Colorful! A feast for the eyes and palate Every which way you turn, there´s something to amuse and tease. So many things under one roof. This is a definite must-see for any visitor to this city. We wanted to eat at on of the tapas bars but had no patience waiting around for our order to be taken. The vendors seem to have a distaste for tourists and they sometimes do not hide it.... I would recommend checking out the stalls further from the centre lane. Still, this market is worth a visit for sure!

Freshest of everything. You can see the essence of Catalan cuisine in this market. It's actually a very big and packed farmer's market. Seafood is especially worth to look. Grab a glass of fruit and stroll.

Foodie heaven and a treat for all the senses. This is the kind of place you see on a TV travel program and that makes you start to salivate and wish you had a discount travel agent on speed dial. The selection of vegetables, fruit, meat and confectionary on offer is just breathtaking. The rainbow of colours, shapes, textures and smells overloads the senses and you start running from one stall to the next like a giddy child.I am not a seafood person at all and, on the rare occasion I do order it, I stick to a safe choice like cod or hake. However it was the seafood at this market that made the biggest impression. Everything was so fresh and tantalizing on the nose that I closed my eyes, pinched some squid from my wife’s plate and swallowed. Ahhhh, sublime… sweet... delicious! Every grown up should be able to enjoy moments like this - a feeling of daring and the fear of trying something new, (hopefully) followed by surprise and delight.Having led a gastronomically sheltered life I had great fun wandering round the stalls playing “Guess the Crustacean.” Some of the things on display looked like they could have come from the dark side of the moon!There is a great buzz about this market and even though tourists appear to far outweigh the locals, it is still a great destination.

For food lovers. In the heart of the city, just right in the middle of La Rambla, huge market with all kinds of fresh food, inclusing mariscos and fish, all kinds of jamon and chorizos, fruits and veggies and sweeeets. Huge variet of fresh juices, hand made chocolate, you can have lunch there or buy some food for take away. Under the outer collonnade an excellent wine shop where also the glass of cava or wine can be tried (for-2-3 euro per glass). A must see, but watch for your staff and beware of pick pockets. Crowdy. Closed on Sundays.

Market. The largest of the fresh food markets in Barcelona. We visited early morning to watch the choreographed setup madness, during the day and in the evening/late afternoon for the shutdown to get an overall sense of the rhythm of the market. Organized madness sums it up. There seems to be more tourist wandering taking photo's than locals shopping for produce, yet most goods are sold daily and restocked the following morning. A must see but some of the smaller Mercat's might give a more traditional experience. Almost a victim of too many tourist, I am sure that the vendors must be tired of people taking up space taking pictures but buying nothing, though to their credit they seem to be good nature about it.
Great fun if you're into food. Spend a few hours here and enjoy the local foods. Fruit is vey good and cheap, jamon serrano well packed to take home as souvenir. Really nice to walk around and taste.

Universal Kiosk at Mercat de la Boqueria a culinary haven!!!. The little “Universal” kiosk left entrance from La Rambla of Boqueria market is as good as it gets for seafood. Every dish is fresh and simple, and unpretentiously tasty. I ordered the mixed mushrooms, razor clams, mixed seafood plate and squid and patates fritas. The dishes were all á la minute and sprinkled in a pre-prepared sauce of olive oil, garlic, lemon, parsley and salt and pepper. And it needed nothing more. The mixed mushrooms were incredible with a flaked salt.The razor clams were a delight. The squid was meaty and tender, without that chewiness and the chips weren't crisp but amazingly tasty soaked with olive oil and garlic, which was surprisingly delicious. You cannot reserve a table or a chair at the bar. You have to go up to the cashier and give him your name and the number of people and then wait till your name is called out. People don't miss out on that.

Enjoyable treat. We visited the market and enjoyed the experience. Some nice fresh fruit to munch on while wandering around viewing all the food stalls.
The hustle and bustle of an indoor food market is an experience that is almost lost in the UK so I found it almost like a step back in time and revived happy memories.

Wow!. If you love food this place is a must on your to do list in Barcelona!!! What can I say? Well, the food is superb, get lost in rows of market stalls selling the freshest meat, fruit and veg. It puts anything you find in the UK to shame! Make sure you stop at one of the stands and get a fruit smoothie for €1 delicious!! The market is really busy with locals and tourists alike but watch your bags and pockets, we were accosted a few times by ladies begging for money. Dont let this put you off though go!! Oh, check out the pick and mix mountain but be wary of buying chocolates €68 a kilo may not sound much but that means 5-6 chocolates will cost you €5!! Will be sure to re visit next time I'm there

Amazing colours and an unexpected treat!. I took a school group to this market expecting a makeshift street market that went on for ages. In fact it is a beautiful fruit and veg market and a fish and meat market all in one. The stalls are well established and all around the edge are cafes etc. My students spent a lot of their time at the ice cream parlour just as you enter, through the fabulous gates eating some amazing flavours of ice cream such as Kinder Surprise. There were some bargains to be had and if you went into the middle the prices were much cheaper. The fruit and the fresh juices were amazing. The colours and atmosphere were marvellous and we even saw some street performers too. We were warned about pickpockets but kept a tight hold of our bags and had no problems at all. Well worth a visit !

colourful market few steps from the Rambla. Just enjoy the colourful atmosphere of the market. It is definitely not the best market you could ever go to and not the cheapest either. But there is energy in the air that will not leave you indifferent. Try their fresh fruits and juices and look for good bargains when the stocks of the day are about to finish.

MARKET IN bellebarcelone.com. You will be welcome by the arabesque style gates. I have heard that the name Boqueria came from "Boca"(mouth). When Count Berenger IV brought these beautiful gates, as part of the booty from the war in Almeria, in the 18th century, the passers were literally left open-mouthed.As you enter the market, you will be hit by the colors and the displays of fruits and vegetables. Every space is used to please the eye, and you can see everything, there is no rotten fruit hidden.You can always get a boost from some fresh juices and fruit cocktails. Maybe you feel like having something at one of the bars inside, some organic food at the stall behind or delicious fresh pasta made in front of you. You can purchase all the goodies you might need, besides the usual fruits... You can get all the spices, herbs, olives, and even "baklavas".

Many reasons to go. Go to the market just to see what the locals buy and sell, absorb the bright colors and array of smells. Have breakfast (or a snack) there instead of at the nearby Dunkin Donuts or some touristy, cheesy cafe. Market entrance is steps from the Liceu metro stop. Market is closed on Sundays.

If there's one place you should visit in Barcelona, it's la Boqueria!. Visiting Barcelona on February 2013 would not have been complete without seeing the market of Sant Josep de la Boqueria. Coming here was part of our gourmet walking tour, suggested by the Tourist Office. We loved the place so much that we went back again the same day and again on another day. In this covered market place you can find everything, from exotic fruits to any edible fish you can imagine. The place is buzzing on Saturday because locals go there to buy fish for their weekend paella! If you like markets, this is the place to visit.It is not only what you can find but also how it is presented. The presentation at every stand is like a piece of art and a heaven for photographers.If you are lucky enough to find a spot at one of the counters selling freshly fried or grilled fish then your visit will have been complete. Be careful of your belongings, as there's plenty of pickpockets, like in all crowdy places.

Love it... What a great place to have a wander around, lots of fresh food of all shapes and sizes, some cool tapas restaurants etc etc etc.This is definitely the place to come for your food if you are staying Barcelona on a self catering holiday. Unfortunately i wasn't but if I was I would have been down here every day buying as much seafood as I could carry!!! Yum Yum Yum!!I could almost move to Barcelona for this stuff!!Well worth a visit!

amazing. this market is incredible and the fruit etc is so good and ridiculously cheap compared to the UK. there are some stalls that may be more geared to tourists but the local produce is fantastic. it's just off las ramblas so really easy to find.

Great luch stop along La Rambla area. This place is along the side of La rambla area. It is a food/fruits market with lots of catalan classics. We dine at a fun place with bar stools in this place called El Quim de la boqueria. The people here are with crown makeovers served great food. We tried the grilled prawns and scrambled egg with white fish---hmmmm, superb.

Barcelona's Most Famous Food Market!. La Boqueria is one of the most famous food markets in Barcelona! Definitely not to be missed! I found it refreshing to go here after seeing hundreds of clothing store everyday. The location is also very strategic, right in the center of Las Ramblas.Well.. you can find any food you want here. From candies, fruits, vegetables, everything! This place is definitely a treat for your eyes, ears and tongue! Do not forget to stop and eat at the legendary Pinotxo Bar!Blogging about food, travel, shopping and trend worldwide at www.thetwotales.com

Delectable. Fresh food and produce, cheeses and meats galore. A great place to take children and yourselves to see and smell different foods you wouldn't normally have access to.There's lots fruit, choc, and hams stalls, all that would make great gifts or just to eat! Great fruit selection to buy, but unless you have a kitchen in your hotel, there's a lot of foods you wouldn't be able to buy.Be careful who you buy from - some market traders treat tourists like they're stupid or are generally impatient. We were fortunate to find really helpful staff when we bought some hams, trying to explain to us how the animals lived, and offered tasting bites with no pressure to buy.

If you love city markets, go!. Many cities have city markets, each with their own unique charm and vibe. La Boqueria is no different. It's quite large and is filled with both usual stalls and some unusual ones. I loved the fish stalls both because of the variety and the presentation - different and creative! The fruit stalls were like impressionist paintings, and the meat stalls cried out for sampling. But nothing like seeing the stalls that cater to the "nasty bits" - tripe, brain, heart, to really remind you that you are in a place that caters to all tastes. Even if you buy nothing, your senses will be filled after wandering around for 30 minutes!

Lovely experience. That is one of the simplest but most interesting attractions in BCN.You can walk in there see fish, fresh fruits, tapes, crab and shrimps, sweets, chilli, and many others. All in one place.You will love the place and probably would want to visit it every day.Advice dont eat there, they treat tourists in a very theefy way. A lunch for two there, on a bar, costed us more than 50 Euros. The invoice doenst show any details, so you cant even negotiate.Another advice, make sure the fruits you buy are fresh and edible. Sometimes they offer immature fruits.
Fascinating. Really enjoyed this - a vast display of meat, fish, veg, fruit, little cafe/bars. Just walk up La Ramblas and on your left - we went twice and breakfasted there.

Everything you can eat in one place. When you enter the market you will see and smell all kinds of food, from seafood to meat and fruit. Some still alive... Often very crowded, be there early. Tapas bars adjacent to the market.Go there, feel it!

We love the Bogueria. What an amazing market....packed with tourists, but so worth it. The Boqueria market with its wonderful tapas/pinotex stands, beautiful produce and not to be missed fruit stands with every combination of freshly squeezed juices. My son's favorites for the day...pineapple mango and raspberry pineapple...2 cups icy cold for 3 euros. Buy the 2 euro Spanish fans sold at the entrance... they were the big hit back at home.

Fantastic food market with great atmosphere. This is one of the best markets we have ever seen - a feast for the eyes. Just wander between the different stalls and soak the atmosphere up. If you want to buy some fresh Jamon or Calamari or fresh fruit or local sweets ... this is the place. Very nice detail: all the fruit vendors also sell small cups with freshly cut mixed fruits - makes for a delicious snack alternative. One of the highlights in Barcelona to experience - and for free (if you don't count the money spent on food you buy there),

amazing. definitely one of the highlights of my time in barcelona, the colourful displays of fresh fruit,veg, meat and fish were a sight to behold and the fresh fruit smoothies and ice lollies were amazing, was a treat cutting through here en route to sonar festival each day, cant wait to go again!

amazing market. this has to be the most incredible market I have seen. Just off the Rambla, you see all those colors and smell all those smells. Lots of tourists here but tons of locals as well. Everything is arranged very neatly and in an appealing way. I was sorry we couldn't buy any of the fresh fish. Amazing selection! No wonder this is #1 of the places visited in Barcelona.
very cool. the variety of food is excellent, as a market it was clean, and the food was very tasty and i liked so much all different kind of fruits that i had the chance to try
reminds me of borough market in london. fish, meats, fruits, candy, spices, oils, seafood-its all there. try to haggle, because its not cheap. but the quality is superb

WORTH SPENDING AN ENTIRE DAY. This little market right on La Rambla offers much more than its historical environment. No wonder locals are very proud of it. Besides the great service, fresh food and the best ingredients from all over the world, it's a delightful visit (OK, the central market in Sao Paulo, Brazil is bigger and perhaps better than La Boquería, as Brazil is a natural producer of grains, vegetables and fruits). But La Boquería has a unique charm and many endorsements as high quality supplier - that's why Centonze Restaurant at Le Meridien Hotel Barcelona is the best in town - they receive fresh ingredients from La Boquería everyday :-)

Amazing fruits!. I came here for the amazing fruit and this turned out to be one of the highlights of my trip. You can get awesome fruit smoothies for €1-1.50 and a quarter of a pineapple for just €1. And lots of the fruit cups come with forks so you can wander and eat before picking up something else along the stalls. I definitely recommend a stop if you're nearby. It makes for a nice little break from all the delicious but heavy seafood and tapas you'll probably be gorging on.

Now that's what I call a market!. This market (which is located right in the middle of the city) has everything you can expect to find at a market and more. Fruits, veggies, fresh fish, famous ham........We came here for breakfast and had the fresh fruit juices and wild strawberries, it doesn't get any better. Not only can you find every different choice of meat (including famous ham), but every type of fresh fish. As a tourist you won't be buying raw meat or fish, but don't worry. This market offers small restaurants that serve up dishes made form all the fresh and scrumptious products found at this market. No one can come here and not take something home with them, be it just the memory of the wonderful atmosphere. I wish my town had a market like this.

A Riot of Colour. La Boqueria is a food market with different kiosks offering a vast selection of various foods. Fruit and vegetables are beautifully displayed with an amazing selection to choose from, some stalls offer the fruit ready to eat in little containers to buy, great if needed for a picnic also these stalls offer various fruit juice drinks too, prices may vary so check out the different stalls but they are an inexpensive refreshing drink on a hot day. Also for sale are cured meats and hams, peppers and spices, dried fruits and nuts, a stall selling every type of mushroom available, fresh fish, an amazing selection to see with the largest prawns I have ever seen, though some people may be upset to see the live lobsters and crabs on display. Not for the squeamish are the displays of offal which feature sheeps heads complete with eyes and teeth and brains in containers too !!.La Boqueria is a fabulous place to visit , it is a riot of colour and it's fascinating to see all the different foods available to purchase and a very nice shady place away from the heat.A recommended place to see when in Barcelona.Visited Oct 2011

Love it. Having read about this market before our trip - this was one of the places we wanted to visit. We were not disappointed. Initially we wandered around the whole market - just purchasing a fruit juice to keep us going - but after exploring the full length of La Rambla we returned for lunch at Bar-central. The seafood platter lunch was excellent. Appreciated the artistic way the food is displayed in the market - the people, people, people, plenty of entertainment just people watching - a wonderful atmosphere. A must if you love food and can cope with the crowds.

That crab is still moving...... Well if you want to buy fresh food where do you go? here is your answer. this is what a market is supposed to be like. Fruit, Veg, Chocolate or Xocolata as the Catalans call it, Sweets, Meat and fish that is SO fresh it is still kicking its last breath until the fishmonger in front of you slams that great big knife down on the poor unsuspecting creature. Sant Josep is extremely busy on Saturdays when i paid a visit, about halfway down La Rambla. so much so its hard to get a good look at the fair on offer. But what a place to visit. I bought some fresh cut up Melon and Coconut for 1 euro each and also some Xocolata for 5 euros. well worth a visit. but watch your pockets as pickpockets roam about here.

A Must Visit!. Even if you are not an experienced gourmet, the Mercat de la Boqueria is a "must see" attraction in Barcelona. Stroll through the endless alleys of seafood (some of it alive!), meat of various types (not recommended for the week at heart), assorted cheeses, fruits, and everything else you can imagine. Join the locals shopping for food, or just seat down and try some boquerones in vinegar sipping some wine. Fantastic place!

Great fun....... Love this market as it's similar to ones all over the world. Best bit for me was the 'Falaffel' stall on the outer edge. Freshly made in toasted pitta bread and as good if not better than downtown Jerusalem especially when you are 'Tapased Out'. This is a must visit.

LA BOQUERIA: THE MARKET, THE THEATER !. Everyone visiting Barcelona walks Ramblas – the main tourist road, the main tourist “axis” with a a lot of attraction. But I know that a lot of tourists like the Hispanic food. The Barcelona’s food is something special, something Catalunic and exquisite. Like to try? At the center of Ramblas, just near the Liceu Opera house you can easily find La Boqueria Market, the legend of the city. It’s not just a market, it’s like an colorful explosion, like the endless festival of Catalunian food and taste. In several years they will celebrate 800th anniversary, but of course through the history it was many different markets on this spot, the largest was built by 1843 and the metal roof that still exist was constructed in 1914. Local people told me that even Gaudi the Great was a frequent client here, may be looking at something here he got inspiration… It’s open from 8 AM to 8 PM, but don’t come here on Sunday, the place is closed. Could you imagine the store which offers about 30 kinds of olives? You could find it here and the name of the place is Graus Conserves. Our hotel manager told me: if you are in La Boqueria and want to taste our specials, go there in the evening, ask for jamon Serrano (special sort of ham) or maybe you can afford our good and expensive wines… I followed his advice and my impression is unforgettable. They have several bars and cafes, and I met there tourists who first got some food, some meals and then just sat there watching curious food lovers. If you are in Barcelona I highly recommend La Boqueria. See me pictures and do not forget the place of a special local pride.alftul

Its overload on the senses!. This place is great. It has so many stands offering so many varieties of foods. They are all tightly grouped together. I ate breakfast here at a little stand that had about 6 bar stools, soo good! The fresh squeezed OJ is tasty to say the least. Must go!

An Interesting Way to Spend a Morning. Before I went to Barcelona, I had done some research and decided that I wanted to see this market. Fortunately, I had some time before my flight the day I left--the only open space on the itinerary.It was interesting to be there just as the market was opening because not only did it give me an opportunity to see the market vendors setting up, it also meant that there weren't any crowds. Though there were some shoppers getting an early start on the day's supplies. I have the feeling that the place gets very crowded during the day.The selection of food is amazing and runs the gamut from fish, game and vegetables to caviar, cheese and baked goods to mushrooms, nuts and candy. The food looked very fresh and the market was very clean.There -is- one thing to be aware of, though, if you are at all squeamish about where food comes from (which I'm not). Some of the stalls sell whole game or poultry, extremities still attached. Others sell animal parts that one normally doesn't see in supermarkets, like ham with the hoof still attached or sheep's heads. Come to think of it, I don't know that I've seen that in any of the farmer's stalls at the Byward Market here...There are several restaurants/cafés/bars inside the market as well as all the food stalls, but since I didn't try any of them, I cannot comment on them. I did stop at a restaurant that was under the portico of the building between the market and the Ramblas for churros and café con leche. And the slightly surly Barcelona waiter experience.

A must see when visiting Las Ramblas. After landing in Barcelona mid-afternoon, we had our heart set in starting the 2-day sightseeing tour bus. It didn't make sense to do it that day because it would only leave us 4 hours, as the last bus service would end at 7. (There was a technical problem with Vueling Airlines, over an hour flight delay to get us from Seville to Barcelona that morning.)The person at the front desk of our hotel recommend in checking out Las Ramblas, 3 Kings Parade, and this farmer's market. After we visited Mercado de Triana in Seville, that market has nothing over this one off of Las Ramblas. This one was bigger and had more varieties.We got there near closing time and some places were already closed. We bought reduced price fruit juices that were refreshing after our walk from La Paral-lel to Las Ramblas via Carrer Nou del la Rambla. This place was brimming with a myriad of colors, with all kinds of meat, seafood (some of it were alive), sweets, fruits, and vegetables. The selection of sweets was amazing. If I were into chocolate, I would have a hard time to choose.We had hoped to come back another day to explore further, especially the places that were closed, but we never did. However, we were glad that we fit it in.

Clear your schedule for a few hours. This is quite simply the most interesting attraction in Barcelona. Such a cool vibe with people drinking wine, shopping, and enjoying life. You can find ANYTHING here:Oysters, Durian, Tempernillo, Manchego, Friends, Fruit, Families, Foodies, just to name a few. The vast array of foodie related items is dizzying. There is a guy selling everygrade of Jamon Iberico. Its like you died and went to foodie heaven.

Best Market Ever. You will experience sensory overload when you walk in. The colors, the smells and the buzz in here is amazing. Every town should have market like this. Grab a fresh juice or a piece of fruit and stroll through. You will see everything fish, meat, ham legs, eggs, chocolate, produce and places to eat. Be sure to bring smaller denominations of euros, it will keep transactions quick and easy. Oh yeah, at the entrance off Las Ramblas the meat counter on the left has small sample plates of cured meats for 2 euros, and they are really good. I think I had it three times in three days.

Awesome!. There is so much to see and eat at La Boqueria, but whatever you do, don't miss out on Pinotxo Bar. Juanito is an institution, and his welcoming grin and thumbs up is, to me, really a true welcome to Barcelona!

Quite expensive. My first time to Spain. I can't imagine a market is a sightseeing spot! In my mind, a market should be smelly and dirty. But it's completely out of my expectation. It's very clean. Besides the stalls, there are also restaurants inside. If you think stuff in market is cheap, you will be get upset. They are comparatively expensive! Go there take a look and pictures are good. If you wanna buy, I suggest you go to the Carrefour which is only a few doors next to it.

An eye opener. Every city should have a market like this a feast for all the senses. Entire stalls of eggs set out like art, over50 types of olives next to each other and fruit to put the garden of Eden to shame. Stunning!

Go every day!. We loved this market and were assured by a local chef that the food is fresh. It is clean and everything is well-displayed. We bought fresh fruit juice for 1 euro, great tacos and nachos for 3-6 euros, and wanted to try much more. It has fresh fruit, vegetables, sea food, and other meat of all sorts. There are a couple Tapas bars and some other ready to eat food.  It is closed on Sunday. If you need to use the restroom, you need a receipt of purchase from one of the vendors.

But Not Booth 652. The Boqueria is definitely a must see but becareful as some of the vendors don't like you to pick out your own produce such as the SURLY, and disinterested grouchy woman in booth 652. But there are plenty of other very kind, helpful vendors so don't miss the experience...

An Absolute Must See and Do When In Barcelona. The Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria, more commonly just referred to as La Boqueria, is something that I wish I could put on a freighter and ship back to the U.S., lock, stock and barrel. What do you want? Meat, Fish, Vegetables, Fruit, Eggs, Grains, Tea, Anything??? There are more varieties of more delicious looking, and tasting specimens of each of the foregoing, that you simply don't know what to try next. There are breads, there are hams, there are oils, there is cheese, there is some of just about every fresh food you could dream of, and then some.The displays make it look as if they were built by Hollywood, but they are real, as is every item that you are looking at. After seeing just some of the meat vendors, selling ham for up to 200 Euros a kilo, I knew I better go back and do some studying before I bought anything. The Serrano ham that we see here in the U.S., which is on par with some of the Italian prosciuttos, is the equivalent of Boar's Head over there, meaning common "ham." Real ham is Jamon Iberico, and then it gets complicated from there. The best of the hams are Jamon Iberico de Bellota, which are pigs that freely roam forests, and whose entire diet consists of acorns (bellotas) which help give the meat its particularly intense flavor. Then you have the Pata Negra, meaning "black-hooved" pigs, considered by many to be the best among the best, and the only real top flight hams come from the rear legs of the pigs, the "jamons," while the front legs are referred to as the "paletas." Then there are the slicing angles from each ham, from the front, the top, the side, etc., each priced accordingly. Finally, you get the top-named producers, whose hams are sold by name, such as "Five Js", which are DOC name controlled by the Government and EU. These hams, which are aged for 3-4 years, can run over $100/lb. U.S. or 200 Euros/kg.But there is more than just ham. You can sit down and eat a crepe being made in front of you, have a sandwich at the small cafes that line the outer walls inside the market, while you try to figure out what you want to buy.If you read any of my reviews, you will note that I am a big fan of shopping locally for food wherever I go, and I love to take picnic lunches along with me when I go exploring, so that I can find some beautiful, interesting or scenic spot to sit down, get some rest, maybe drink a beer or some wine, depending on what country I am in, usually toting along my trusty little collapsible lightweight cooler, to carry my lunch and some water for the day. Most days I would head to La Boqueria and stock up on some amazing bread, meat, cheese, smoked fish, fresh fruit, and stock my hotel fridge and plan the lunch for the day. It beats the prices that you would pay in any restaurant for the quality you are getting and you get to decide exactly where and when you want to eat. Enjoy.

If only for the fruit. This area has really fantastic fruit juices! I went here because my friend had recommended it to me and I was delighted at all the fresh fruit and fruit juices they had. There were cactus fruits, dragonfruit from Vietnam, and a whole slew of fruits which I couldn't try all of. I got a great juice every time we came in.It wasn't so busy when we came but the vendors sell fried fish - bacalau which was tasty and you can sit at the bar in the back and get fresh seafood served to you.It is definitely worth a visit if only to get your fruit fix.

variety. We went to boqueria five or six times in a week and enjoyed ourselves during all experiences. You can find all types of seafood, pork meat, vegetables and fruits. I wished there we were staying in an apartment not in a hotel only for to cook that seafood and veges. TIP: by closing time fruit boxes and fruit juices cheapen.

A great (yet crowded) market.. This is a great market in the middle of La Ramblas.The fruit and veggies presentation is beautiful, as are the numerous juice stands, with bright colours and lovely smell.The only downside to this market is the fact that it is always packed and that pickpocketing is a constant issue to notice.Still, totally worth a 30-minute visit.

Incredible!. What an amazing market! Every type of produce you can possibly imagine, from fruits and vegetables to meat, seafood, nuts, dried fruit, chocolate, breads, pastries, etc etc. A highlight is the fresh juice stands, with really interesting and delicious (and cheap) juices. Well worth spending a few hours, and if you have the privilege of an apartment in Barcelona, definitely get your produce here!

Lots of yummy food :). We came across to market on the off chance, just by Cataluyuna metro stop. There are alot of fruit stalls selling fresh fruit juices and packs of fruit. Drinks were 1 euro and fruit packs around 2.5 euros. There are also lots of stalls selling local produce and spices. Definatley worth a visit and of course spanish ham and cheese.

celebration of spanish gastronomy. Mercat de Boqueria is certainly a place to be in Barcelona! Convenient location (metro station Liceu, or you can drop by there just walking along la Rambla) and a huge selection of food made us return there over and over again. Fresh vegetables, fruits, exotic fruits, catalan chocolate, traditional almond dessert torrons in any form imaginable, fresh seafood, jamons, various types of Spanish sausages, fresh juice, tea, wines, pies - you name it! Besides, there are several open-counter cafes that serve seafood (they cook them fresh right in front of you) with reasonable prices. Once we had to wait for 10-15 minutes to get two seats but it was worth the wait. We ordered a plate of seafood assortment and it was delicious. I also like the way they sell some fruits, like pitahaya or pineapple, already cut open with a spoon, but even if the fruit you'd like to eat right now is not cut open, you can always ask a seller to cut it and give you a spoon. Actually you can just tour around the market trying everything on your way, it turned out to be so much fun! The atmosphere is really friendly and there are so many things to try.. so I suggest that you fit several visits to the market in your itinerary, you won't regret it.
It's fantastic. Big market with lots of colors and tasty tapas to try. It's amazing to taste a colorful juice and take some also colorful photos. A place to check out in the middle of La Rambla.

full of culture!!!!. what a fabulous experience although i have never been to such a busy market!!! it is so full of life and lots of characters on the stalls. the food is amazing and so full of colour. lots of stalls offering their produce and people sitting enjoying tapas / wine etc. good atmosphere and buzz about the place. it is just off las ramblas and easy to get to. it is more expensive than other markets as its right in the middle of one of barcelona's most popular streets but maybe not for the locals? worth going to even if you don't buy anything.

Fabulous. Whilst in Barcelona, my Wife and I spent two wonderful hours in what has to be one of the greatest food markets in Europe. Full of wonderful displays of fresh meat, fish and vegetables, plus great Tapas Bars. Cannot recommend this place enough. If you are in the great City of Barcelona and are a Foody, do yourself a favour and go.

Amazing abundance!. We went to this market by suggestion of a friend that lives there.... Coming from the US and being accustomed to supermarkets...this was a huge eye opener! Every fresh fruit, vegetable, fish, spices, candy... Simply amazing... The fresh fruit juice for 1€ was a needed treat in late June, the fish aisles were smelly, but they are fish, lol... Definitely worth visiting.

Absolutely Amazing!. If you are a foodie you will love this market! It's buzzing with people and shop owners, fresh fruit, meat, and seafood are overflowing the stands. The tapas bars are around every corner serving up small plates of delicious food, good spanish wine, and wonderful coffees. The cured ham is by far the best in the world. Me and my husband could've have spent the entire day in this market just browsing and eating. Only downside was traveling with a stroller which was very hard to navigate through a crowded market.

Wish we had one at home. I'd actually enjoy shopping for food if we had a market like this at home. Colourful, vibrant, wonderful seafood, sweets and veg. Beats Tesco's by a milllion miles. Even if you aren't buying go and have a look.

Loads of food. I loved this market because it's so colorful and full of people and food! We were looking for something to cook and there we found amazing fish of many kinds, meat, vegetables, fruit, spices, fresh food, cooked food.....they sell fruit box ready to eat with exotic fruit or "normal" fruit! You can even buy freshly squeezed juices, smoothies ecc... We went there for lunch, brunch, breakfast... Expensive? It depends on what you buy! ;-) as usual!

The top fresh market on the planet?. If you don't rank La Boqueria 5-stars it means that you don't like REAL food and you don't like a REAL social experience. Fresh markets are amongst the great unheralded attractions of Europe. They tell you lots about a city's soul. They are hugely colourful. They are offer 'Kodak moments' in abundance. Rick Stein raves about it, but then he is as far from a supermarket shopper as they come - a REAL produce aficionado.Bak Choy - here you are. Top grade Jamon Iberico - how much, lady? Whole horseradish - sure. Gilthead bream at prices you cannot believe. Sausages and 'salamis' in all imaginable shapes and sizes. And all set in a riot of colour, sound and movement. THIS is what Europe is REALLY about.

Even when you're not hungry, you'll enjoy !!!. Spent some time at that market today and was amazed by all the freshness and diversity of the food. I bought some fresh spices and stopped to eat at "Molt bó" (booth 920-921). Great ULTRA fresh pasta. I absolutely recommend to ask for a mix of all the different sorts of ravioli and other stuffed pasta. They'll prepare it for you ALDENTE as it must be with nice pesto, oregano and spicy oil. Eat it on site, it's part of the ambiance ! El servicio es fantasático y la gente muy amable !

Wonderful Markets. These markets offer the chance to see and try all of the local spnish and Catalan foods.The prawns in the seafood section were so fresh they were still kicking and if you wanted you could buy a few slices of the famed Iberica Black Pig Jamon to try- wonderful as you would expect at 155 Euro per Kilo.Taps of all types available and some excellent small food stalls where they would have a variety of tapas and other localo foods on offer. Right of the La Ramba so very easy to get to, near exit from Liceu Metro Station.

Awesome!. One of the best markets I've been too. So much fresh fruit, fruit juices, vegetables sea food, meat. Definitely worth the visit. Find one of the bars and sit down and order your fresh seafood and watch them cook it right in front of you. A must see in barcelona.
A real market for the city. Loved the fruits and chocolates. The variety and the atmosphere invites you deeper into the market.We had a fresh seafood meal, freshly grilled when we order. Excellent.

Freshness is the name of the game here!. A great introduction to Spanish lifestyle. Fresh catch, dine, wine and people watch!an open air market serving everything from fresh seafood/meat/fruits and veggies to local food at the onsite outdoor tapas bars like El Quim. Pull up a seat at one of the outdoor tapas bars and grab a glass of sangria because the food is fresh and made to order. I had a seafood feast!!
La Boqueria. An amazing experience. The most beautiful presentation of fresh food that you will ever see. Every display is a work of art.
Great place to start your day. A really bustling and lively Market, lots of interesting things to look at and sample, a really nice way to spend an hour.

This place it is like no other. It is a market just a market, but from like a different world, there you will see from regular seafood to goji fruit from china, Pinotxo a bar/restaurant to die for, if you are into seafood

Fantastic. Located next to Las Ramblas this market is a fantastic place to stroll through. Very busy , you will be bumped and knocked only because of the amount of shoppers doing their daily business.Sant Josep attacks all of your senses. The smells are fantastic as you pass various stall and the colours are vibrant.One of the best markets I have ever seen.
Best Place to Eat a Breakfast. This market is the best place to eat a breakfast in Barcelona. Juices, xuixos, fruits and a lot of options to start the day.

Barcelona Experience. The Boqueria is a place to shop, dine, people watch and experience Barcelona and Catalan food. You can buy a wide variety of fresh and processed food. And you will be amazed at the selection available. The chorizos and jamon at Marcos are especially good and we bought several to take home. It would be better to go to their store on the farther left side of the Boqueria instead of the one on the immediate entrance since you can do some ham tasting there.
