You can order the quantity you like and have it vacuum packed. If you get tired, there are lots of dining places all around serving the best tapas and paellas in Barcelona. We ate at El Cochinillo Loco and had a great tapas experience. The prices may be a bit high but it's all worth it for the experience.

If you love food, that's your place!. Elected to the world's best fresh market in 2008&2009 by the world trading association, this is a magnificent place to visit.It was overwhelming to see these nicely decorated wonderful fresh goods. Here you can buy everything you need for a 3 star dinner. Fresh mussels, meet, mushrooms, fish, Jamón iberico (:-)), cheese, nuts, chocolate & pralinées, fresh fruit juices, exotic vegetables & fruits, bread and many more things. It is unacceptable to leave the market without eating anything freshly cooked for you in the place. It is worth waiting, your stomach & tongue will love you for what you offered them :-)
Fresh, fresh. A wonderful place to see everyday Barcelonans shopping for the freshest seafoods, meats and veg. Good cafes too for a snack

I wish I lived near a market like this!. This place is amazing. Visually, it is a fantastic place to look around. If you love food then you will love it here. I saw so many things for sale here that I would never be able to get back home (huge selection of dried mushrooms, courgette flowers, truffles etc). If I lived near a market like this i'd probably go everyday (and put on quite a lot of weight!). Well worth a visit although it does get quite busy.

A feast for your eyes and mouth. There is so much to see and taste here - I wanted to taste something at every booth! Everything was arranged so artfully, and there were lots of colorful fruits and smoothies to visually enjoy. We walked up and down every aisle to take it all in, and I left with a tub of figs that I munched on for the rest of the afternoon as we strolled around town. Delicious!

Beautiful to the eyes, overpriced to the pocket . It's beautiful! Like a predator flower waiting for you to spend your euros there. Avoid the first shops if you want to save some money. Must do in Barcelona.
Worth a visit.. Lots of life, colors, food. Interesting displays of fishes, meat, ham/sausages, etc... A must.Also especially nice for those who are into photography.

if you are a foody. go to this market if you do nothing else in barcelona.it is incredible.the food and presentation is wonderful.kind of looks like art.several tapas places in the market so try them out.

Colourful wonder. This is a great market selling all sorts of fruits and veg to artisan and deli products. It's an amazing experience of colour with all sorts of items -From the expensive chocolate stalls (73 euros perKg) to fresh fruit juices at only a euro. There's something for all purses. There are also a couple of tapas bars located insid where you get fresh seafood. It's right in the middle of the La Ramblas so well worth a visit.

Not only a market, but a place to see too. Here you can find everything you can eat in good prices. We used to cook at home some days so we made some shopping. But even if you don't need to buy anything, this colorful place is something to see in Barcelona.

A Delicious Must See!. Make this your first stop after you check in to your hotel! Buy fruits, nuts, snacks for your visit to Barcelona. You may be slightly overwhelmed, but you will not be disappointed! Go slow and look at all the vendors.One word of caution, La Boqueria can be very crowded. Keep an eye on your belongings. I did not have a problem, but was warned by a local friend to wear my backpack in front while exploring in here.

Fresh Variety. Excellent stop at the start of our holiday to top up the fridge in our apartment with fresh goods. Most stalls spoke English sufficiently to help us and there was a rich variety of choice.
A must see. The best market I've seen till now. It has only food but its definitely enough. Come hungry and don't forget a camera.

Sensational market but misses providing an easy eating spot. What gorgeous food items; but its a shoppers paradise, not great if you want to sample the local fare, which if available looks greasy. I came home with some padron peppers and Spainish saffron, but was dying to try the massive gambas (prawns) that looked fresher and more gorgeous than anything in a restaurant. I really wish they add in some more eating spots that use the markets wares in their menus.

Terrific place of Barcelona!. Amazing place and the must to visit! Great seafood bars to have breakfast or lunch. Wonderful freshly made juices (blackberry with coco was amazing). Fantastic choice of cheese (Pecorino with truffles and the must), fruits (including very exotic ones), fish and various sea creatures, meats, pastries. The must place for Spanish culinary investigation,

A Foodi Treat. I had seen the market on a travel/food t.v. programme and as we were going to Barcelona as part of a cruise we planned to go to the market.If you are doing the “Hop on Hop off” bus around Barcelona you get off at the main stop at the top of La Ramblas.The market has an amazing array of food and colour, we had fresh juice for one euro and there was plenty of fresh fruit for one or two euros cut up ready to eat. Also amazing selection of just about everything fresh you can think of. A Foodie Treat!

WOW!!!. Our nephew & niece who visited Barcelona recently highly recommended this market and were they ever right! We've traveled the world and been to plenty of markets but this one has to be one of the best. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. It's huge and chuck full of every kind of food and beverage. We tried to go back on Sunday but discovered it was closed. Guess we'll have to go back to Barcelona!!

A feast to the eyes!. If you want to organize a big and tasty banquet, or of you just want to stimulate your 5 senses with all the colours, smells and tastes, La Boqueria in Ramblas is the place to go. Like all markets it has everything you need to have a banquet, but disposed beautifully in the stands. Take your camera, because you will want to record this experience. You can also sit in one of the Bars and have some tapas and drink cava. A Barcelona trip can be exhausting, because you can walk everywhere and here is the place to rest. Just a tip, go round noon or 13h. The spanish usually have lunch later, so you wont get the crowd.

Wow! What a great market!. The market is right in the middle of the Ramblas. You can't miss it. The fruit looks wonderful, but don't take the first stall you see. Go to the right. At the end, there's a fruit stall which is less expensive. Great fruit juices (1 euro) and cups of fresh fruit (1,50 euro). Everything tastes great. You also find all kinds of meat (head of a goat), fish. Name it, it's there. The atmosphere is really great. You have to go and see this.

Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria. An absolute must for all 'foodies' and even if you are not just go and experience the displays and astounding choice. It gets very busy so just be aware of your bags and purses as a cauntionary note.Every time we went down 'La Ramblas' where the market is situated I had to call in and have a stroll round just to see the things I may have missed. Fresh fruit pots of all kinds of fruit can be bought for 1 euro lovely to munch on as you walk around. Wonderful experience!

Be aware of fish shop cheating on your change. Market itself is very interesting with so many different kinds of vegetable, meat and fishery products, but one unfortunate experience in this market totally ruined our day in Barcelona. I bought 1 piece of fried fish ball at the fish shop called Marisc Nineta. Fish ball was 1.5 Euro and I gave the shopkeeper 20 Euro. She asked me whether I have smaller changes, but unfortunately i didn't. Then she quickly folded 5 Euro bill into small piece in order to disguise as 10 Euro bill and gave me back 8.5 Euro instead of 18.5 Euro! Realizing that i got a wrong amount, i kindly pointed out to the shopkeeper and asked her to give me 18.5 euro. She refused claiming that it was 10 Euro that i gave her. The attitude of shopkeepers was so rude, and when i tried to take a photo of the nameplate of this shop, they were shouting at me. So be careful when you shop at Marisc Nineta, especially if you look like an easy target: naive looking foreign tourist who don't speak Spanish. Barcelona is such a nice city, but one greedy person can destroy your whole experience.

The Little HAVEN in Ramblas. The Ramblas is a huge magnet for turist from any country There are more marveloius atractions on Ramblas but one of them is incredible, If you see closed the monumental gates,, rich decorated with marks &coat of arms Barcelona's , Catalunia, you can imagine that behind them are an ancient arena of castelans turnir or arena of corida.Who knows that before this gates is prepear to open a crowd of artizan arhitects of beauty . They work at magnificent scene , copious , colorfull and good smelling. The art to made such a variety and quality products is enrich with art of cooking , and decorative art. You are lost, in admiration, tempted to taste everythink, enchanted by incredible beauty around you. Don/affraid, Sant Josep adviced them to have prices for all, to rich or not so rich people. All of this made as Mercat de SantJosep de la Boqueria to be a little Haven wich enjoy everyone visit or eat in it. Congratlation! EvaChiser

Must see, must do, must experience!. We has such a great time at this venue to start the a nights off. Great people watching and an electric atmosphere, made this place so appealing. Gets crowded so go early to financial place to sit. Or just stand and be a part of it all!

The best market we have ever been to!. This outstanding market is a joy to behold. The food is magnificently displayed, tastes wonderful, there is a huge variety of all types of delicacies. It is truly a paradise for people who enjoy the freshest of food presented in the best way possible. There are plenty of pre-cooked options,as well as wonderful juices, chocolates, macaroons...you name it---it is there!

Wonderful experience. This place is amazing. Colorful, people are friendly, it smells good, a lot of food to taste, etc.
We had lunch there and was simply great.

All I can say is, "Incredible". This is probably THE best market I have ever visited,and I have been to many all over Europe and Latin America, but La Boqueria is in a class of it's own. The quality, variety and quantity of products sold is amazing. This is truly a foodie's paradise. My husband and I will be coming back to Barcelona in about a week we will be staying in a small apartment with a kitchen, I am already dreaming of going back and buying some of the wonderful seafood they sell so we can prepare it at the apartment. There are also places where you can eat at the market, we visited around noon and after having hearty breakfast around 10 a.m., it was too early for lunch. I cannot say enough good things about the market, you must go and expereriece it.

A must for any foodies.. The Boqueria Market is a joy for anyone who has a passion for food. What a thrill too see the beautiful displays of the vast assortments of fresh fruits, vegetables, meats, seafood, cheeses, chocolates and more. This vibrant market is a must see while visiting Barcelona. We started each day here with a fresh fruit drink and snacked away on local treats including local ham yummy cod fritters. A feast for all!

A true Market Vibe. A visit to the Boqueria market has to be included in a visit to Barcelona. To see, experience and enjoy the atmosphere of the market was brilliant. The different areas for seafood, meats, sweets, fruit, ham all provided an understanding to the culture of Barcelona. A busy place off the rambla worth visiting.

stunning market, well worth the visit.. This market is situated just off the Rambla. Its stunning inside with a huge variety of foods - meats, cheeses, fruits, vegetables and chocolate. There is such an enormous range to choose from and relatively well priced. If you're in an apartment and cooking whilst you're in barcelona this would be a great place to get your foods.You can also sit and eat freshly prepared food at various stalls alhough these tended to be more expensive (fair enough for limited space there is). Even if you're not buying, just go and have a walk around - its full of great sights and smells and well worth a walk in.

Entertaining and fun. Every big European market is a feast for the eyes and nose, and this is no exception. Not exotic like Asian markets, but still a colorful, happening place with seemingly every type of produce, cheese, meat, fish, and flowers available in the northeast of Spain, plus cheerful welcoming vendors. And like all great markets, plenty of presentation points.I'll bet it is particularly fun in the early hours as the vendors are setting up, as mentioned in some other reviews.

Barcelona: tradition, culture, people. If you want to learn about idiosyncrasy in their local people: visit a local market. la boqueria is a place with food, tapas, wine, fresh fruits, turron and much more!! a must see while in barcelona and It is very close to La Rambla

Must visit if like food.. Yes, it is full of tourists but I am a tourist so no problem there. Paradise for Jamon lovers, after some grueling effort, i found 50grams is my perfect single portion, there are so many to try that isn't available in the states and much cheaper. I gravitate towards the smaller owner operated stalls, found Mateo's to be a great one, tried both of their Jamon bellotas, Salamanca and 5j both incredible(just in my head but 5j taste better in barcelona than in US). Saw many people at the popular tapas bar in the front of the market, so I squeeze in too, but killed it for me when i order a hot chocolate and got a store bought glass bottle that he heated up with the milk steamer....a tiny dish of salty callos(tripe) was 6euros. The next visit, I headed inside to a small cafe counter in the middle of the market, Cafe Sant Josep, the people running it are very charming have been working there for 30-40 years, while i was there I only saw elderly regulars stop by for coffee and snack. Great coffee and wonderful callos for about half the price of the stall in the front and tastier too! It was much more enjoyable at Cafe Sant Josef after that another visit to Mateo's.

Worth a look. I was there for a purpose in early October. Need to remember this was one of the most important makets in Barcelona. It's getiing a bit 'Touristy' now with all the sweets and drinks 'ready to go' but still amazing to most northern Europeans. We stopped eating the stuff they sell in the Boqueria 50 years ago !! If you want a lower cost and maybe more genuine market they are still there but a bit further out. My only gripe was the the bars behind the market are off limits and are being re-developed. Such a shame but hey ho thats progress

An amazing experience. This market has been operating since the 1200's- it is a must see in Barcelona! We went there each day we were in Barcelona -We stayed less than a 100 steps from the entrance- the best time to go is in the morning around 8:30-9:00 to see all the vendors set up, to see all the seafood come in and the fresh fruit being prepared for display. The colors are fabulous. The sights and sounds a treat. It is a experience for all the senses!
Beautiful and fresh foods!. Delicious foods, all displayed in a cravefull surrounding! Defenately a must! Try the fresh fruits and the special chocolates:)
The famous and incredible!. I could spend every morning here. And did while we were in Barcelona. I dream of a market like this back home. Amazing morsels for your eyes, nose and tongue. Swooonnn.

Food Wonderland. This was my husband's favorite place in Barcelona! We loved this outdoor food market. Just the sight of the variety of fruit, fish, meat and vegetables! Everything looks so much more colorful than any other market I can think of. The traders were friendly and gave lots of samples. I was fascinated by the candy stalls--I wish I could have tried it all. We mostly stuck to the fresh fruit juices, which I thought were a good value at one euro. So many varieties. We tried 5 different combinations, and they were all delicious (especially the bubble gum pink pitahaya, which I think may be starfruit?) Do not miss this place--it's right on the ramblas and should be called an attraction in itself.

Wish we had this back home!. Amazzzzing to see! Locals and tourists made this a very busy place to be.... If you overlook the begging at the entrance and have a good look around before you make your purchases ..... A fantastic opportunity to see local produce being sold the way it should!

The only disappointing part of our trip. We spent 6 fantastic days in Barcelona, what a beautiful easy going city, but the central market was probably our biggest disappointment. We don't have a problem with crowded markets, but we just found it to be too catered for tourists with its 1 euro fruit juice stalls which there are loads of. There were a few what we considered to be proper meat and vegetable stalls, but when we stopped to look at the tripe stall as our 7 year old wanted to know what it was, where it came from etc... the old guy threw his toys out the pram and signalled for us to get away from the stall, thankfully the lady at the pig stall was much more pleasant. There are a number of wine shops, butchers and dried fruit & nuts shops around the Ravel area which are far more interesting, friendlier and much much cheaper.

Cool place!. The best place for buying Jamon, fruits, cheese and other tasty things. Everything will be packed for you to take to your country. There are also small cafes and you just show what you want and they cook it for you - meat or seafood. There are also fresh juices for 1 euro! I bought there Jamon, sobrasada and sausages, everything was wrapped and i just put in in my travel bag and took home to Moscow. Everything was fresh anf of high quality.

Must see. A friend of mine living in Barcelona told me that I must go there. And she was right, it was 10 minutes walk from the hotel. A very nice and clean place, very organized, with sellers not being pushy and not trespassing or competing with their neighbours. You can find very nice snacks for 2 euros or more and fresh juices..
The best I have seen. The quality and the quantity of the fresh fish, meat and produce was phenomenal. The Seattle Pike Market seems small and touristy in comparison.
So much food, so little time. Just go, this place is great if you are a food lover. Wonderful seafood platter for lunch one day and loads of little snacks available from a euro.

A must. If you are visiting Barcelona and like food, this is a must see place. Fresh fish, meat and vegetables, ham, sausages, cheese.... everything including a few very buzzy and exciting tapas bars serving stunning and fresh food

This should be grouped as an attration too.. When you walk down the Rampla, dont miss the oppotunity to visit the market. The way the food is arranged is comparable to art in some of the best shops. Buy a fresh fruit drink or some nice chokolates -there is something for every taste. It is really a great experience.

A must see in Ciutat Vella!. The Market is something to see for all the vibrant colors and wonderful tastes. Granted, prices can be a little steep - ask before. Ice cold smoothies are a hit. You can have breakfast there as well. Stalls are not quite ready before 9/9:30. Another must in in Ciutat Vella.

great market to visit when walking through las rambla. we just stumbled across this market when we were walking on las rambla, nice market where they have lots of fruits and other assortments that you find in a market. its pretty big so make sure you pass the first set of stalls and then you'll find it gets a bit cheaper than the prices from first sets of stalls.certainly if you are in the area, come visit the market to check it out and get some nice snacks/fruits and foods. one of the resturants on the tripadvisor app was actually there in the market so we went there to eat (its on my reviews list but a lil exy).Overall glad we stumbled upon this place by accident to check it out :)

A must see if you like food!. This place is the crown jewel of Barcelona's outdoor activities. The market brings together all cultures but most of all the Spanish food and culture. There are tons of exotic fruits, which I discovered for the first time in my life. Really amazing types of jamon, sea food of all kinds and all you can drink natural juices. There is a splendor of colors and smells. Go, it's a must see if you are in Barcelona. Enjoy yourself if you're a foodie!
My favorite place in Barcelona. Colors, smells, FOOD! You have to go there. Be hungry and try food from the shops inside (avoid the restaurants - prefer the stalls).
Nice market at Las Ramblas. Nice off-the-beat tour to the traditional spanish fish, meat, fruit, everything food market close to Las Ramblas. Enjoyable, nice atmosphere, crowded, but not overcrowded.

Very cool place in Barcelona. I was absolutely impressed with this place. The fruit stands were so colorful and each one made it's version of smoothie. I wanted to try everything. The other impressive area is the fish area, so many varieties and all fresh. I did not sit down and eat, but it looked like many locals do this. I would recommend a brief stop by here to soak it all in.

Noisy, colourful, crowded - but great food.. Great to wander around, amazing selection of food.Great fruit and veg stalls, and also loved the breads and cheeses. The fish and meat are also superb. Squid, shellfish, sheeps head and cow feet - can be an ordeal for vegetarians but the three in my party loved the place.Pick up lunch to eat as you walk through (squid on a stick maybe) or stop at one of the micro-tapas bars.We were after saffron and it paid to shop around, we saved three euros on a 5g box.

Must do!. I began my day in La Boqueria: Barcelona's famous market. As soon as I entered the market I was overcome with colors, sights, and choices. The first area of vendors mainly sold vibrantly colored dried fruits by the weight, including things like dried kiwi, nuts, candied nuts, and candy. And oh my god this candy! There was gummy candy, 20 different types of licorice, and chocolate. Not surprisingly, I blew my money on the chocolate, which was well worth it. I had a porcupine shaped chocolate coated in colorful sprinkles, a thin layer of milk chocolate, a thick layer of white chocolate, and filled with a milk chocolate and nougat center. I also had a coconut cream covered in coconut and filled with white chocolate and coconut inside...read more at http://godsavethefood.blogspot.com/2011/11/barcelona-mi-nueva-favorita-ciudad.html

Lovely market. I don't think you can beat a good market, and this is one of the best. There are lots of stands selling fruit from beautiful displays, plus meat and fish sellers stands selling a variety of interesting products. It costs nothing to look around, but if you're feeling adventurous make a purchase! It is a bit cramped, and like on La Rambla, watch out for pickpockets.

small jump in colors and smells. I waited actually larger sizes, but I was not disappointed. The market can be found right on the main street of Rambla smoothly. It is also fantastic as the Arab markets, but it is clean and you will not bother anyone. Large and colorful assortment of all sorts of things. Pleasant stalls with delicious food. Also, small cafes. Prices are obviously higher, but bearable. Very good tip on a little trip.

Very colorful, unique but touristy and crowded. If you visit Las Ramblas, you must visit ls Boqueria. You will seen plenty of neatly arranged fresh fruits, cut fruits, fruits juice, candies, nuts and raw seafood, meat etc. It is very crowded at the entrance. Once you walk toward the back, you will see locals shop for their food. I don't know another real market as tailored and welcome to tourists.I will say watch pickpockets, try a few items and spend no more an hour here.

Jump in - Jump out. Every one told me that it is a must place to visit.Well, it is not that must.The marcet was smaller then I accpected, the food isn't cheap.Thogh if you are already in, buy yourself some meat and fruits, enjoy watching the seafood shops and get out,So as I said, jump in, jump out.

A Must for Foodies. It's a foodies paradise! A complete farmer's/fishermens market containing the freshest and best of everything the lands of Catalonia and seas of the Mediterranean can provide. Best if all, it keeps with its food market intent, unlike the markets of Rome or those of the United States that seem to be turning into half flea market, souvenir, rag and trinket shops. The eyes of the fish glisten with freshness, so fresh I even saw a couple of them move. Most of the vegetables are local as are the cheeses and many of the meats. I had no trouble not only locating fresh seafood, but also being the adventurous cook that I am; I was delighted with the availability of fresh suckling pig and rabbit as well. Keep in mind, this isn't Spain, it's Catalonia as many of the vendors are quick to point out.
Colorful. Busy, colorful place. A great place to get a taste of the local foods. Probably not the best value for many, but an interesting experience makes up for it.
A must visit place. We returned every day during our trip. Vibrant colors. Fruits, juices, chocolates, vegs, fish & seafood, french baguettes, chorizzos, fresh food etc. Like heaven.:)

Gorgeous Market with Lots of Yummy Stuff!. If you are ever in Barcelona you must go to the Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria. Colorful and vibrant, packed with people and vendors. A foodies delight...fresh and colorful produce, lots of meats, cheeses, food stands, pastries, cakes, candies...the simple and the exotic...there is so much to see, smell, and taste. Great prices...gourmet delights....grab and go meals or sit down at crowded counters at food stands.

Heaven. We wandered around this market for almost 2 hours. We loved the displays and eating the wares. The liquer filled chocolate was amazing. So was the fresh fruit juice. Be sure to make your way to this market at least once during your time in Barcelona.

Touristy but necessary. Wandering amongst the other stalls you'll find all kinds of fruit juices on ice, local fruit, veg, spices and nuts piled high in colourful pyramids, garlic ropes and chilies hanging from the ceiling, many types of eggs...when space is scarce sometimes buckets and boxes are just piled in the aisles. Spanish olives and olive oil of almost every variety are also readily available (although the Olive store in El Born has a better selection of oil) and vac-sealed for travel. We brought several of these home. Then there's jamón - Spanish cured ham that I cannot get enough of, bacalao - the local variation of salt cod, piles of slippery fresh fish and seafood, all kinds of cheese, foie gras, produce, etc. There are also many, many tourists. It's a wonder that the market survives, but many vendors either ship outside of the market or have a chain or shops, or prepare snacks for the visitors, so I'm sure that helps. We visited several other markets in Barcelona and found them to be more pleasant to shop in, but they lack the diversity and splendour of the Boqueria.

Wonderful place for lunch. We visited twice on our before/after cruise stays in Barcelona. What a culinary surprise!! The amount of fresh food (breads, meats, vegetables, fruits, juices, fish) is amazing. Most vendors sell foods to eat on the spot. We ate here twice for lunch. Both times my husband had fresh sushi that the vendor was cutting up on the spot. The pieces of sashimi were very large and extremely fresh and very well priced for the amount (7EU). My husband paid with 10EU and told the vendor to keep the change since he couldn't believe the high quality of the fish and this meal couldn't have been touched in NYC for under $25-$40...he thought 10EU was a steal!! I had a fresh skewer of Iberian ham for 1EU and it was amazing!!! The Catalans really take their Iberian ham serious!!! The flavor proves it!! Another day i had a fresh crepe made with serrano ham, mushrooms, carmelized onions, spinach and cheese. It was very large and definitely fresh (the vendor made it to order in front of me) and a value at $7.50EU. The fresh juices are plentiful and quite exoctic combinations. I would highly suggest stopping here early in the morning to look around and have and early lunch...later in the day is packed and stuffy!!!

A very busy market.. We went here a bit late in the evening . There were still some stalls open selling there produce , however most of the stalls had closed. It is a very large market in the heart of the Las Ramblas area/strip. There are many stalls and i think this is the oldest and largets fresh produce market in Barcelona. There are also stalls and a Tapas Bar(pinxto bar) which sell food to eat such as tapas , and fresh seafood and fresh squeezed juices etc etc. When in Barcelona , this place definately must be visited.

Market at the heart of the city. It is really crowded and relatively big. You see locals shopping as well. Mainly for tourists there are take away fruits and fast food. I have never seen so much varieties of fresh squeezed fruit juices and sliced fruits. Especially fruit juices help in hot weather to refresh you.

A culinary delight. Wow! This was by far the best market we saw on our recent trip to Spain and France. Fresh fruits, vegetables, meat, seafood, spices. A culinary must for any visit to the city. Sit at one of the bars and have them whip you up a fresh omelette, or seafood lunch, have a cortado (espresso with a bit of milk) at Pinxto , buy some fresh fruit and wander.

Avoid after 10:30 am. This is a wonderful market, full of vendors selling spices, nuts, fruits, vegetables, sweets, fish, and meats. It's lively and the vendors are friendly. However, I'd avoid going after 10:30 during summer as it is literally suffocating with bodies and enough to make you dizzy.

Super colourful market, great place to grab a bit to eat.. I loved walking around this market. Its all touristy and fruit at the start, with fish and meat for the locals towards the back. Its very colourful and busy.

A Beautiful Market. I enjoyed seeing this market because the fruits were so artistically arranged. There was a very large variety of products in this market. It was really a joy to see it. This is undoubtedly one of the best markets in Spain.

Hang out and try things. This market is a culinary heaven. It is overwhelming how many shops are under one roof and how many people can be crammed into one place. Once you get acclimated to the crowds, take your time to try things. Fresh squeezed fruits juices can be found two for 2 Euros along with fresh cut fruits. Try the famous Iberico jamons and buy some to eat later. They sell wines, sandwiches, candies, spices, etc. Sit at the counter of the many restaurants and just point to what you want. It's fun and a great way to experience Barcelona.
Must do in Barcelona. Fresh market where you can find pretty much anything... Eat straight from the vendors or take some home for later. Either way, it's delicious

Excelent Market. Excelent market ... colorfull ..the variety is exceptional Try the fresh juice at the entrance right in the midlle there is a guy doing crepes - amazing The quality of fruit and vegetables is amazing buy some - try the taste there is a plaza on the right side outside the market with a terrace where you can enjoy delicious tapas in the market close to end on the right side there is a food bar with exceptional food you can choose your piece of meat , fish or whatever they have on display , price is right Do not miss the market I was going almost every day

What an incredible place. A Must see in Barcelona! Wow I wish every city had a market like this, just incredible. We rented an apartment for the week and saved a tonne of money buying fresh food here and not spending at restaurants for every meal.

Food market just off La Ramblas. We found this market by accident whilst going through the back of a restaurant, looking for toilets. This food market is colourful with wonderful smells. Do like the locals, east small tapas from the stalls while drinking a glass of wine or Cava (Spanish champagne). All the vintners and bodegas around the market sell wine by the glass which is perfect. The market is set in a small square, surrounded on all sides by columns, giving it the appearance of a smaller Covent Garden.A marvellous find and one which we will go back to on our next visit.

Fascinating to see ... and clean bathrooms too!. Le Boqueria is a bustling place, jammed to the gills with fruit, vegetable, bread, cheese, meat, and fish vendors. The colors are amazing to see. The place is alive. And, unlike some of the other fruit/vegetable vendors around town, their food actually looks fresh and well cared for, rather than dried, over ripe, or neglected.If you love to buy fish that has only been out of the ocean for a few hours, this is the place to go.There are also several sit down or bar eateries in the market where, presumably, they use the fresh ingredients that are all around them.So, definitely a must see attraction ... and surprisingly clean washrooms downstairs at the back of the market. They have fulltime staff maintaining them. We travel with three small kids, so these things are important! :-). If you buy something or eat in the market, the washroom is free. Otherwise, it's one euro. So that's the deal on the washroom for all you folks that travel with small kids that only give you 3 minutes notice that they're about to pee their pants!

Fascinating - the food stalls were underwhelming. The only reason this isn't getting 5 stars is because the food that I ate from one of the vendors in the back was pretty underwhelming - and expensive. But wandering the market itself is so fascinating and the vendors have beautiful arrangements - tons of fresh fruit, candy stands, meat, seafood... a wonderful market that I would shop at frequently if I lived in Barcelona. It's fringes, especially the restaurants, seemed to cater to tourists and provided lower value for what you spend, but all in all it's definitely worth detouring off Las Ramblas to check out the Mercat.

One Of The Best Markets In Europe. If you are in Barcelona- even if only for a day -you must visit Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria. Get a fresh juice (it comes in every flavor imaginable), wander around gawking at the endless array of live sea creatures and gorgeous veggies and stop to have a seafood plate and a beer at the counter. Or pick up some mouth-watering meats and cheeses, some fruits, nuts and cava-marinated olives and a good loaf of bread, and enjoy a feast at the top of the Park Güell as the sun starts to set over the city.A Tip for Smart Shopping: Browse around before you choose which stall to buy your meats, cheeses and olives/ canned goods at. Stalls closest to the entrance often ensnare tourists, but these vendors are usually pricier.

Best market ever. If in Barcelona, this is a must see. It's an incredible market selling just about every kind of food you can imagine. The fish area is amazing, fresh hunks of just caught fish everywhere. Huge head on shrimps, and langostines and lobsters. There are several produce stands whose items look beautiful. And if you like ham and charcuterie and cheese, there are no less that 15 places selling all of it, many slicing ham legs right in front of you. This place is a spectacle of sights and sounds and smells and tastes! There are also a few tapas places you can sit at and have some bites, along with several stores selling small bites of their wares. Don't miss this gem!

Highlight of the holiday. Another highlight of the holiday where we went 3 times in 6 days.Amazing to see all the different foods in one area and if you get a chance to sit down and eat this food, i recommend Bar Boucheria. The food is Barcelona at its best. Superb food at excellent prices, been there 3 times and for my wife and i we must of spent on average 40 Euros for both of us and we ate loads (6-7 dishes). I recommend going to there around early afternoon so the fish is still available to eat because come 3-4pm the fish is near enough gone and restricted to eat whatever is available.

You must visit the Boqeria!. The market was the highlight of the trip for me and the best market I have ever been to (which is quite a few!). The atmosphere is busy and a little hectic but that just adds to the enjoyment. As you enter, you are welcomed by the stalls which cater more for tourist needs with things like fruit smoothies (delicious) and the famous Iberico ham. These are great but I would really recommend venturing a little further in and seeing the stalls which cater more towards the locals. The fish circle in the centre of market is amazing. On one morning there was a full tuna (they are pretty big!) being expertly dressed and the following day it was a swordfish. If you want to get the best from the market, try to get there early when the produce is at its best or in the late afternoon when it is all about the tapas and pinxtos.This is the best free entertainment in Barcelona!

The Busiest Bustling Market I have seen.. It is an assault on the senses. Sounds, smells, sights. truly extraordinary. Filled with tourists when I was there. Would have liked to have been there in the morning early. Fruit, veg, bread, wine, cheese and lots of meat and fish. Also sweets and delicacies. As a vegetarian I was still taken by the colours of the market it some parts not by the smell of the meat and fish though. The smells of the herbs and spices truly uplifting.
Colorful. Such a colorful market with fruits and vegtables and all types of sea food.....

Eat Everything. Above everything else this is a market. Locals buy meat, fish, fruit and veg to make their dinner. Marketes exist all over the world but not all of them are filled with fine Iberico Ham and fish so fresh it doesn't have a smell.If you like the noise and manic fell of a working market I recommend you spend an hour or so here and buy some food! You can buy small open packets of ham (which is gorgeous), fruit, drinks and an endless list of edible treats. As much fun as this is, don't fill yourself as you MUST eat at one of the tapas bars inside the market before you leave.I counted 4 tapas bars and all are given brilliant reviews. you can't go wrong and as most food is on display you can politely point at anything you like the look of (if your Spanish is as bad as mine).Loud, Busy, Exciting.

Interesting, good, cool and shady break. Definitely worth a visit, particularly if you are looking for a variety of jamon and cheese. It's also a good stop before heading out for the day, since they sell alot of prepared fruits and juices. It can be a busy place, though. Also, unless you are planning to cook on your own, there's not much more to do here than look. But, worth a stop.

Great experience. Definitely go here, could easily spend a couple of hours going up and down the aisles and trying everything! loved the little bars serving up fresh seafood, had it not been for the waiting lists we would have ate at one of them - put your name down as soon as you get there and go hungry. amazing fresh fruit juices sold everywhere - we rushed to go there in our last hour in barcelona just for one more juice.

Bustling Fun. Fresh flowers, fresh food fresh everything lovely people and an even lovelier treat. We bought some fresh fruit smoothies at the entrance and some freshly cut chesse and ham inside scrummeeee

Lots of Fun. If you visit Barcelona you must see the outdoor market (actually covered, but technically outdoors.) Lots of fresh juices and all sorts of other food abound. It is one of those shopping experiences not found in the united states. It's a place to stroll around, and maybe enjoy a seafood lunch at one of the counters. It is right off The Ramblas, another wonderful place to stroll around.

Watch out for the heads!. This market puts markets in my county to shame, everything looked so appealing, not fancy dressing but pure functionality, all fresh ingredients for those fresh cooked meals. It gets packed at the main entrance, we snuck in via the side entrances and moved more freely for it. Tapas bars to the rear full of the best Catalan food. Get there early or end up seeing the left over fish and animal heads as the fresh meats are sold out. Get a really fresh iced fruit drink off of a number of stands and recharge yourself.

Simply amazing. This is the king of produce, meat and cheese markets. We loved wandering this market -- and were amazed at all the choices available. I'd love to have a place like this to do my food shopping in.

This must be the first thing you see in Barca. While we had the benefit of staying a couple blocks away, we visited this amazing market four times during our short stay. We had breakfast here both mornings in town (fresh fruit juices 2 for 2 Euros and some ham and cheese sandwiches) for a price that really couldn't be beat. I think I took my favorite photos here, as well. Be sure to work your way to the stalls to the middle and back -- those on the periphery get lots of tourists - to have a better sense of shopping like a local.
Disappointed.. We are not what you would call 'foodies' but we didn't enjoy our visit to the market. We found it dirty and way too busy.

A 'must-go' destination at Barcelona. This market is along the famous La Rambla shopping street and is always spilling with tourists. However it is not a tourist trap. Besides the fresh fruits and vegetables, there are astesan chocolates and nougats on sale at the market at reasonable prices which you will not be able to get anywhere else in Barcelona. Don't forget to go early if you wish to try out the freshest of seafood cooked on the spot upon order. We had lunch twice at the Universal Kiosk, a large stall at one corner of the market. You will not miss it as the stall is crowded at all hours. Go to the guy manning the stall and he'll take down your name. Wait patiently for your name to be called and he'll assign a seat at the counter facing heaps of seafood and salad. Don't forget to try the razor clams, grilled shrimps, mixed mushrooms and prawn salad. It is guaranteed to satisfy!

Colourful fresh fruit and vegetables. A colourful and busy food market just of the Ramblas. The tour guide had told us to check it out and you can try some samples. Its a kind of colourful fresh fruit & veg market you tend not to see in the UK these days, the layouts of the stalls are very well done. Go further in and you have fish and meat. If you thirsty you can get some juices.

special marketplace. This is one you have to visit while you are in Barcelona. Its easy to find, side street of the Ramblas and its bigger than you think when you first enter the square. The place is covered so no problem when it rains. You can find all kind of fruits, meat, vegetables, herbs,etc.. here. Smell the flavours, enjoy the taste...And few small restaurants at the sides ...or enjoy a glass of wine and see the atmosphere from a different point of view. A must see ..

Great selection but go early to avoid the crowds. Wonderful food market off Las Ramblas. It has everything -- fruits and vegetables, meats, fish, spices. Some stalls have been in the same family for generations. Go early, say 10:00-12:00, but not too early or only about half the stalls will be open. By mid-afternoon the place will be so crowded you can barely move. Also has cafes and restaurants where you can have breakfast or lunch. Definitely worth a visit.

Spectacular Market. This is one of the top things to do in Barcelona. The market has an almost endless variety of stalls, featuring fruit, produce, seafood, cheeses, spices, and on and on. There's also stalls that prepare food. I had an excellent pasta primavera for lunch one day, and a really good slice of pizza at a different stall the next day. There's also a few tapas bars, regular bars and wine stores within the market. You could easily spend hours there.A couple of tips: It's popular with both locals and tourists, so be prepared for crowds. We were staying at Hotel Bagues a block away, so if it was too crowded we'd just come back later. Another tip is to avoid the restaurants that have tables around the perimeter of the market. These are just the back entrance to restaurants that front onto La Rambla. So you get La Rambla quality (low) and prices (high). Stick to places within the market itself; there's an enormous amount of choices there.

Amazing and interesting. One of the best things to visit in Ramblas area. I have a real passion for food, and this place sells everything... From fresh fish, meat to lamb heads and ostrich eggs! Great places to eat in there and a real treat. Just wish I had something like this near me!! Yes it's touristy and busy, but a must see.

Vegetable and Fruit Galore. I wish I lived in Barcelona so I could visit this market everyday! There are so many fresh vegetables and fruits. Lots of beautiful colors! In addition, you can get your meats, seafood, candies, and majority of your grocery shopping done here. If you are hungry, you can stop by several shops for food. I miss this place!
Amazing smoothies!. Loved the atmopshere of this place. Great fresh fruit juices for only a euro!

wonderful place to start out the day. I always go to the market early in the morning, it is less crowded and the food is really fresh. My first stop is a fruit stand located on the last isle on the right side, they have fresh fruit and delicious juices, the perfect treat to start out the day. The juices are 1€, get fresh fruit and not the stuff in a cup, they will cut it open for you and give you a fork or spoon to eat it. After that I always go for a sandwich with jamón ibérico, there is a few good places on the left side after the fish stands, they are around 2€ and you can pick your ham.If you go in the early afternoon or for lunch I would recommend trying the paella, the fish is fresh and they prepare the dish in front of you, so much cheaper than in most of the restaurants and the atmosphere is just great.

Great seafood. We had a brief look round the market through curiosity as we had read various reviews as well as a good write up in the guide book we had. Fantastic array of fresh fruit and veg, meat and seafood. We had no real need to buy anything as we were hotel based but enjoyed the experience nonetheless.We stopped at one of the seafood stalls for a bite to eat (from memory it was called Bar Central, situated opposite the entrance to the market office). We had to wait around 10 mins for seats but it wasn't a problem as we got to have a good look at the food on offer. We had the most delicious seafood platter with a plate of grilled veg and a couple of beers to wash it all down. Tasty food and a great experience overall.We also grabbed one of the fruit smoothies on our way round which were lovely for only 1euro.Good place to grab supplies for a picnic.

A must for foodies!. La Bouqueria Market, located in the heart of Barcelona (at the top of La Rambla) is an absolute joy on the senses! Fresh fruit and fish ensure the little cooked food stalls inside (and the 2 restaurants just outside the back door of the market) are filled with locals at lunch time, grabbing a variety of great value lunches for under 10 euros.Well worth a visit, but do go early, as it closes for siesta and re-opens for afternoon and evening trade. The best place to find on day 1, if renting an apartment in Barcelona. My best buy: A string of bright red dried chilli peppers, at 6 euros, which cheers up my kitchen and reminds me of sunnier climes when I'm home.

A FEAST FOR THE SENSES!!!. Entering the market, it quickly became apparent to me why this is one of the top things to do in Barcelona. Shopping, Eating, Drinking and seeing the colorful arrays of fruits and vegetables and the unique displays of different kinds of hams hanging and all ready to be captured by my camera lens. We had most of our meals here from breakfast to early dinner, we first tried "El Quim" this is on the left side of the market when you enter, we had prawns, razor clams and sweet peppers so yummy! Then we had breakfast at Pinotxo bar they have great coffee and pastries and loved the garbanzo dish w bread. They are closed on Sundays so I'm glad we went and ate the first two days.Its very crowded so watch your belongings while you take pictures. It's definitely one of my favorite places in Barcelona.
The Best in the World. A quite extraordinary experience. The best fish in the world. And the best picture opportunities for food camera work.

Got to see. Went for a walkaround, this is a proper market, stalls oveflowing with fruit, veg, fish,meat etc where the locals buy, also great looking food stalls with locals and tourists sitting, a must see.

Showcase Barcelona Market. This market was beautifully fresh - fresh meats, fish, fruits, cheeses, food. It was a great place to wander thru and absorb the vibrancy of Barcelona and its lifestyle. It was also a great place for a drink (nonalcoholic), snack or lunch. I never saw so many types and combinations of fresh fruit juices chilled on ice. I enjoyed several. There were also food counters there for fresh fish or salads and other food. Once again the key to this was fresh. You most likely won't be sitting to eat or snack, but you can feast your eyes on the variety and really enjoy it. After eating some heavy meals and gelatto, the choices and light variety was perfect. Don't miss it.

Nu?. It has become a "must see." OK, go and brave the crowds and you'll see nice fruit and vegetables and fish and shellfish and... in a nice array of of colors and shapes. In other words, you'll see what you see in any market, what I see at least once a week in Fairway in NYC, but more cramped due to the throngs of tourists that are there to gawk but not to purchase anything other than, sometimes, the fruit juices (they are very good, indeed) or the containers with cut fruit (first rate) to eat in the Ramblas. And both you can buy in many other places that are not the hassle and waste of time that Boqueria has become over time. I think that you still should go and walk past all the stalls, if the hordes don't trample over you in the attempt, and exit at the other end and discover a beautiful courtyard with interesting architecture and restaurants.
One of the best markets I have seen anywhere. I love fresh food- the way it looks and smells (and yes, tastes). This market is a true experience for the senses.

Have never seen such a wide range of foods in one area. Loved the fruit stands, the candy stands. Some of the meat displays were a little gruesome and the fish smell in some areas of the market could be a little overwhelming-but it was a fun atmosphere and thoroughly enjoyed sampling food from some of the vendors.

AMAZING!. An absolute must!!! The market is unlike any other I've been too... all the fruit makes the market so bright and vibrant and there is seafood, meat and anything you can imagine all around.There are little tapa places inside which I highly reccomend. You can also stop by El Celler, right in the market, and drink wine!

Kingdom of plenty!. La Boqueria is a place you just can't miss it. I came across by chance and I could't believe my eyes how beautiful it is... Plenty of fruits from all parts of the world painstakingly sorted and packed in all sorts of combinations. And you can take it all! There's no just fruits there, but also vegetables, fish and meat but everything is just perfect. You would like to taste everything you see..but it's hard because you can't it is such a large selection and you have just to take photos and at the same time to choose at least something. To go without some nuts, chocolates, fruits - that would be a crime!
Amazing colors. I loved this place.The colors,the fruits and the chocolates are simply a feast for the eyes.

Must visit for the sights and smell.. lovely place to walk around selling fruits, vegetables, meat, nuts... the juices inside the market cost less than the ones outside. i would say it's a great place to visit for fresh fruits. things like nuts and nougats are a little more costly here.i stayed near the market so it's almost a daily walk for me.some pictures in this link.http://nikikoh.xanga.com/762276800/espa%c3%b1ol-de-invierno---la-boqueria/
Great Food Market. The largest food market in Spain. Wonderful photos opportunities of beautiful food. Artistic displays of all types of food.

An experience - you don't need to buy anything.. Just off Las Ramblas - once you're in, you can see all the fruit, chorizo and veg you could want! The fruit pots are only around 1.50 euros and the smoothies are around 1 euro. There is so much variety and choice, that you don't know what to buy! It's all displayed beautifully and very tempting. A lot of people were there simply taking photos. I bought a good few chorizos etc and it was decent value. It's open every day except Sunday.
My favorite place, very artistically and naturally beautiful. Full of beautiful color, natural, delicious and healthy food, I am sure moat people who go there will not come back with empty hands...

Closed on Second Easter and Sunday!. We recently visited Barcelona before and after a Mediterranean cruise and sought out this amazing market on our first day, just before the cruise departure on the following day. We had great plans to shop here before returning home after we returned to Barcelona after our cruise. We were back in Barcelona on Saturday May 26 and decided we would do some touring on the 26th and 27th and shop on the 28th, the Monday before our return home very early on the 29th. We expected stores to be closed on the Sunday even though their economy would probably benefit from businesses being more accessible especially with so many tourists around, but we were really surprised when they were again closed on the Monday for what we discovered (too late) was the Second Easter holiday.We had not seen this mentioned in any guide books and there were no signs in stores and large markets such as this, advising of this holiday. Even the large El Corte Inglés store off Placa Catalunya was closed and there were no signs advising of the reason why.As a result all the shopping we did was either at small corner stores that were open and the duty free shop at the airport on the day we left.

well worth a visit. there is so much fruit here that you won't know where to look.They sell pots of various sizes with different fruits and prices and they do look nice and fresh.There are also fruit juices of all kinds to satisfy your thirst.The prices are cheaper than any where else that we found.The market is a little off La Ramblas tucked behind the shops but find it and you will enjoy just looking.

Best. Juice. Ever. Amazing photo ops too!. Just off La Rambla, La Boqueria is a literal feast for the senses. Such an incredible variety of fruits, meats, cheeses, breads - and juice! You must try the fresh juice. We kept going back and trying different flavours. Just delicious. Colourful in so many ways - from the displays to the people you'll meet. A great place to wander into around lunchtime (which can be really any time in the afternoon in Barcelona) and just munch on all the different offerings. Bring your camera, the vibrancy translates into some beautiful pictures without even trying. Don't miss it!

Midway on the pedestrian Ramblas, this is a great farmers market for photos. The colors look good enough to eat -- and so do the produce, meat, and tapas here. One of the nicest indoor markets in Spain.

One of the world's best food markets. A trip to La Boqueria is something you will never forget and not to be missed attraction when in Barcelona. Easy to find via a short stroll down La Rambla from Plaza Catalunya. From ultra fresh seafood and vegtables to spice vendors, olive vendors and much more, La Boqueria is a feast for all the senses! You can sit down inside or outside at one of the numerous little food stalls serving meals as well and take a break from the madness. All of the food vendors inside serve meals made using only ingredients from the market. But prepare yourself for hordes of people as it takes time and patience to get around this massive market. Exceptional experience.

A Market For All Senses. If you like local markets when travelling this is a must. The color and textures of the food, the aromas and sounds of the market, all worth taking in. Chocolate lovers will be in heaven viewing the beautiful chocolates on display and even the fruit displays were beautiful. Just off La Ramblas you don't have to make it an event on your itinerary but drop by and it will become an event to remember.

Great outdoor market- Food - Drinks - great price- No SUNDAY. A have to when in Barcelona and strolling along Las Ramblas- half way down it will be on your right side- just walk in and start to munch--- from Serrano Ham to Manchego cheese- need a drink have some Cava or Sangria or Wine and Beer- need something sweet- its all there. Open till 6pm everyday except Sunday's

Cool place. A really great place. If its edible its here. Great even just to walk around and experience it.You need to be clear with the stall holders how much you want to spend else you will get ripped off, for example when buying things like chocolate or nuts.I loved this place but think due to the language barrier i didnt experience it to the full. Think i would consider a food tour round here next time i go to barcelona or learn the language!We went here twice, second time on the way home for lots of bits to take to the airport, much cheaper and tastier than airport produce. And maybe worth stocking up on some items if your a foodie, dried mushrooms, spices etc.Wish we'd tried one of the lovely tapas bars that are here they are very popular.Only negative was we couldnt find any toilets.

a sensory excitation. every time i visited Barcelona i visited the La Bouqueria to enjoy the colour the smell and taste of Barcelona and the rest of the world in one go. It has never been a disappointment. i loved the iced fruit juice,rambutan and dragon fruit.The display of fish was unique.

A must when in Barcelona. Since our hostel was practically next door the market was a perfect stop every morning for some fresh fruit and exquisite juices. Apart from the convenience, la Boqueria is a must when you're in Barcelona to take in the smells, colors, crowds and deliciousness.
LIVELY MARKET. This is a must! A bustling food market where you can purchase all kinds of fruits, vegetables, assorted meats, fish and cheeses.

Foodies heaven. If you are a food lover, hobby chef etc then definitely do this. We were going to do a foodies tour but opted to just wander the aisles ourselves. As it is situated off La Rabla it is so easy to access and it doesn't take long to do.

Fantastic Food Voyage through La Boqueria. This very old (1200s), crowded and amazing market with endless and brightly colored displays of the best products of Catalonia is a must-see for any visitor to Barcelona. There are coffees and candies, pastas and peppers, tapas bars, wine bars, ham and honey, spices and seafood, most food groups are represented here. My advice would be to take a Barcelona food tour, which includes other stops including La Boqueria, so you can get an overview and a quick tour with a knowledgeable guide. Then return to La Boqueria on your own to visit or revisit some of your favorite food stalls. This is a perfect place for pocket pickers so watch your bags and wallets!!located just off La Rambla, although an outdoor market, the market is covered.

a must see!. A very nice outdoor market! Don't be put off by a couple of beggars at the front of the market - Barcelona could really try to do more in terms of beggars, and annoying street vendors trying to sell you all kind of trinkets...Other than that, la Boqueria is absolutely wonderful. Went there a couple of times for fresh juices and fruits! We went both early in the morning, when people were just arranging the stalls, in the afternoon, in the middle of the buzz and in the evening, for a couple of bargains. Definitely recommended, at least for 5 minutes if you are strolling down La Ramblas.

Wow and wow!. Never seen a food market with such vibrancy of colour, variety and abundance in my life....you MUST experience this, we would have loved to have sat at one of the tapas bar's within the market, but just too long to wait... Loved it!
Fabulous!. This is a foodies paradise! Loved La Boqueria! The carnercia, the tropical fruits stalls, the vegetable stalls and the flower displays are not to be missed. Bring your camera.

"THE" market in Barcelona, but.... An exceptional array of choices abounds at this very famous marketplace. There are tapas places, restaurants, meat, seafood, fruit, produce, pastries, candies, and more, to choose from.It's a sensory overload here, uncomfortably crowded (in mid May) and noisy. Imagine the zoo it must be during the Summer months! We were unable to get a seat at a few places, and felt as though we couldn't move through the market at our own pace.It's obviously a tourist destination, but hey, we were tourists, and we were told that all "foodies" needed to see this place. I'm glad we saw La Boqueria, I really am, but next time will seek out the more "local" market offering (Santa Caterina, I believe).

CROWDED,NOISY,& STUFFY. We usually enjoy food markets and i am sure that if it was not stuffed with thousands of visitors it could have been better.Actually we were there twice but the first time we did not succeed to get through the main gate because of the crowds.

Smells and colours were amazing!. Just off La Rambla in Raval we stumbled across the huge Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria. It was pretty rammed when we went so be prepared for some elbows and your toes being trodden on (mainly near the entrance and exit) but once inside it really is worth it.The colours and smells and sheer volume of produce was amazing, the best market I've ever been in. The quality looked to be very good - but I didn't purchase anything, nor did I pay too much attention to the price... so I couldn't say whether it is a complete tourist trap or not. Still worth experiencing though.We also noticed that as well as the traditional market stalls there were places were you could grab a bite to eat after it being cooked right in front of you.A nice (but just as busy) escape from La Rambla :)

A Feast for the Senses!. Fabulous food market!If the variety of raw food and prepared delicacies were not enough, the numerous bar stool type tapas bars were truly delightful.The sounds of lively chatter mixed with sizzling food and independent musicians all lent to its vibrant atmosphere. Varying scents of fruits, meats and viands were enough to make one giddy with anticipation. We loved a deli merchant who just sliced off pieces of jamon from a huge leg and picked cheese from his vast selection which he handed us to try. We could not resist the crispy looking array of croquetas, piles of turrones, and mounds of nuts, chocolates and other interesting treats.After selecting our croquettas, jamon and queso, we parked at a tapas bar where we ordered some food and wine to complement our initial purchases. Everything tasted wonderful! We ate most of it by hand which felt so rustic and old world. I recommend experiencing Boqueria no other way!Downside is it supposedly closes at 5pm which is sad cause it would make for a really great night market.Undoubtedly one of our favorite experiences in Europe. Once is not enough.

Beautiful, winter review. Beautiful displays. We went at the end of Winter. Main things that seemed different were (possibly to do with when we went) many meat vendors were closed, though a number of the seafood vendors were still open (with interesting things to see ... I didn't know people eat barnacles?)Beautiful displays of fruit though no little flat peaches that I saw in Summer, many years before.Beautiful displays of candied fruits and chocolates.Many different kind of juices but of the 4 or 5 I tried, they all made me wonder if they were made partially or entirely from cordials or other liquids which weren't fresh juices (it could be the time of year or the mixtures I'd picked)Nuts on display too :)I recommend the dried peaches there :)My girlfriend loved it (so did I). She took some beautiful photos :) :) :) We went back more than once and if we'd stayed in Barcelona longer than a few days (we could've if we had more time and given the option) we would've gone back even more times :)

More than a market, it is the catalan life live in front of you. colors, smells, sellers, clean- small open shops, you can taste, buy, drink, eat. Cherries, rasberies, vegetables, fishes, pastries, cheese, meats. You can buy your breakfast. Fresh juices. Buy salami catalan, cheese and prepare your own sandwiches for the day and breakfast or sit around a tapas bar and enjoy
Tantalising!. What a choice of fruit, cheese, meats, spices, sweets, wines, fish, break - mouthwatering.

Food Party. La Boqueria (Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria) is a large food market on La Rambla in central Barcelona. The market can be traced back to 1217 as an open air market. With years of development, it now has the metal roof since 1914.We all need to eat and finding food becomes more critical when you are travelling. Most of the time, it is not that easy to find a place that provides all kinds of food under one roof. La Boqueria is a unique place that not only has more food than you can imagine, but also is right in the center of the city. You can take the metro to the Liceu station (L3) and walk to this famous market. It sells hams (jamón), fruits, meats, sausages, vegetables, fish, nuts and fresh juices. You can also buy tapas and other local food for lunch, and it is cheaper than you can get in the restaurants.This colorful market place will be in our memory for a long time. It is a place that you have to visit when in Barcelona. I bet you will go to La Boqueria not once, but many times if you stay in Barcelona for awhile.
wonderful. went there on the basis of trip advisore reviews well worth the visit and lived up to expectations

La Boqueria is a 'Must See' in Barcelona. Spent a week's vacation in Barcelona and after visiting La Boqueria on the 2nd day, I wanted to go there everyday. The market is so colorful & lively! It is also clean. The vendors creatively display their merchandise of fresh vegetables, fruits, nuts, fresh fish, dried salted fish, shellfish, fresh meats, all kinds of Spanish hams & chorizos, candies, freshly squeezed juices, tapas, fish fry, etc. The whole market is exciting! There are bars where you can have tapas & wine. As a tourist, you can save money by eating in this market. Food is fantastic at an affordable price. Even if you're only in Barcelona for a day, don't miss to vist La Boqueria.

Beautifully displayed!. What a great place, even if you do not try anything it is just a nice experience everyone visiting Barcelona should enjoy. Food was so fresh and beautifully displayed, fuits, seafood, ham and meats. We tried their "zumos" and they were delicious and if you feel like eating try their Jamon Iberico.

Definitely worth the visit. La Boqueria is definitely worth a visit while in Barcelona. It's right off of Las Ramblas (easy to find - you'll see the huge crowds on one of the side streets) It's fun to just walk around & try a few foods if you're interested (but a lot of the stuff needs to be cooked) Watch for pick pockets & keep an eye on your stuff. Otherwise just have fun seeing everything!

A must for food lovers. Great architecture, really colourful and the array of food is amazing and the smells are fantastic. Bought smoked paprika and saffron here at reasonable price. Try the tapas as well. Cod balls on a stick are great and fantastic value. If you are a foodie and love cooking this market is a must see. If travelling in on the metro get off at Liceu, market is right by the metro stop.

HOW FRUIT & SEAFOOD SHOULD BE..... ...And it's obvious the Catalonians keep the best produce for themselves and send the c**p to us, all joking put aside we wandered in here quite literally from La Ramblas. First impressions were good just looking at the vast array of fresh fruit, veg, and seafood etc, on offer. It was a joy to see oranges twice the size as i get back home, not to mention the prawns. Walking around we found it to be a bit chaotic at times due to the hundreds of tourists taking pictures and so on, a fact that wasn't lost on the traders and locals who tended to scowl at you at times, including one grumpy trader who proceeded to barge his way through the crowds with his barrow narrowly missing my legs, but did knock other tourists flying without as much as a sorry. That aside we enjoyed the fresh fruit juices 3 Euros for 2, the fast food outlets were tasty and cheap too, in fact it passed an hour or so looking at the amazing array of seafood some which was still twitching and winking at you now thats what i call fresh.! Yes i would say this is a definite visit just to see how the other half lives, the plus side here is it's free to enter and you can taste and buy just about anything that walks, swims, crawls, or fly's..The downside is the traders are not the friendliest I've met on my travels around the World and are pretty dour in my opinion and a smile here and there wouldn't have gone amiss, but if you love fruit, seafood, & chocolate then this is the place for you, and wait until you see and try the strawberries on offer pure joy i kid you not...

You must try the fresh juices and fruit salads.. A little bit crowed sometimes. There is a vast variety of eatables to buy from, such as fresh juices, fruits and vegetables, meat, fish, chocolates, candies etc.

Amazing experience. Well worth 2 go, fruit, fish meat cheese veg nuts ham chocolate olives whatelse u want.Just go to see it or go n have fresh shellfish at 1 of the tapas bars, went to 1 on the corner on left , fantastic amazing razor clams, clams ok, prawns sweet n delicious!! Picked up few other bits 4 picnic in beach!!

dazzling display!!. the market is off la rambla and is a bustling, exciting place full of amazing food to tempt you. there are juices for 1€ at some stalls (though some of the concoctions are pretty weird and i am not sure how much watering down was done!) and also stalls selling jamon, seafood, tapas, nougat, etc. it is full to the brim and a bit of a tourist trap! stopped at the chocolate shop and as it was really busy, i couldn't really get what the price was - the guy seemed to say it was 86 cents a kilo and after i picked a few items, he said it was 20€ or something like that. as he was distracted and rather rude, i just dumped the bag i had and left. the stalls are really dazzling, the wares are arranged beautifully and it's a feast for the eyes and senses, so it's definitely a stop to make to experience the liveliness of the market, but do be vigilant and conscious of your surroundings as it is very packed!!
Food Lovers - don't miss!. After 5 minutes in this amazing market, we wished for cooking facilities! Next time, we'll rent an apartment so we can cook after a morning of shopping here. Wow!

One of our best stops in Barcelona. I admit it. I was trying to be like those cool TV chefs and stop at the local market, a la Anthony Bourdain. I'm so glad I did! My husband and I ended up staying much longer than expected. It's fascinating to watch little old grandmas wield massive cleavers and hack the heads off of fish that are bigger than any I've ever seen! The variety of skinned rabbits and sheeps' heads with their eyeballs still in is...well...gross. But you can't stop looking! LOL. It makes me realize how far removed we are in the USA from where our food originates. This was the first place I got up the courage to attempt a little Spanish. With mostly hand gestures, I managed to procure just a slice of local manchego cheese and a slice of the famous jabon ham. For less than two Euros, my husband and I had an absolutely delicious snack. We also bought a fruit called a "cherimoya," which I'd read about in a kid's magazine. It is very hard to ship and only grows in a few spots on the planet, Barcelona being one of them. You slice it open and eat it with a spoon, and it's creamy and sweet, like ice cream. What a great experience!

A must see!. This is a wonderful, colorful market!You can see everything from seafood, fruits, meat and candy. It is so big and versatile, I loved it! I especially enjoyed the fish market (they had a huge fish head - I've never seen anything like it!) and the candy stall.I also loved the colorful fruit slushies - you can get two for 2€ (or one for 1,5€). We tried the kiwi and pineapple mix, and it was wonderful.We also bought some cut fruit, that was wonderful. A quarter of very delicious pineapple cost 1€ or 2€ (I can't really remember), a box of cut fruit with pineapple, mango, strawberries and kiwi (Kiwi was especially delicious! So sweet!) cost 2,5€. We also bought a box with pieces of coconut, which was very interesting, since I've never tried "real" coconut before. I don't remember the price, but I think it was 2€.It's really a wonderful market, and you can stroll around as long as you wish. But it does get quite crowded in the afternoon.

A must see!. This is a wonderful, colorful market!You can see everything from seafood, fruits, meat and candy. It is so big and versatile, I loved it! I especially enjoyed the fish market (they had a huge fish head - I've never seen anything like it!) and the candy stall.I also loved the colorful fruit slushies - you can get two for 2€ (or one for 1,5€). We tried the kiwi and pineapple mix, and it was wonderful.We also bought some cut fruit, that was wonderful. A quarter of very delicious pineapple cost 1€ or 2€ (I can't really remember), a box of cut fruit with pineapple, mango, strawberries and kiwi (Kiwi was especially delicious! So sweet!) cost 2,5€. We also bought a box with pieces of coconut, which was very interesting, since I've never tried "real" coconut before. I don't remember the price, but I think it was 2€.It's really a wonderful market, and you can stroll around as long as you wish. But it does get quite crowded in the afternoon.
A must for foodies!!. You really must go there, the fresh foods are amazing, fruits, fish meats, etc and try the tapas there, it' so good! Just a great way to spend a couple of hours.
Great for trying out new things. Liked the juices and fruits. Disliked the smell of the meats though.

Must See for Foodies and Photogs. What an experience the market is. Do take the time to at least breeze through. And do take your camera. While white balance is tricky (you can fix at home) the opportunities for shooting are spectacular. Full of interesting items that you won't see anywhere (at least) in the US. From sheep heads to sea urchins. Emu eggs to candied fruit. The amount of time that goes into some of the food displays is amazing. And the selection can't be beat. Make sure you at least get some olives and some nuts. Perhaps a snack of jamon. For those with better kitchen facilities on their trip there is a veritable banquet available.

Fresh but expensive, especially for tourists. La Boqueria is located abeam midway of La Rambla, the large street connecting the center of Barcelona with the Maritime area. It is a popular place, there is everything re food and as always the heart of the market is taken up by the fish department. Awesome sight, if there is something swimming in an ocean, it is there at La Boqueria. BUT, my eye caught a technique of a lady selling chocolate. The scales were blank, when a local came to buy something the price was Euro 35 per kilo. When a tourist showed interest she put in another price, Euro 68 per kilo. So, if you want to get something pay attention. Don't say I didn't warn you.

Fine place but crowdy. I loved the atmosphere of this market, with strange seafood offers and colorful fruits, but if you can visit this place early morning, for avoiding the crowd. On the up corner of the building close to the rambla an authentic vinery can be found.

Start off your day here. A wonderful market that we enjoyed exploring. The fresh fruit was a nice start for the day rather than all the pastries at all the breakfast stops. I was disappointed in the chocolates, but they looked great!We enjoyed lunch at Bar Boqueria. See that review in restaurants.

A Must Visit. Every visit to Barcelona must include a trip to la Boqueria. It is quite an experience to see all of the fresh produce, seafood, meats and well as the restaurant stalls all under one roof. Each time I travel to Barcelona, I have breakfast at Bar Pinotxo-blood orange juice, a criossant and a cortado. The staff is very friendly and appear to really have fun doing their jobs. It is an uplifting experience to start the day. Allow a couple of hours to make your way through the maze of vendors at la Boqueria. You might even want to stay for lunch as there are many options.

Colorful and tasty!!!. This is a market in the centre of the city, right on La Rambla so not visiting it is quite absurd, but just in case you think markets aren't interesting, think twice. This is one of the best places in Barcelona: colorful, tasty, amazing and vibrant! You will see more fruits than you have ever seen and you will be able to taste them - fruit salad bowls and freshly squeezed juice are sold at the market at very low prices. Walking further inside the market you can continue this tasting tour: freshly cut ham and salami, cheese, bread, sweets etc. There are several food bars in the market, too, always full and offering delicious local dishes. Don't miss the sea food stalls which are even more amazing and abundant than everything you have already seen. This is a true feast to the eyes!Most probably you will stay at the market at least twice as long as you have planned and you will not regret it. If you are staying in Barcelona long enough you will probably visit it several more times - whenever you feel hungry and it's not dinner time yet. La Boqueria will definitely end up being one of your favourite places in Barcelona!

Amazing!. Don't miss this great sensorial experience: sounds, colours, scents, flavors...Fruit, fish, cheese, hams and other salumes...everything attracts your eyes and your nose.You can eat inside or in one of the little restaurant just around the Market or taste some extremely good fruit or juices inside at a very cheap price: we took a fruit salad of almost 300 grams, with strawberries, kiwis and papaya for only 1,5 euro!

Wow. This place was awesome. I had never seen such a variety of fish, meat, fruits, vegetables, candies.... etc. etc. etc.! Would love to go back again. The sweetest and juciest dates I ever ate were purchased here.

Tourists put your cameras away and eat!.
