Just off the tacky las ramblas lies the jewel of Barcelona A fantastic frenetic market which is super practical but always a a joy to the sensesAs a local resident it can be annoying to see the place rammed with tourists taking pictures when they should be indulging themselvesWhat is better to eat a star fruit or take a picture?The best fruit and vegetables in all Barcelona are on sale there at a fraction of the price of el Cortes inglesOne point though is the little bars in the market where you can basically get them to cook anything you want from the market which are fantastic and not to be missed, just wait for a seat to be free and slip in. Quality is fantastic and prices are keen. You will have to take each seat as it comes availinle if there are a few of youI bought the best shrimp there are closing time, at 2.30 the lobster sizes shrimp were down from 27 euros a kilo to 10 and were the the best I have ever eaten.Nearer the back there are more humble butchers still selling excellent quality productsEverywhere the Jamon is excellent

A feast for the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth!. This is a great market! All of the food displays are beautiful (even the butcher displays that have lamb heads, tongue and tripe!) You're sure to see a few food items you've might not have seen before. Buy yourself a freshly squeezed fruit juice or fruit salad and stroll through this market and enjoy the sights! There are a few small restaurant counters with only a small number of seats at each. If you can score a couple of counter seats, enjoy the tapas and the wonderful seafood available at these "cafes".This is a must see when in Barcelona, but avoid on weekends though when the crowds are intolerable!
Fantastic & typicall Catalan Market. Beatifull arquitecture, plenty of colours, really typical, located in a charming square place with a lot of coffees & shops, nearby the RAMBLAS

One of the Better World Markets. I have seen big/small and run-down/well-kept markets all over the globe. This is a very PICTURESQUE market not too big that has a great variety of food (though Spanish) and one could prepare whatever Spanish one would want to. It seems to be more priced to a tourist budget and not for the locals although. One of the things that should be noted in markets is, does the locals squeeze the oranges?i will still recommend it for seeing (for sure), but be prepared for a price a tourist will expect.

One of my favorite places in Bcn. The color mix at Bouqueria is something amazing. No matter how many times I go there, I still get impressed. Amazing photo opportunities of authentic Bcn and dynamic movements of the people.The food is also great. I recommend it for a lunch break more than any restaurant! Fresh, healthy and delicious!

A must!. If you are lucky enough to stay at at hotel near this market, you can visit it every day. It is not only full of exciting food, but several bars where you can have a meal. It is also popular to have breakfast here in the morning. The market has a large choice of meat, fish, vegetables and other things. If you want to bring something home, the turro (typical Spanish sweet with almonds) is a must. L'Agramuntina who sells this sweet is located in the middle. Otherwise, you should buy good ham (preferrably the pata negra or belota instead of ordinary serrano that you find everywhere). I always buy almonds and nuts in a shop on the opposite side of the entrance (I have the impression that the farer you walk, the cheaper it is): ordinary hazelnuts and almonds or salted and roasted.One thing to avoid: I have tried the fruit salads in several shops at this market, but I am often disappointed: it seems slightly overpriced to pay 2 euros for a bowl mostly filled with watermelon...

Happy quick meals in the Ramblas areas. We ducked into the Mercado de la Boqueria, just off the Ramblas. The stalls are vibrant and the site bustling. Compared to some Latin American markets, it is upscale. They had wonderful fresh juices to-go, my favorite being the blackberry-coconut, as well as some fruits that we had not seen in the US. We got hooked on the fresh-squeezed approach throughout our trip. The Barceloni have a great chocolate tradition. And, they prize the Spanish jamon with the smoked haunches hanging in the stalls. We went several times during our trip when we could not face the touristy cafes and prices. For breakfast, we perched in a small side cafe and had great coffee, and pudding-thick hot chocolate with churros. For lunch, we liked the fresh baguette sandwiches.

La Boqueria. This is the highlight of Las Ramblas. Frenetic and Fantastic. Stalls piled high with fruit, vegetables, sweets, jellies, nuts and hanging with fronds of chillis. The fish and shellfish are amazing. And a great place for lunch! Read more in my blog at http://bigbarcelonablog.blogspot.com.es/2012/04/la-boqueria.html

Fantastic.. This is a treat NOT to be missed for displays and colours. A staggering mouth watering selection of foods, flowers, fish and meats. The meat counters had some of the most extraordinary and sometimes disgusting things available which were jaw dropping just to look at. There were also some nice little Tapas bars amongst the stalls.

Must see, must buy food, must eat it. Go there. It's as simple as that. Fabulous atmosphere, and all you can possibly want in a market - including specialties. Take a bite on one of the small bar-style diners inside the market.

Catalan food pornography. The earlier you can get here, the better. It gets quite crowded at times. You should wander throughout the whole complex, I'd be surprised if you don't see something for the first time after making it through - whether its Emu and Ostrich eggs or some unidentifiable sea creature. These are the ingredients- the flavors- that make up one of the world's most celebrated cuisines. It's hard walking through and not imagining what you'd cook (or would like to eat) later that day.The eating establishments within the market are all well regarded, and you will eat well there, though you will pay extra for the experience. Additionally, though this is a market, it may not be the most economical place to pick up goods to take home like saffron. Be sure to shop around within Barcelona before you commit to anything.

Pretty, but Pricey, Unfriendly, and Lacked Variety. Markets are usually the highlight of any trip for me and my husband. Had high hopes that La Bourgueria would be a world-class market, but it didn't stack up to markets in San Lorenzo in Florence, Santa Fe, NM, Portobello Road London fruit and Veg, the Ferry Building in San Francisco-- to name a few. I rated this good because of presentation and the fabulous modernist arch at the market's entry. The food is a sumptuous array, gorgeously arranged, but every stall offers the same goods. There was little variety within each class of food. Boring and over-priced with one exception: the fish looked translucent, plump fresh, but as a traveler I couldn't sample. Vendors are not simpatico as they tend to be in most markets. Very few offer samples. If we were purchasing a 90-euro ham, we would have been treated differently; in most markets that doesn't matter. You can ask questions and expect friendly responses without a purchase. Beware of hand-sliced Serrano ham. Ours was very tough. Try to sample first. Watch out with cheeses. They sell come sheep cheeses as Manchego that is some other kind (not bad, but not Manchego). Just outside the market to the right are a few produce vendors who don't have prime market real estate but whose goods are fresher and better value. The bread at the one bakery stand (near outside vendors off to the right) is outstanding and well-priced sandwiches. We got better value in the supermarkets, which are wonderful. Went to a few as we had a car. Staff in each one spoke no English but bent over backwards to help us. In Barcelona you must go to city outskirts. Pre-sliced Serrano ham was moist and delicious. Manchego was a bargain at about $3 a pound. (1/3 of a kilo?) Great for gifts like wine, olive oil, chocolate and cheese. Might not be able to get the ham on the plane because of agriculture laws. There's some way to do it, but we didn't check. The restaurants inside the market looked promising but even off season we couldn't get close to counter. Crowds 3 and 4 deep hover over diners--unlike Florence where the market restaurants frequented by tourists and locals have one line. Same great noisy energy level but without ravenous folks leaning over your shoulder while you're eating.

Try A Little Bit Of Everything. I wanted to get the most out of the market so I tried as many different things as I could while I was there. First I bought some cold, delicious Sangria and walked around. Later, for dinner, I bought ham, cheese, figs, tomato and an empanada. It was all delicious - especially the figs. The market is a fun and lively place. A must see.

Worth the visit. Definitely worth the trip - tons of great meat, excellent fresh smoothies and fruit, and lots of fresh seafood - SO FRESH, THEY STILL MOVE! Yep, live seafood in ice...it doesn't get much fresher than that!

A fun time with great food. This is another must-do in Spain, even if you aren't going to buy anything. The fresh meats, seafoods, and fruits are top-notch, and the haggling experience is a blast. The prices can be a little steep on some items, but the experience is well worth it.
Amazing. Even if you don't buy anything, pop in to experience the sights, sounds and smellsFab

Intoxicating smells....all the good kind!. If you do one thing in Barcelona visit la Boqueria! Conveniently located right off La Rambla its the perfect spot to grab a quick breakfast, a snack to take on your sightseeing day or settle in to people watch as you enjoy lunch. The smells of this market are just intoxicating!!! The entry way introduces you to all the color of fruits, veggies, and juices. Go a little further into the market to come face to face with meats galore! Seafood stalls are in a bit of a circular hall toward the back. Cheeses, flowers, candies..you name it...its here!I just walked around with my mouth on the ground in awe and in pure desire to try a bit of everything! The first day we settled for some apricots and walnuts from one of the front stalls for our bike ride. We returned the next day to sit at one of the surrounding cafes for a coffee and quick bite for breakfast. If you happen to have the patience or good timing....grab a stool at one of the cafes towards the back of the market. These are really prime people watching spots!

Go Before Closing for Discounts. Great stuff. There's a vendor toward the back that sells tropical fruits but a lot of them are expensive. Actually, I think the common fruits are cheaper the farther into the market you go.At closing time, some vendors sell the juices for 1 euro, more than 50% discount.
Very Colourful. Went a walk to this first thing in the morning as it was just up from the Hotel,very colourful, full of fruit/veg/fish etc,again a must.

Taste and colour of Barcelona. On the edge of Las Ramblas, the main tourist street through Barcelona, their is a large indoor market, immediately on entering this big hall you are blasted with the mixture of colours, the first thing that grabbed my eye was a stall that had lots of smotthies on it, of all different colours, spectacular, had to try one! then saw one with all colourful sweets on it, bought a bag of them! then saw a fruit stall so bought 500g of red cherrys, spectacular!then we took a walk around, ice cream, cheese, fish, butchers god i wished i'd lived in Barcelona, i would work and shop in this place, it's amazing!The only down thing that happenned was that we went to a tapas bar there and asked them to knock up something for us, they gave us a seafood platter with eggs and potatos, it was really nice, but they charged us €50 for it, i felt a bit like a mug of a tourist when this happenned but that was my own fault, considering that i saw a local handing over a tenner and he had a big plate of allsorts and beer too. At this point, watch out for some of the spaniards, they seem to think that they have the right to charge tourists extra, just be weary.overall though the market is spectacular

Colorful Market Makes for a Nice Respite from Sightseeing. Don't miss visiting this fabulous market near the Gothic center of Barcelona. You will find a beautiful display of fruits and vegetables, butchers, seafood vendors, spice vendors and much more. Grab a glass of fresh-squeezed juice while wandering around and plan to eat tapas at one of their busy cafe bars - delicious food and well-priced!

La Boqueria: Feast for your eyes and your palate. La Boqueria is a fresh produce market right in the center of Barcelona (adjacent to the lower parts of Las Ramblas) which also features a number of fabulous little eateries and bars where you can grab a quick bite to eat in the course of the day. This is a great place to see all kids of local produce, some exotic, others slightly more familiar. Of course, everything is ultra-fresh (and very often alive).The little eateries offer some seating (get ready for a substantial wait) but most people just do take-away, carrying around their little trays and dishes as they browse through the market or venture into the streets of the city. The best time to visit is around lunch time.Nibbling your way through La Boqueria is the real way to taste Barcelona’s food – you can meet lots of interesting locals who aggregate here eagerly, and at the same time stay very close to the center of the movida.After visiting La Boqueria we regretted we were staying at a hotel instead of renting an apartment – it would have been so fun to shop at La Boqueria and cook on our own!

Wall to Wall Color. It was fun to roam around. Most of what is there is of no use to tourists except for sightseeing. There are a number of places to buy chocolate, fruit, juices, etc for take away and there are several small restaurants generally arranged around bars. Most of the people eating there seemed to be locals and some of the places had people waiting on seats.Definitely worth a visit and probably a good place for lunch or breakfast if you are staying on Las Ramblas.

One of the world's most beautiful markets. As soon as you reach the walkway up to the Boqueria the first thing you are hit with is colour everywhere. As you go in you will be visually accosted with so much colour, visually amazing and artistic displays and a selections of every food you can think of and it's really hard to know where to look first. One can easily spend ages just walking around this extremely busy market which never seems to empty out. Easy to get to as it's just off La Rambla.

Fun. I expected to hate the Boqueria. Yes it's a tourist trap and some of the vendors are not nice (one Spanish lady ripped my head off because I barely touched a vegetable). The fish market in the center is very interesting. And we had a tasty lunch at Bar Clemens in the back. (If you do choose to eat at counter service, only choose those bars that have prices publicly displayed, like Bar Clemens, or you might get a rude surprise).

Colorful and appealing. La Bouqueria market is something not to be missed if you are in Barcelona for foodies and non-foodies alike. The food is beautifully displayed. It is very colorful and appealing. You want to buy everything! The assortment of meats is intriguing and perhaps a little disturbing for us North Americans. Not sure when a good time to go as we were there at about 10:00 and it was very busy. Expect a crowd, especially at the front.

Kokua Shoes - amazing. Shopping in Barcelona is great fun, but when you get tired feet head to Kokua Shoes to fit yourself out with the best pumps found in Europe. You can't buy them online, so well worth tracking down and investing in a couple of pairs (only 60 euros and they last for ages. C/Boqueria, 30 (C/Banys Nous), Barcelona, Catalonia 08002Great blog an photos here: http://www.thebaghagdiaries.com/2010/06/spanish-ballet-flats.html

Go their for breakfast!. I really enjoyed La Boqueria. First of all, we took dozens of nice pictures. And we tried amazing fruits, fruit juices and ham sandwiches. I read some reviews saying it was not worth the visit, but I don’t agree. Perhaps I am used to much smaller markets… The fact is I really had a nice time!

La Rambla's most colorful place. La boquería is a colorful, noisy and ally appealing market located at the heart of La Rambla. It is obviously a touristy place but it is well worth a visit. Unlike the other restaurants in this area which seem to focus on serving expensive meals to ingenuous tourists, in La Boquería you will find a nice variety of fresh tasty products. Therefore it is probably the best place in La Rambla area to have a decent meal. Even so, the best thing about this market is its’ own atmosphere. The merchants are friendly and you can even try to bargain for your favorite snack. I was lucky enough to buy six juices for two Euros at a stand about to close.Summing up I would say that instead of expecting an exotic place filled with unknown products, one should prepare himself to visit a large traditional market. It is a fact that all products available at La boquería can be found somewhere else (and even cheaper!) but you won´t find many places with the same atmosphere.

Not as good as its reputation. I realise that what I am saying is controversial - stick with it. I am 55 and been coming to Barcelona for 3 decades so I've picked up a few tips along the way. I give la boqueria 3 stars simply as it really is a must see - an institution on the Ramblas, and the iron architecture is superb.However here are some drawbacks for you:1. It's s rip off. The prices are sky high for a market - especially on the stalls nearest the front. If you must buy here go to the rear.2. It's really hard work; the crowds are immense. because of this you MUST watch your pockets and bags, and don't leave that $1000 Nikon swinging round your neck as the thieves carry blades to cut the straps3. Avoid on Spanish public holidays - it's chockaThere's a much better alternative. Go to the Mercat Santa Caterina - it's about 120 meters from the Gothic Cathedral, other side of Via Laetania....you can see its coloured wavy roof from the Cathedral square. See my photos.This modern building is stunning, there are no crowds, the prices are much better and it's more a locals' market than a tourist trap. And they've even built in roman remains in the same building.From here it's also an easy 5 minute walk to the Picasso Museumenjoy both.

Fantastic fresh juice, fruit, cheese, artisanal chocolate. Our first visit to this major produce market was an hour after we arrived in Barcelona. We ate lunch at a pizza stall inside the market, and that pizza was every bit as good as pizza in Rome. The market has several stalls that sell a staggering variety of fresh fruit smoothies for 1 Eu a glass. We returned a couple of times to eat an early dinner of fruit, cheese and chocolate. The vendors were obliging and sliced a hunk of Spanish manchego cheese in 3 for us. Same with chocolate. Delicious. Wish I was back there now!! Market closes at 8 p.m. every day.

What a place!. You can find all kinds of things in here from fish and meat to candy. The candy was great!You need to be attentive to your purse/wallet as it can be snatched. The best part was Bar Quim for tapas. A bit hard to find a seat, but worth the wait. It's where the locals go. The tapas were delicious and the people so friendly. Try the fried artichoke.
Another must see. Great market lots of energy delicious food on the go at cheap prices!!!!

Top of your list after Gaudi..... One of my favourite food markets in the world and this is about my 4th trip to Barcelona and I still love it. We took some friends there yesterday which was a Monday and many stores were still shut around lunch time and most of the seafood stalls were not open so I am presuming that Monday was not a good day for fish. Its a delight for the senses only draw back are the big groups of tourists ..... looking foward to stocking up before the national strike day and cooking in our rental apartment!
Colourful, bustling and a feast for all your senses. Lovely place. Great way to get to know local cuisine and buy cheese!

bustling market in a popular tourist promenade, La Rambla. St Joseph's Market is one of the destinations that makes La Rambla a popular street with tourists. It is a good place to buy meat, fish, fruit and vegetables if you happen to be staying in apartment accommodation nearby, and also good for drinks and snacks when passing by on walks to sights like the nearby Palau Güell.Take very good care of your valuables and carry items here and all along La Rambla because it is wellknown as a tourist area targeted by pickpockets and bag snatchers. The often crowded conditions here create ideal conditions for thieves, despite the strong local police patrol presence we noticed when visiting in February, 2012.The merchants' association of the market runs an informative multi-lingual (Catalan, Spanish, English, French) website at http://www.boqueria.info/ which is worth a look before you visit in person. The website includes a handy market map and list of stallholders which are good aids to planning shopping.

For tourist that never have seen an aubergine!. Don't waste your timeVery few original things leftAnd if you are not "Catalan" you are treated unfairly and really bad!!!!Especially in a Fish department!!!Good luck!

really nice place to visit. we visited the market in 8/3/2012 at none and it's already full with people but not crowded though. the market doesn't have anything that isn't food ( i thought i would found some clothes there) , really nice standing and nice order and colors , you will fine a lot of photo opportunities , and reasonable prices if you want to buy some fruits for a picnic .. locals shop there so this isn't a tourist trap.

A vibrant and colourful market. This market was the reason we opted to stay in self catering accommodation. Last time I was in Barcelona I really loved this market but was frustrated that I couldn’t buy the food and go away to cook it. Just of the Ramblas, this market is full of colourful stalls selling meat, fish, fruit and vegetables. There are also several stall were you can sit and get lunch. The choice of produce is mesmerising and the atmosphere is intoxicating. It’s a real market selling to the locals and the quality of the food is excellent. The different types of ham on offer was phenomenal. Even if you are not going to buy the food go in and have a look around and sit and taste the amazing tapas.

Best market in Europe. One of the coolest places I've ever been to, ever. Worth the 8 hour flight just to go here, spend a day, and turn around. If you're a foodie, or just like a good meal, this place is for you. Absolutely beautiful, well maintained, stocking everything from pig brains to passion fruit. I was in Barcelona for 5 days and I went here every day. Check out the mini restaurant in the far back for some good tapas, or check out the sandwich place for a quick chorizo on baguette.

Best Market and Great Choice for Breakfast/Lunch. Walking into the market, I was overwhelmed by the size of it and knew it would be fun to go through the different aisles of vendors and small cafes. There are a few places with quick pintxos of sausage or ham for a euro and many fruit stands sell this incredible variety of fruit juices and fresh ready to eat fruit like mango, coconut, pomegranate seeds. In addition to all the pintxos, we ate at a seafood stand that grilled your order in front of you. The great thing about the market is that it does not only cater to the tourist but is a regular market. We wanted to have some pintxos in the early evening and returned--while the market is open until 8pm, most food places were closed by 7pm when we returned.

right of the rambla.. and a step back in time. La Bouqueria is best visited in the morning, when the vast open market is bustling with vendors and shoppers amidst the stalls selling everything from pig heads to fine cheeses. this market is a permanent installation as opposed to the open air markets which pop up in france and spain once or twice a week. it is a unique view into life in barcelona as it has been going on for centuries. wonderful food stalls, sea food, nuts, spices, cheeses, meats, and a madhouse of smells, sounds, and sights.as it is right off the rambla midway between the square and the harbor, it is a must visit as one walks the rambla. lunch is available at a couple tiny sidewalk restaurants within the market. no charge, no hassle, and take lots of photos.

Life's a fish. This market was just down the street from our hotel. From 7 in the morning until 9 at night it was bustling. Everything you could every want for cooking or eating was here, Fresh, cheap and delicious. Breakfast everyday started here. One of the true gems of Barcelona

What an amazing experience. Wow, what a fantastic market! We wandered around looking at all the fresh produce, and the sights, sounds and smells were incredible.Our tip would be to try some of the tapas on offer, or just to have a fresh fruit juice for 1 Euro that you can take with you as you wander La Rambla. If you are a foodie then this place is a must see, loads of lovely cheeses and fresh fruit, as well as nuts and chocolates, fish and meat.We didn't feel the need to do a tour with a guide, wandering around by ourself at our own pace was perfect.Enjoy the experience!

Amazing..... Go to the small restaurant within the market and have the dish of the day. They get the food from the market and it is an amazing atmosphere. Get there early and blag a table outside.The choice of fruit, veg, meats and seafood put anything in the UK to shame. I wander in wonder - time has no meaning.

The Sant Josep Market is AMAZING!. For food lovers the Sant Josep Market is almost as paradise! It is completely indescrible. Really just a thing you have to experience during your stay in Barcelona!There is fresh food of all kind so what ever you are seaching for something special or just want to get inspired the food market is the place.Just go out and enjoy the Spanish passion for fresh food :)

Well worth the visit. This is a great market. Looks really lovely, and the things we bought were very tasty. (Juices, a plum, and some candied fruit). Yes, it is a little bit touristy, but it also has a lot of locals still buying plenty of stuff too. If you are on La Rambla anyway, it would be a shame to miss it really.

This fresh food market is a feast for all your senses!. Don't miss this market, it's beautiful - take your camera!Fresh produce, meats and cheeses, snack food, seafood, and the candy booths were beyond gorgeous. Not just for show, the locals actually shop here, so watching is an adventure in itself.(Crowded, so watch your belongings too.)This market also has a roof, so you can still enjoy it if it rains - and keeps the hot sun off in the summer.A couple tips: The food and juice booths near the front and outside are a bit more expensive than those deeper into the market - but they're also a little more well known. (location, location, location)If you're purchasing seafood to cook yourself, go early in the day - the fresh stuff goes fast.We ate lunch here twice while visiting. Found a small seafood dinner all the way in the back that was fantastic! Many locals were there as well, always a good sign. We love fresh seafood, and we were NOT disappointed, great food and not overpriced.If you want baby octopus for lunch go early - it sells out very quickly. :-)

Palette for the sense. Riotous colors, open-mouthed fish, shellfish and glowingly fresh sashimi, oggle-eyed sheep and goat heads, tripe, kidney, brains, refreshing and fruity smoothies, odoriferous cheeses, earthy palette of nuts and dried fruit, rainbow colors of every imaginable fruit, yelling, pushing, jostling, (watch for pick pocketers!); all your sense are heightened at this wonderfully busy and colorful market right off La Rambla. Don't miss it!

a gigantic, genuine riotous feast for the senses, almost an overwhelming display of the finest, freshest foodstuffs anyw. Barcelona - Late breakfast and lunch inside the Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria, in Las Ramblas. Anyone who has been to La Boqueria knows it is a gigantic, genuine riotous feast for the senses, almost an overwhelming display of the finest, freshest foodstuffs anywhere. I had never seen anything quite like it. Scattered throughout the market are more than a few places to sit down on a stool and eat, and we chose two during our visit: Pinotxo and Kiosko Universal. Both were just terrific, with fresh cooked small dishes (including some wonderful lamb skewers, gambas, and clams suggested by the wonderfully friendly owner/host/head waiter Juanito Bayen in a vest and bow tie, at the former; and razor clams, wild mushrooms, and a great grilled sole at the latter) and good cava! We would return!

Great!!!. Loved this place, had a great lunch of hand made pizza and beer for only a few euro. We tried several foods from several boths and all was great. We bought cany for the kids back at home and bought fresh fruite to and a fruit drinks to snak on. This place had everything!!!!

One of the best markets in the world. I love markets and this one even in winter is a delight to the taste buds, and the eyes. I especially enjoyed the fish market and the sweets.... On the Ramblas and well worth a visit and a taste
Don't Miss it. The colours, atmosphere and smells of the Market were brilliant! I have never seen fruit and veg like it. The presentation of produce was a work of art in itself

Can't miss it !. Fantastin covered market for food : great to see .. to smell and to taste. Try the wonderful hand made fruit juice they sell (1€ each) : orange&strawberries one was amazing!
Lot of nice pictures to shot throught your camera !
.

Eye candy for photographers. We found this market by accident as we meandered down Las Ramblas. From the outside, we had no idea how huge it is inside!! This was a great place to just wander about and let the colors, sights, sounds, and particularly near the meat/seafood stands - smells - overwhelm your senses. I had never seen such monstrous or colorful displays of fruits, veggies, candy, dried chilies and sausages, or fresh seafood in my life. A photographer could get lost finding interesting shots here and nobody seemed to mind us photographing their goods (as long as we didn't get in the way of serious shoppers). To boot, we scored an excellent deal on fresh cut fruit as it was the end of the day and the vendors were trying to unload food that might otherwise get thrown out. Don't be afraid to haggle - we ended up with boxes of fresh mango, papaya, strawberries, melon and coconut for just 3 euros. I loved the variety of cheeses being sold - though I don't think we got nearly as good a deal at that stand, the kindly vendors did give us several free samples so we could select just the right cheese to go with our meal. This did seem like an ideal location for pick-pockets so keep your valuables sealed up and secured. Also it was packed and some of the aisles were quite narrow which may be troublesome if you have a stroller or wheelchair.
WOW!. If you ever want to see fresh food at its best, then get to this market, great vibrant colours....dont forget your camera!!

This is a must visit!. Just off Las Ramblas, this place is a great way to see a little bit of Barcelona life, sit in a little "cafe" there are have a fresh spanish omelette and a coffee, then buy a fresh juice and some chocolate from one of the many stalls. Loved it!

explosion of colors. Beautiful mercat, is unavoidable. A lot of people, shouting, explosions of colors . Try fresh-squeezed juices (about 1.50 to 2 euros) and cold fresh sliced ​​fruit (about 2.50 to 3 euros) Colorful sweets and chocolates, dried fruit entice from each stand. Well-organized mercat.
Beautiful market. This market is beautiful. The merchants make real expositions of their fruits, fish and vegetables. A feast for the eye and mouth.

La Boqueria in Barcelona - A market that you will never forget. We were so priviledged to visit the famous fresh produce market La Boqueria in Barcelona. Just walking up the la Rambla to the market was already an experience never to forget. All the people and the street performers are mind boggling. We were flabbergasted to see all the good fresh juices, fish, meats, sweets, spices and the most amazing fruit. We just love sea food and had we been in a self catering cottage we would definitely have bought some. There is so much to buy that it is rather difficult deciding what you really want to eat. Everything is so beautifully arranged and the colours very inviting. One can easily spend a lot of money in a couple of minutes. I would recommend going to the market early as we found it very busy round lunch time. I would also recommend a quick walk through the market as prices vary and then one also has an idea what is available in this huge market.Do not miss it ....... You will LOVE IT!!!!!

Foodie paradise. The Lonely Planet recommended this for breakfast so we decided to have a look. From the moment we walked in the door we knew that it was worth the visit. We found Bar Sant Josep and parked ourselves on a stool and ordered coffee and tortilla - both were delicious. Then we spent several hours wandering the stalls and looking and tasting.

Boqueria - hectic, packed, exciting smorgasbord of foods. A must see for an hour or two. Keep valuables well secreted and hold kids hands, but do visit and try some of the Serranos, the Smoothies and the Quesos. This is part of the fabric of the city so weave your way through the aisles and savour the gastronomic and social delights.

Amazing kaleidoscope of colors, smells, and tastes awaits. This is a terrific place to get food or candy or fruit smoothies but really you should go just to see all the arrangements of meat, vegetables, spices and so on. The vendors work hard to make their stalls as eye appealing as possible and are often out there passing out samples too. It is worth an hour or more wandering through, snacking and taking pictures.

Love this place!... specially if you are a foodie like me!. The aromas, the sounds, the people... what an amazing place to taste and learn part of the Spanish culture. If you go to Barcelona... don´t miss it!... You´ll love it!

I wish I had read about the rudeness of the traders before going there. The place is way too turisty, so traders don't feel the need to be respectful to clients (kindness would be too much to expect). Yes, it is colorful and full of variety, so you might want to have a look around, have a fresh fruit juice (good price at EUR 1,50) and then leave. Many places have overpriced food, awful service and turist traps (such as surprises in the bill). Particularly avoid Bar Central, where I was told by the bartender to leave my seat after having waited more than 40 minutes for it, simply because she wanted other people to sit there and they had just arrived at that moment! When questioned she yelled “This is my place so I can do what I want”. Look at her picture menacing us with a nife to leave.... It's absurdly unbelievable that this place still has clientes! It is probably solely due to pure lack of information by the tourists.

Great market and amazing food. This market is amazing, full of color, great seafood, excellent places to eat. We went to El Quim de la Boqueria and had their specialty: Squid and Eggs. It was excellent!, we had it with a beer and a cava.

A must on a trip to Barcelona. On a short stay in Barcelona my fiancée and I decided to visit Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria which is situated along the La Rambla.It was an amazing place to visit with its fish, chocolate/sweet, meat, spices and fruit stalls and also a few small restaurants.The presentation of them all were an amazing sight and left your mouth watering for food and you could spent a fortune easily.It’s very busy but well worth going to on a visit to Barcelona.
Market along La Rambla that sells delicious food. My hotel was near this market so I went there to buy food almost everyday. The fruit juice is really the best ever.
Overpriced. i don't know what's all that buzz around La Bouqeria. It's a market, nothing special or exotic, selling salad, carrots, fish, etc - you can see this at home.

One of the great food markets of the world. One of the great food markets of the world. Make sure you get a fresh juice from one of the juice stands. Great meats, fish, candies, spices and a great bakery in the center of the market. One of the largest selections of fish I've seen in any market. Some of the most colorful fresh fruits and vegetables anywhere.

Perfect place to stop and take in the sights and smells of Barcelona. La Boqueria is an amazing and authentic market (surprising given its location to the most popular tourist street in Barcelona) that boasts some of the freshest food and produce in the city. The entrance is right off La Rambla and has about 10 long rows of meat vendors, produce stands, fish mongers, and cheese carts. At the front, make a stop at Pintoxo which is a tapas bar. All the food is fresh from the market and some of the best in the city.

Amazing place to eat or photograph. Stalls of food and drink were everywhere. Full bodies of rabbits, chickens, and other small animals hung near the meat cabinets. There were fantastic fruit creations and smoothies as well for vegetarians. We thought it was such a beautiful place and photographers would delight at the numerous kodak moments. We spent a long time here wandering around the food stalls to see all that was offered! It's a cant miss stop right off Las Ramblas so easy to find with an intricate entryway!

Best "Farmer's Market" Ever. So you think you've seen good farmer's markets? Think again! This place had products you can't even imagine! If you love a good farmer's market, you'll go crazy for this place!

Dynamic, fresh, coloured, crowded and delicious. Lively market-place as Barcelona. Drink freshly squeezed fruit juices (kiwi-mango is my favorite), eat fresh and the most delicious calamari and shrimp at Bar Central (at the left end of the market). Be careful of your bag, purse, wallet, mobile phone, etc.
Worth a visit. Beautiful vibrant colourful market, with stalls selling fish, meats, chocolates etc. Fantastic colours, smells, atmosphere, etc snacks and bar inside too

If you go nowhere else in Barcelona.... You could eat all day every day from La Boqueria. Oh, and drink, too. We discovered Bar Sant Josep, a tiny place far right, about two rows back. Only about 6 stools, but the most charming people speaking almost perfect English. We had drinks, snacks, chocolate and churroz. And I stopped in for a brandy after my shopping trip! But getting back to the market. If it's edible, you can buy it here. From local ham (delicious)to all kinds of sweets, cakes, breads, fruit and veg, seafood, wine - have I left anything out. Pork, lamb, beef, chicken, offal, eggs, fruit salads and juices, oh, and there are toilets at the back (not easy to find in Barcelona). One day I'm going to come here for a fortnight and cook every day just from this market.

Bit of tourist trap. Have visited the market on many occasions before & its to get more touristy everytime. Lots of people walking round taking pictures & not really buying anything. The people working here & trying to make a living & i'm sure they would appreciate sales over pictures. Can highly recommend the juice bars, great value at only a euro

We just loved it here. So much fun, so much to see, so much to taste! We had bocatas every day we were there ( lovely baguettes with tasty Spanish ham and cheese, simple but delicious), fruit salad for our breakfasts and a sit down meal at Bar Central. MMMM, eggplant tortilla and pescadillos. Don't miss the fish mongers (amazing seafood), the fresh produce or the candy and nut sellers. Everything was amazing.

great market. I always love a good market to give me the flavor of the city. You can just visit or if you want to eat, some of the vendors serve meals. We were advised to go in the morning and it was teeming with fishmongers and vendors filling their stalls with fresh meats, game, candy, fruit and vegetables.

Awesome!. Wow! la boqueria is an amazing market where you can browse, buy and taste! From candy/chocolate, seafood, meat, veggies/fruits to wine. I even found produce from Puerto Rico which I don't ever find in the USA. Also, there are cooking classes offered at the Aula Boqueria at the end of the market. The classes are more of watch and taste. One observes the chef cook, takes notes on the recipe sheets offered before class and eat the food at the end. However, classes are only offered in Spanish, mainly locals attend this class.

Must visit if you love food!. We always visit the market when we come to Barcelona and the varieties of different foods still amazes me. This weekend there were masses of different mushrooms and the tender care that they were being laid out with was amazing. I then saw the 20 euros a kilo price label and realized why!! The prices do seem to be higher at the front of the market so if you are looking to buy head further back.I've been to other Spanish markets in Madrid, Valencia, Bilbao and Malaga and this is by far the largest with the widest amount of choice. It is probably also the most touristy though and this is probably reflected in the prices and the feeling that there are far few locals shopping in there than the other markets.We've sat at the bars and had breakfast and would recommend this as well.Overall it is a must visit if you like your food and the choice is unbelievable.

Overwhelming! Wow. Foodies will go crazy here. It is huge and the variety of food and drink is overwhelming. Just beware some vendors take offense to tourists photographing some of the more exotic items on display. You may see some offerings staring back at you...

A definite stop!. We stayed just a few blocks from this awesome market. Go in, buy a fresh squeezed fruit juice for 1 euro, and explore all this market has to offer! The stands offer everything from fresh meats, fishes, candies, to produce. It's sensory overload! Well worth a stop for an early evening snack or a different kind of lunch!
must visit. great place to have a quick bite... a wide variety of foods/fruits and fish available....

Crazy amounts of food. This place is huge and intimidating...and it is an active food market, so if you are not looking to buy food it may be a bit much. We were looking to buy food and cooked an amazing meal that night. Loved it!!!!

A large market with plenty of variety. We hadn't planned on visiting this market but stumbled upon it while walking in the Las Ramblas area. I'm glad we did because we loved it and enjoyed walking around. We marveled at the large and colorful displays of food. They have everything you can imagine from fresh fruits, vegetables, and seafood to chocolate and other desserts. We were hungry for a snack and freshly made smoothies hit the spot.

Lovely place. walking around the place and taking pictures of the fruits and vegetables over there is such a wonderful experience, but the sad thing about this market ,is that if you tend to buy anything from there, you're not allowed to pick anything that you want...it's the seller who chooses old items to fill your bag with! and they're kind of expensive compared to the regular supermarkets or the Carrefour that's adjacent to it
The most vibrant of markets.. Having been to Barcelona many times we still enjoy the colour and vibrancy of this fabulous market - a must see.

A feast for the senses. Where to start? Stunning food stalls, stunning food. The meats, fish, cheese fruit and veg all looked and smelt so tempting; the prices were not cheap, but the food was so good. Take a wander around and people watch - an exotic interlude in your journey along La Ramblas.

not for me. i wanted to get some fruit and popped in here to check it out.. way too large, noisy and smelly due to fish.. would not suggest it to those wh are turned off smelly fish and meat.. its just off las ramblas for those who would want to go.

Highlight of Our Visit. We ate at least 5 stalls. The food was great, from fruit drinks to shellfish to wild mushrooms to gazpacho to crepes. It was exciting and fun to walk around and see. The cinnamon is the best take home buy here. It smells more like Big Red than the stuff we get at home.

Colourful, wonderful. I dislike the amount of tourist going in but most of 'us' tended to stay near the entrance. So, walk freely to admire everything that is for sale.
I bought (vacuum) cheese and smoked fish, spices and seeds for the beans that go in the paella valenciana.

Try the seafood.. Went to Boqueria market for 3 consecutive days, it's very close to where we stayed at hesperia Ramblas. Bought form MAS the top end jamon (from extramdura & jabugo), its really a must try though a bit expensive. Try the fruit juices and bacalao crocketas from the inner stalls (cheaper) and try the razor clams, langostines, gambas and pulpos.

A must see, but not buy.... Its one of the touristic centers of Barcelona, and definitely a must visit. Its colorful and awesome, and WICKED expensive. If you MUST, and you want to the eat, go to the establishments in the back, as the locals do. When you first get to the Mercat, walk to the left and go all the way to the back and work yourself forward. WHY? Because all the tours, tourists and photographers tend to congregate in the front, making it impossible to maneuver. One STEAL inside the mercat, for sure is the zumo's (fresh juices). 2+ euro out in the regular commerce, Mercat sells the deliciously freshly squeezed addictive and refreshing concoctions for 1.5 euros. Now if you MUST shop, take the metro over to Mercat San Antoni - locals, locals, locals, and far cheaper goodies than Boqueria, and another people watching, more "real populos" feel to it.

MUST is you are a foodie. Great place to familiarize yourself with all of what Catalonia has to oofer, from seafood, to charcruterie, vegetables, eggs, sweets.... Whenever you get hungry go to the Bar grab a barstool and eat whatever they serve you!

Get there early for the best experience. This is absolutely a first class and fun place to go if you have even a moderate interest in food. My advice is go before 9:00 in the morning. It gets very busy later in the day, and it is harder to get around and you are a greater risk of having your pocket picked. I found the vendors more interested in talking before the crowds got to busy. Lunch at El Quim is definitly a good idea. He has a stall located fairly centrally in the market, and the food was great...albeit priced in line with what tourists will pay. Go with the lower priced dishes and forgo the more highly priced menu items. You'll have a great time.

Feast for the eyes. We loved visiting the market on our visit to Barcelona. The wide variety of colorful and unusual food on display was fascinating. It was very hot and crowded with lots of strong smells but we didn't mind. We purchased fruit for a snack. I consider this a must see. I would definitely return.

Boqueria market. Fantastic to see but beware the prices.......am convinced tourists were charged way more than locals!!! But the fresh juices are yummmm....just dont get them at first stall you see....shop around for prices!!

Boqueria Market. Boqueria Market, also known as San Zhuzep, is perhaps the oldest food markets in Europe. It was founded around 1200 AD.It is surprising just about anything, from a rich range and finishing with a huge number of visitors, most of which are not typical consumers, but rather come here to enjoy the great atmosphere and to capture on camera the beauty of the local stalls.Just think, every day the market goes up to 27 000 kinds of products. If you compare this market with European counterparts, the nearest worthy competitor will be only in Paris, even though prices are considerably higher.The market is open daily, except Sunday. Its doors are open from seven in the morning, but most sellers start their work after eight hours.Its convenient location (near the central streets of La Rambla) makes it extremely convenient to visit. It is perfect for breakfast, enjoy the taste of exotic juices, and taste the local variety of donuts (churros).Huge selection of various fruit platter will delight you with its low price and freshness.The market occupies an area of ​​about 1600 m ². Market building was built of steel and glass, decorated with mosaic elements.Often, the local products are packaged in such a way that the pass is almost impossible.You can also use the services of local eating houses, where you will cook almost anything that can be found on the market. This may be a fish and meat, and seafood. It all depends on your desire.Special pride of Spain is the jamon. If you prefer, you immediately it narezhut. Sliced ​​jamon is a whole show, usually, the seller receives from this particular pleasure.

Our number one attraction in Barcelona. Been to La Boqueria market on many occassions and alway eat at the "International Kiosk". Wonderfully prepared, fresh seafood and the tastiest fries anywhere - only a million calories a portion! The garlic sauce they put on the seafood is to die for.

Worth a visit. Even if you don't intend on buying anything, this market is worth a visit for the sights, smells, and wonderful colors that surround you. They have a variety of items that are sold, but my favorite was the fresh juices. They also have a range of things from chilies, to candy to meats.

What a great experience!. Just walking around this market is facinating. Make sure you don't miss the fish counters with all the live lobsters and crabs! Some fabulous, colourful photos to be taken. Enjoy!

A Street Market Above All Others. We have been to a number of street markets in Europe, but la Boqueria trumps them all. There is an amazing selection of fruits, vegetables, meat, fish, cheese, spices, baked goods, candy -- you name it, they probably have it and at a good price. The vendors all seem to compete with each other over who has the best looking displays. You can order cured Spanish jamon and watch as they cut each slice from the whole ham right in front of you. There are freshly made blended fruit juices available from several vendors for as little as €1.00 a glass and they'll be the best you'll have on your travels!

Amazing food market, so colourful. I have visited this market 3 times and would not go to Barcelona without going back! Awesome array and displays of colourful fruit & veg, also meat, hams, fish etc. Locals seem to go there for breakfast of coffee (or wine) and seafood! Stall holders are generally very rude and don't like the tourists, but we found this enhanced the atmosphere. Great pastries from the bread stall, far better and cheaper than breakfast from our hotel. We sat and had coffee from Dunking Donuts (DD) on the left hand corner by the entrance to the market (and our pastries, as the DD staff were so rude). There are just a couple of tables outside at the back of DD, from where we sat and people-watched. Most entertaining.

Paradise for your eyes and stomach. Must stop at La Rambla ‘cruise’. Very attractive, clean and organized bazaar. Some things are expensive but who care. Fruits, meat, salami, fish and sea food and etc. Sit and try some sea food at El Cochinillo Loco (most south line of Boqueria) – at lunch time expect to have que.

Must visit tourist attraction in Barcelona. Very colorful market with all variety of food. Fruit display is beautiful. Samll cafe and stalls provide you with snacks or full meal.Since it is located at the La Rambla, the price you pay reflected that you are paying the tourist price. Still, everytime I go to Barcelona, I will visit the place.

Such colourful fruit candies!. On holidays abroad, we always make a point of visiting the local market: it always is a great fun to look at whatever are there. La Boqueria Market was no exception: we were pleasantly surprised at the variety of colourful local(?) fruits, vegetables, fish, and FRUIT CANDIES. Also, we did not fail to notice the carefree and happy-looking faces of the locals enjoying themselves in the market. Not understanding a word of Spanish did not stop us having a delicious lunch at one of the many crowded food stalls in the market; we just gestured that we wanted the same things as the locals sitting next to us were having!Also, we bought a pack each of three kinds of fruit candies with irresistible colours and shapes, but when we were back at the hotel, we found to our great dismay that we left them behind us on the local bus!

Very cool experience. Eat here at a tapas stall with locals. Buy candy, fruit, fresh juices, nuts, pasteries, we bought a picknic lunch here to take to Monserrat. It's a great visit for tourists even when you are not cooking for yourself.

Amazing Market showcasing some of the best produce in Europe. Where do you start. It is overwhelming at first but take your time to ingest this market. The fruit smoothies are incredible. Every little alley way is jam packed with goodies. Fresh fuits, meats, fish and every other thing that moves is for sale. It is very hard to communicate at times as the markets are very noisy as traders are calling out all the time. Try to get there early in the morning as lunch time is insane. Fantastic photo shoot and the traders do not mind being photographed. A touch expensive Some of the produceis a touch expensive but there are plenty of stalls selling the same thing so do not be in a hurry to take a photo and get out. Lots of taste. La Bouqueria Market is a great place to shop if you are staying in an apartment in Barcelona for the duration of your stay. It is crowded on weekends so weekdays is preferable. A good overall picture of the way of life in European markets.So much better than visiting a supermarket. It is definitely a must visit place when in Barcelona. It is just off La Rambla.

Awesome Experience. We went on a cruisse in March of 2011, so we went to La Boqueria twice, (it's a Market)the first time though, was the bomb! all the sales people were on customs, adding a lot of color and imagination to our visit.We found everything there, from desserts, chocolate, candy, loly pops, big and small. fresh fruit, fresh vegetables, can goods, we were at atll surprised to find some Mexican grocery items at la Boqueria. fresh seafood, you can't go any fresher than la Boqueria, the shrimp, crab, were alive!All kinds of meats, rabbit, pork, beef, chicken, etc. Proccessed foods, like sausages, ham, etc. We never seen so much fruit, and fresh produce in one place, a delight for your eyes, nose and mouth! Some products from the other side of the world. You must stop here!a couple of hands full of restaurants, where you can have your glass of wine with your food, only in Europe! Spain rocks!Being at la Boqueria, was a great experience for us, we got to try so many things, so we went back, not disapointed at all!The place is usually packed, so watch your purses, wallets, etc. Las Ramblas is known for crime, pocket pickers, be aware of your surroundings. We did not have any problems! This is their official Webbsite: http://www.boqueria.info/

Shop, don't stare. Mercat de La Boqueira, o Sant Josep, not only is one of the oldest public markets in Europe, is considered too to one of the best in the world. Go and visit. Go early in the morning. Avoid the time when tourists jam the aisles and turn into a real nuisance. Be considerate; people work there and work hard so that you can marvel at all the amazingly array of fresh produce, all of the highest quality. My suggestion, as a Barcelona Tour Guide, is go with as purpose. Shop. Have breakfast or lunch in any of the several excellent bars you'll find inside. Forget about "Pinotxo", the one you see on your right as you the market from the Ramblas. The little and always cramped place has become so popular that now everything in the menu is over-priced and the service is terrible. Most importantly, visit this market ONLY if you don't have the time to visit others. Mercat de la Llibertat, in the barrio de Gracia, is another lovely and less known - and like Boqueria, Modernist period. Right next to it, outside thre premises, you have the bar La Pubilla. This is one place you cannot miss if you are looking for place to have a proper bite. The chef there manages to produce the most outstanding food for a bargain price!

Yummy. So, the fresh fruit juices are a must but definitely go towards the back as its less expensive and still just as yummy. We also ate at this shop in the back... not the restaurant but the shop enclosed by countertop bars. It was great seafood and the person who served us was wonderful. The razer clams delish!

Amazing market, the astetics of the stands are amazing. This market is amazing,Not bacause it's big (it's not) but because of the aesthetics of the stands.Even the egg stand was beutifull,There are some small restaurants inside which I regret I didn't try,It is not expensive, and you can actually buy fruit or freshly squeezed assortments of fruitsIt is not expensive.It is not bad smelling also they have fish and other sea-originating species.

Colorful food market just off Las Ramblas. Looking for fruits, nuts, cured hams, seafood, fresh meat or any assortment of food items you should visit La Bouqueria Market. It is located just off Las Ramblas. It was a nice stroll through the market and we purchased some wonderful tasting strawberries.

It is a food paradise.. In all my traveling I like to visit food markets. This Barcelona was one of the best but not the cleanest. Nevertheless, the variety is incredible. The most striking is that the Spaniards did not throw anything from the animal, meat, bones, feet, stomach, head and even the nose of the ox!

UTTERLY RUDE TRADERS. While this market is colorful and vibrant, the rudeness of the vendors is breathtaking. While some may put this down to being "just their way" and therefore part of the culture, my experience in Barcelona is anything but - most of the people are as courteous as in other cities. This is not a culural thing - stallholders here have an attitude that some vendors adopt when they get their custom is too easily (especially from tourists - they know the locals wouln't stand for it). This market is good for photographs and looks good in postcards but the reality of the experience is just not worth the bother. Again, like in a lot of places in Barcelona, keep a good watch on you wallet, purse or anything else that can be removed from your person.

The most tasty and colorful place!. If you go to Barcelona you have to visit La Boqueria! You can buy fresh fruits or refreshing juices for only 1-2 euros! And specially in a hot day, La Boqueria is the place to be!!!
Worth a go. If you were on a longer stay or living in Barcelona, the value here is great. Nut regardless it's worth a walk through and stomping for drinks and tapas (awesome).

Beautiful!. I loved this market! I am a huge market fan anyhow and consider them one of the must do things while traveling to get a view at the local produce, their flavours, the people... and La Bouqueria was just perfection. The fresh fruit smoothies (1,5 €) are delicious, also the little fruit packages (1 - 2 €) which we bought for a light lunch. I also tried some delicious chocolate here, but even more importantly, here is where I found the famous creme catalana, one of Barcelona's very well known deserts. Had it served to me at a tiny bar in the back of the market at 10 am, while people next to me where eating seafood and already starting to have some wine - a true blend with the locals. Loved it!
Worth a stop. Great stopThe ultimate open marketYou should not miss on your trip to Barcelona

More like a shopping center than a true market. We visited a lot of market days in Europe and we love them - set for a day and then gone. This is different. More like an ongoing, outdoor shopping center with the same stands each day. Yes, there's a big selection but also a lot of redundancy in fruit, meat and veggies. The mushroom, candy and seafood offerings are unique and interesting.

A feast for the senses. This large market near La Rambla was one of my favorite Barcelona attractions. A place to enjoy all kinds of fresh vegetables, fruits, fish, cheese, candies, nuts ...etc at cheap prices which provides a nice change from eating at restaurants.Best to avoid during weekends when it becomes very crowded and overwhelming. The sight of all kinds of animal parts and fish smell can be hard to handle for some people. Nevertheless, it is a must if only to enjoy the wide array of fresh cold fruit cocktails!
Mercat for the senses!!. It's a must...be ready to exchange good talks with the merchands and clients, walk around, eat well and buy fresh food!!

Amazing place. Love this market. Prices are cheaper in the back than entrance. El quim is great for food. Beware of old women and their shopping carts. Packed with people. The best fresh fruit and candy. Love it here.

very nice but very touristic. like many others' we also liked this market bcause of its colorful sights and "authentic feeling". on the other hand, in contrast to many other markets in europe, this one seemed to be directed to tourists and not so much for the local populatin. this is the reason why it is only have "authentic feeling" and not realy authenticity.

Delicious fresh fruit. So amazing. I had the best peach of my life, ever (though I paid almost $2 for it). There were cheaper ones, but I could smell these from about 2 stalls away. The fruit juice was delicoius. You can't miss this if you're in Barcelona.

A must see!. If you go to Barcelona this is one thing you cannot miss! It's an amazing market and it puts any other markets to shame...I went mid afternoon and had lunch at their seafood section of the market. You sit ar the bar tables or at the counter and watch them cook the freshest fish ever. What a treat! It's hard to accept any other seafood after you've eaten here...need I say more?

A feast for your eyes. You don't know where to look first, if you're hungry, you soon won't be. Try a taster from one of the stalls where you can sit and enjoy whats cooking at that moment. We bought delicious salmon steaks, new potatoes, asparagus & doughnut peaches to take back to our apartment for our evening meal. This market can be a squeeze to enter and exit, you can see persons from every side of the globe here, its great. I agree with other reviewers, this market should be on your list of places to visit when coming to Barcelona. (A little precaution, take care of your bags & wallets here).

a world of colors, smells and tastes. The Mercat San Josep de la Boqueria, or simply La Boqueria is the main market in Barcelona. From its entry, made ​​in cast iron art nouveau stained glass, go into a world of colors, smells and tastes - La Boqueria is one of the incredible places in Las Ramblas. The product range is huge, meat, poultry, fish and seafood, nuts, hazelnuts and fruit in the world, ham and cheese, teas, herbs and spices, the list is almost endless. There you will find the famous Spanish nougat, and the saffron, the world's most expensive spice.But for us, mortals, a simple fruit salad, a refreshing fruit juice or exotic fruit for a few euros, will be very rewarding. Usually the the stands at the background are cheaper. You can also enjoy some appetizers, tapas and sparkling wines in the minirestaurantes.

Vibrant, bustling, colourful and fresh!. A feast for the eyes and nose as well as our bellies!Just off Las Ramblas, Mercat de la Boqueria is the touristy food market but that is n0t a bad thing. The food is laid out fantastically, piled high in decorative patterns on each stall. You walk into the smell of fresh fruit at the entrance where you can buy freshly prepared fruit salads and smoothies on ice. Further in there is the meat section with lots of cured hams and fresh meat as well as ready to cook burgers and sausages to take home. There is also a cheese section with a wide variety of spanish cheeses and also stalls selling spices by the sack load, some with artisan chocolates and some with mounds and mounds of sweets! here is something for everyone with organic and vegetarian stalls too.All this is centered by the fresh fish counters, all on ice with live shellfish, pre prepared tuna steaks, sardines and everything else in between!The market has several tapas bars too where you can sit at the bar with some plates and a glass of barcelonian cava.Many local restarunts cook solely with ingrediants from the market and ltho its a tourist place it is full of locals too which is a good sign. They also have a cookery school here - check the website for more info.

#1 place to stop everyday. In our 7-day trip to Barcelona, this was the place we went everyday.Whether it's for fresh fruit, fresh fish or just drinking a fruit-juice (~1 EUR), the Boqueria has everything you could possibly need in a market.Colourful, full of amazing aromas and friendly people (a lot of people come here to eat, as there are a number of places that cook fresh fish there) - but not the cheapest, as it's already a tourist attraction.

Wonderful experience. Walking into this place and you'll be overwhelmed by a huge selection of fruit juices and definitely have a few. My husband and I had 2 each almost everyday while we were in Barcelona. This is a huge market places with a huge selection of food, fruits and seafood. We also manage to get ourslves a spot at the Tapas bar and enjoyed some good and yummy seafood. This place is definitely a must-do activity in Barcelona, don't miss it.

really aesthetical offer. I enjoyed very much the way how they placed the products. And I was also amazed at the range of products, in Hungary we don't have such an incredible choice. I found lots of new. The fresh fruit drinks, sliced fruits (pineapple, melons, mixes) were prepared to be ready to eat. They have toilet, many restaurant, vegetarian food to take away, etc. So it worths the visit. And so close to the tourist attractions.

We Went Back Over and Over!!. This is such a fun place, and it is easily accessible, right off Las Ramblas. Sure, markets similar to this exist in the U.S., but I have never seen the variety - including tripe and sheep heads with eyeballs! It is packed in there, so watch your belongings. You will get jostled.We loved the variety and prices of the fresh fruit and went back several times just for that.

Simply Superb!. This is a must visit on any Barcelona trip. I always spend time here on every visit to Barcelona and normally just have the best tapas around in this nice place. Words aren't enough to describe the beautiful colours the fruits and vegetables display, nor the variety of things at offer. What are you still doing here? Go ahead and pay a visit :)

Vibrant and colourful. When you are strolling along the Ramblas be sure to call in on this market. As we stepped inside we immediately noticed the fresh scents and deep colours of the fruit and vegetables - and the sheer size of them compared with what we usually buy in the supermarket at home! Further inside, in separate sections, are stalls selling fresh (still moving!) seafood, meats, cheeses, chocolate, sweets and spices. We visited twice: lunchtime and late afternoon the following day. Both times the market was bustling with tourists and locals. We sampled strawberry juice ( 1 euro) and a packed fruit salad (2 euros) and both tasted just as fresh as they looked.This is soooo worth a visit - it doesn't cost anything to enter and look around, and it's an easy detour when you visit the Ramblas!
Plenty of fresh products. Have a real fruit not from Tesco,macadamia nuts Love it!

Not Worth The Visit. We were in and out in 5 mins. I cannot for the life of me understand how this tiny market causes so much interest. We were walking along La Rambla and thought ok let's check it out. It's a small market with about 25 food stalls, yes with the fruits and the tapas but further in are the fish and meat stalls, how can people find this thrilling?

Excellent market buzzing with activity.. The market is located in the middle of Las Ramblas. It is buzzing with activity. Full of locals jostling for their groceries and tourists snapping all the vibrant foods on offer.The fruit is out of this world. Large and vibrant fruits, stalls full of nuts and spices and sweets. They have lovely fruit salad bowls for a couple of euros and yummy fresh fruit drinks. Theirs a large meat and fish section which certainly opens your eyes with sheeps heads and live seafood available! The sights and smells are lovely. Its a very busy market so just keep an eye on your cash etc. Definitely a must see free attraction.

Enjoy the little bars. There are many markets in Barcelona, but the Mercat Sant Josep, or La Boqueria as it's known locally, is by far the most known, and for good reason. In here, you’ll find a sea of colorful stalls, so even if you don’t plan on buying anything, it’s still a great place to go, although I recommend you take your time and enjoy the little bars. If you plan on buying anything else, take the time to check the prices at the other stalls, as they may vary a bit.

The best market I've been so far!. La Boqueria is the best market that I've been so far. They have such an amazing offer of seafood, that we were going there with my husband just to see such spicies that we've never seen before! You can also eat some of the stuff in this place, as they are making it on the market fresh and tasty. You'll find loads of fresh fruits and vagetables. I recommend fress fruit juices they are amzing (different tastes - watermalon, mango ets) really tasty. You can also find there jamon serrano, iberico, and all other spanish meats, and cheeses.

An amazing food market!. If you're a bit of a foodie and appreciate great ingredients then you'll LOVE this place... everything is FRESH - you'll see snails, crabs, mussels and oysters still moving with life... You can get 100% natural yummy fresh juice mixes for just a euro and bites to eat for around 5euro. You can find great chocolate, spices, meats, cheeses... everything! And if you have time to stay for lunch, you can find some excellent fish restaurants hidden at the back of the market. Def worth a visit :)

a must.. The place is so gorgeous and coloured and lively I could see it again and again and enjoy it every time as the first time. Do keep in mind that this is not only a market to come and buy, but also to enjoy the pleasure of wandering around. Everything is just so colorful and delicious looking.I always buy freshly squeezed and concocted fruit juices which are amazing and so cheap! Breakfast every morning here (the bread feels like it’s out of the oven straight into our mouths) is a must. La Boqueria’s best feature may be its huge fresh Seafood Section. However, other food items are also available. For example: many kiosks sell typical Catalan and Spanish foods, including famous Iberian hams.This is one of my favourite places in Barcelona. If you go to Barcelona and want to feel and taste the local culture, you have to go here(www.perfyi.wordpress.com)

Food, atmosphere, activity and local flavor...what more could you want?. Loved this market. Am a fan of local farmers' markets anyway, but this place has so much character, not to mention an amazing selection of what's local and fresh, that it's worth a visit even if you're not doing your grocery shopping. With the added attraction of stands that serve prepared food as well as beer and wine, this is your meal and entertainment all in one. Don't just pass through the front near Ramblas, if you wander further back, you find better prices and more local flavor. Also, after finding fresh produce missing from many restaurant menus, this was paradise!

Busy place, great for some tapas. The Mercat de la Boqueria is not to be missed when you are visiting Barcelona. It is very interesting to walk around the market and just have good look at all the different kinds of food that are on display. Here you will find everything from exotic fruits to seafood and meets and of course local specialties like jamon serrano and cheeses in all variations. And if that made you hungry you can try some of best tapas right there! Enjoy!

Avoid the Pinotxo Bar...... The market is a must for visitors: Full of atmosphere and a magnificant display of local food. But we do suggest you avoid the Pinotxo Bar ( going through the main entrance, at the right side). Juan is the owner, and a legendary figure in Barcelona. The food is good, but the problem is he charges exorbitant prices! We ordered prawns (or gambas) and had to pay 17 Euros for 4 medium-sized prawns. The same story with the calamares...........People sitting next to us were shocked to see the bill, and they queried Juan. He simply ignored themBe aware: The price board is hidden high up the ceiling behind bottles of wine. These are not the prices of a full meal, but of a small portion (tapas)

Magic Market!!. I've never seen a market like "Sant Josep de la Boqueria".All that products, such as fruits, vegetables, fish, meats... the colors, the tastings, the smells...a experience that i'll never forget!!

Typical Spanish tourist market. Typical Spanish tourist market with plenty food tobe offered in front and flooded with the tourists coming down the Ramblas. You buy food from the stand at bit higher price than in non-tourist markets but the atmosphere is still nice. In the back you see the localsbuing fish, tourists do not do that.

Worst restaurant in Barcelona is in la Boqueria Market. We went to this restaurant called La Gardunya behind the market. The olive bowl they gave us as an appetizer had an eaten olive with a seed in the bowl! A small basket of bread was placed on the table we thought it was part of the meal but each bun was charged one Euro. The paellas are expensive and look More like a soup than a solid dish. The sangria Was like dark pink water with no taste at all.The service was terrible we hardly ate and we ended up with a 75 euros Bill ! Please stay away from this place there are so many Nice places to eat in Barcelona. This was the worst culinary experience we had There!

loved the market. this place is humming. the fruit and veges is far larger and better than pikes market in seattle.there was a great man making crepes on the right as you go in, and he was making some incredible munchies. fun just to have a drink and a tapa, and so many places to chose.

Don't miss this amazing market in the heart of La Ramblas!. Definitely worth a visit...large number of stalls selling all sorts of fresh produce...we got a container of freshly prepared fruit for 1 euro@ as daytime snack....it is home to the legendary Pinotxo eatery, serving all sorts of house specials.

Amazing mediterran atmosphere. The atmosphere was quite amazing, especially if you go there to buy fresh breakfast. They have variety of fresh fruits (even exotic like papaya,mangos ...etc) vegetables, plenty of fish etc... Was aboslutely satisfied.

Great food, very expensive beer!!. We ate at one of the restaurants at the Mercat de la Boqueria.We had a paellia which was great in quallity and at the price of 14 euros, big enough for 2 persons.What we didn't like at all, is the fact that they didn't give us a catalogue for drinks and we paid 14 euros for 2 glasses of draft beer!!!!!!!If we had known it , we would have never ordered them!!

Do not miss having some tapas at the market on Saturday morning. If you go to the Pinotxo stand in the market you'll have a panorama even before the food starts. It's so picturesque! They serve "fork breakfasts", meaning you end up having peas with "butifarra" at 11 a.m. Very recommendable! Pinotxo and Universal

BOQUERIA NICE BUT NOT GREAT.. Nice market and all but poor value for money in the restaurant.Just buy some Jamon iberico inside the market and bobs you uncle. Maybe I caught this place at the wrong time of day, busy, poor service and not great value.The food is very good.

Outstanding Food market. This market was outstanding. Nothing like it that I have ever seen. The whole center area is all sorts of fish and seafood. The fruits and vegetables are amazingly fresh. There is so much to see and purchase if you are staying in an apartment. People are actually shopping here so it gets crowded with the tourists and the locals so be prepared.

Amazing fresh fish - lively, colourful place to eat. There are a few place selling seafood and fish meals in the market. The place we went to was on the edge of the market, selling varous fish and seafood, all beautifully displayed, and cooked while you watched. We had the fish and seafood platter for 39 euros and really thought it was great. The place was not open in the evenings - it closed at about 5pm, so no good for an evening meal. People were queuing for tables on the Saturday when we were there.

Best market in Spain. I wouldn't categorize the Mercat de la Boqueria as a restaurant. Instead, it is a sensory experience that I'd recommend for any visitor to Barcelona. We snacked here, stopping to inspect and explore all of the items for sale at this indoor market just off of the Ramblas. Visitors will find full-fledged meals (sandwiches, tapas, homemade pasta), but also fresh fruit juices, bites of ham/meat, candy, and all of the produce and fish needed to produce a gourmet meal.

Love it!. Breakfast here is a must for me on every visit to BCN. I could sit here and watch the world go by all day!Great choice of food, a tad expensive for a market restaurant, but as it is a very touristy market, it is understandable.Will be back again next September!

Atmosphere different food good but questionable value.. Read a lot about this place and did enjoy it given its unique atmosphere. The value was not great, the food is though and this makes up for it. Come here early morning also as the live market located next to this restaurant is a must for tourists, especiallly if you want good Jamon (ham) iberica.

The Best Market in Europe. The Boqueria is the best market that I have been to in Europe. First---it is a very large market with vendors selling the most incredible looking seafood,meat,and produce that I have seen in any market. Local candies and sweets were also plentiful and so reasonably priced. Tapas eateries are in abundance as well and you can get a quite good meal for a very reasonable 10 euros! The Boqueria is colorful,fun,and very inexpensive. The natural fruit juices ----papaya,mango,coconut are wonderfu and costs only 1 euro!

Wonderful market!. Best outdoor, covered, market just off of Las Ramblas. This place is filled with life and energy. You can buy a fruit, nuts, jamon (ham), fresh fish, and many countless food items. In addition, there are a few little restaurants where you can buy some fantastic food. My husband bought chorizo with potatoes. He states that it was the best food ever. Head to this market for breakfast, lunch, to sightsee, or for a simple snack.
