FASCINATING - THE FOOD IS LIKE WORKS OF ART. this is just off the la rambla.it is a food market. the way the stall holders arrange the fruit and sweets and meat is just unbelievable.it is amazing - all the different colours of the various fruit and sweets.would recommend. photographers would love this place.should be in the top 5 things to see in barcelona

A must for anyone going to Barcelona. This Mercat (which is just off La Ramblas so it's very easy to get to) is wonderful experience. I've heard that it's Europe's largest outdoor market so it is filled with anything and everything you could want. Fish, meat, fruit, drinks, sweets, chocolate...... Even if you aren't looking to buy, it's worth a little nosy around just for yhe atmosphere.

Highlight of Las Ramblas. This was one of the highlights of Las Ramblas. The displays with all the colors are great photo ops. It was very hot and crowded when we were there in July. We had a fresh fruit drink that was very refreshing..

Unmissable. As good a regional food market as you will find anywhere. Not so big that it loses the personal feel but bustling with as many local shoppers as tourists. Interlaced with excellent little snack and booze bars where you can sample a wide selection of dry meats cheeses fish and all kinds of tapas and other delights. Pity you can't fill as many bags as you can carry and take them home on the plane.
Lively market but many stands closed in August. Didn't eat at a restaurant - just had a bocadillo (panino) and a fresh fruit juice.

The sights, the smells, wonderful. This was one of the highlights of out Barcelona trip. The market is filled with many locals and tourist. The fresh food colors are fantastic. We tried the fresh juice bar, so good. I had the blackberry juice, wonderful. My husband had the strawberry-kiwi, and he loved it. The market has everything you can imigine to eat and drink. This is a once in a lifetime sight. Please go to the Boqueria in Barcelona.

A great view of local culture and cuisine - colors, flavors, and smells. We found la Boqueria in the middle of our walk down Las Ramblas. It is a covered open market area with vendors offering all types of food and drink.It was a great way to see, taste. and smell the foods of local area.

Superfun, yummy and inexpensive. This isn't actually a restaurant -- it's a market. We went each day between 8-9am and picked up both breakfast and lunch for later. There are great bowls of mixed fruit, fresh squeezed juices, and baked goods for breakfast. For lunch we picked up baguette sandwiches for only 2.50Euro each (at nearby cafes they're 5+Euro). Walking around the Mercat is a tourist experience by itself -- we loved seeing the seafood vendors set up their shops. It's a fun quick morning visit.

Food on the go for tourists and locals alike. Slink past the entrance and bear right to pick up a mouthwatering Macedonia (fruit salad) and a day-glo fresh smoothie before heading to the centre circle 'Fish Island' for a big portion of cod fritters. Make your way out the back and past the loading vans to a quiet little square to enjoy your feast. The whole adventure comes in at less than six euros per person and you can laugh in the face of five-a-day!
Tons of Fun. A must do in Barcelona. Pixtinto is a must as well as the entire market. try the pastries at the counter...great

Amazing - highlight of any trip to Barcelona. From Jamon Iberico sliced off the leg in front of you to ripe, full figs to cones of fried cod balls to caramelized pecan nuts to a myriad of other outstanding foods, this place is a foodie dream. In August (when we went) it was extremely busy, with most stalls at the front catering to tourists wanting packages of sliced fruit and freshly squeezed juices. The juices are great though - try the coconut and mango! Open 8am-8pm, Mercat de la Boqueria is a great place to get your picnic ingredients. Every day for 8 days myself and my husband bought a big loaf of baker's bread, 100g of jamon serrano, 2 peaches and 6 figs for less than £10, which set us up for breakfast and lunch. The only negative was that some stalls were closed for the 'vacaciones' - native Barcelonians tend to escape the city in August due to the heat! However, there were a couple of tapas bars still going in the market, so you can still try authentic Catalan cuisine in a foodie setting in the summer.

Local life and gastronomy with all its color and variety. Visiting Boqueria was a fun experience. It was in our last day in Barcelona although we have passed many times for the market’s main entrance.The market stands are beautiful, full of color and passion. The sellers really want to call visitors’ attention and so they commit themselves to make art with their products and stands. It’s a nice place to visit. Here in Oporto we have a similar place, Bolhão, also worth a visit.We didn’t eat anything at Boqueria as we were full from our breakfasts at H10 Universitat hotel However we drank fruit juices. Its stands are one of the most colorful and appealing.I’m sure I would be very pleased if I ate there. Tapas’ spots were crowed with locals and tourists and the food seemed tasty.Probably next time

Local life at its best. Visiting Boqueria was a fun experience. It was in our last day in Barcelona although we have passed many times for the market’s main entrance.The market stands are beautiful, full of color and passion. The sellers really want to call visitors’ attention and so they commit themselves to make art with their products and stands. It’s a nice place to visit. Here in Oporto we have a similar place, Bolhão, also worth a visit.We didn’t eat anything at Boqueria as we were full from our breakfasts at H10 Universitat hotel However we drank fruit juices. Its stands are one of the most colorful and appealing.I’m sure I would be very pleased if I ate there. Tapas’ spots were crowed with locals and tourists and the food seemed tasty.Probably next time.

Amazing and Cheap!. Fruit, vegetables, juices, salads and jelly beans…everything with an excellent appearance and with nice prices.For me this is one of the main Barcelona attractions and a great spot to have breakfast, a snack or even have lunch.

A colourful marketplace. Not a restaurant but a marketplace that you can find everything! Fresh fruits, fish, ham (jamon), chocolates etc. We had beers and tapas in the Bar Boqueria (check pics) that were simply great and inexpensive. Worth a visit for the atmosphere and tasty "snacks" or proper lunch.
One of a kind Market. Great food, great atmosphere a snack eaters heaven. A few more places to sit down would be nice

Take care. This is a market with several small, basic, but nice corners to eat. But this market has become a major attraction for tourists and that is why you should take very much care. Many tourists like to buy some fresh cut fruit and some fresh juice. But the shops in the front of the market often ask twice as much as the one frequented by locals further down.
Fun place to visit, very colorful. Great & beautiful market. Very colorful & fresh foods. A few small places to eat., but very crowded. Worth a look see even if you don't eat or buy.

The atmosphere says it all. St Josephs market (or La Bouqeria) right off the strip of La Rambla is always packed with locals and tourists. The smells of meat, cheese, fish and fruit makes you really believe you are in a market of style. And you are - big time! My biggest regreat is that we lived in a hotelroom and not an apartment as I would have loved to be able to buy alot of special goods.Our favourite was the fruitshakes that are sold at almost every fruitvendor stand. For 1,50 Euro you get a cup of your favorite fruits mixed. My personal favorite is the fresa/coco (strawberry/coconut). The only downside to this is that the vendors are very often stressed and therefor seem a bit tired and cranky.

Prices are not cheap. It is a tourist oriented market. Keep in mind that variety and prices on most products (cheeses, jamons, olive oil, etc ) in El Corte Ingles are better. Tapas in one of the market's restorantes were good.

Loved Pintxos and the whole market. We ate breakfast twice at La Boqueria, both times at Pintxos. We came back the second time especially for the xixos, the sugared donuts, which are to die for...though calorie laden! The first day we had tortilla/omelet with spinach which was also delicious. We meant to go back to eat at El Quim but ran out of time. Wandering around the market is a delight -- so many wonderful things to see, smell and eat!

Great market on La Rambla. I visited here several times while in Barcelona, and loved it. It's got a great mix of sights and smells (especially when walking through the fresh seafood part, haha). Don't miss the Pinotxo Bar near the entrance with Juan, the smilingly thumbs-up owner and the fresh fruit juices.

Go here if you are going to be out all day!. Stop here first if you will be out all day at a park or sightseeing. You will find amazing food at great prices! Don't buy from the first stalls, go further in for great quality and price! It is a bazaar of stalls with all sorts of assortments of food!

Not a restaurant, but a marketplace. This is a good place to buy fruit, bread, sandwiches, etc. A few stands also make breakfasts. I had eggs with potatoes and ham -- deliciously made. Sandwiches can be had for 2-3 Euro -- stuff a pair into your day pack and then you can tour around with enough food to get you thru to the 9pm dinner time of Spain.

Pinotxo: great experience... twice!. We just came back from a trip to Barcelona and perhaps my most memorable experience was a Pinotxo. For those who aren't aware, it's a tapas bar in the Boqueria Market. I would guess that it fits about 15 people and there are usually a few small groups of people waiting. We were lucky enough to get seats the first time we came... we were greeted by the man himself who suggested we take the chick peas and the baby squids. The chick peas were excellent and had a "familiar" taste that was easy to enjoy. The baby squids, perfectly cooked, were served with beans. The flavour of the dish was good and it actually grows on you (well, me, at least). We were so impressed by the experience that we went back after 2 days. The place was very busy and were afraid we wouldn't get a seat. Mr. Pinotxo recognized us and informed us that a specific group of people were ending their meal soon and that the spot would be ours. This second time around, we also had the baby squid but we took the beef stew (they were out of chick peas). Both dishes were amazing once again. We then proceeded to ordering desert which was some kind of "flanc"-type dish made with cheese. He also included two extra pieces of desert, compliments of the house. ALL deserts were fabulous. It was a perfect end to a vacation in Barcelona.It's normal to be confused when you first get there, especially when you have to fight for a seat. We had no idea as to what they served and how much it cost. Even after our second visit, we didn't know much more. The idea is to talk it out.. even though not everyone is perfectly fluent in english, they are extremely helpful.This place is a MUST.

Its an open air food market full of brilliant colours. El Quim de la Boqueria, Pinotxo Bar and Bar Central are 3 bar-style restaurants at la Boqueria. We ate at Bar Central and it was just awesome! Pinotxo (at the entrance of la Boqueria) is probably the one with the history and the reputation but we didn't feel as if we could order in English over there. Bar Central is on the other side of the market and the lady running it could speak English. And did I already say that the food was great! :)

Nice for the eyes. After we booked our trip to Barcelona I looked for places to eat and I found that everybody recommends this market because one can find good food at good prices. We went there as soon as we arrived for lunch and bought a juice first (2.50 euro) and then waited to get a seat at a food bar situated at the back of the market. Since it was crowded and all the names were in catalan we just ordered two plates of baby octopus and a glass of sangria each. My husband got also bacalau (cod) fritters which came two on a plate. Sangria came from a big plastic container and the glass size was on the small size. The octopuss came only with a small piece of bread and a wedge of lemon and it was delicious. The cod fritters had pieces of cod and were great. The bill at the end was 47 euro and I can hardly call theis reasonable or cheap for a market. The market was very crowded and we had to watch our pockets.We bought two chocolate truffles (2 euro each, of normal size) which were nice visual but below average taste. I considered them a ripoff in the end. One of the mornings we got each a fruit salad that was nice and fresh for 2 or 2.50 euro.If you visit Barcelona you shoul definitly go to the Mercat de la Boqueria at least for the visual effect but don't expect to eat cheap as is suggested in reviews.
Eat at a kiosk in the Bocqueria.. The market is a must see, and you really get to experience it when you eat at one of the tapas bars inside the Bocqueria.

Visually stunning but a bit dissapointing for actual price and quality. I would recommend that you go to the Boqueria market meerly from a visual perspectic. The displays of fruit and sweets are bright and colourful and the fish market is amusing. However, this is the place where I felt most at risk in Barcelona, it is a very tight space and you can feel claustrophobic and at risk of pickpockets. We did purchase some of the fruits annd sweets and found that the fruit wasn't as tasty as it looked and the sweets (pick and mix) were very highly priced. A small bag can cost about 17 euros!! I also thought that there wasn't as large a range of stalls as I would have hoped for. There was alot of the same stalls repeated and no bread or pastry stalls. The best value item was the fruit juices at 1 euro.

Outstanding Tapas at El Quim De La Boqueria and Pinotxo Bar !. The best culinary experience to be found in La Rambla is Mercat de La Boqueria. The lively atmosphere and the fresh fruits, dried fruits , fruit juices, sandwiches, nuts , cheese, seafood , meat ( fresh and cured ) , bread and pastries displayed in this market are breathtaking. I had read a lot and seen a lot of the Mercat in travel programmes prior to the trip and was worried that I had my expectations set too high. I am happy to report that it exceeded my expectations! The Mercat despite its tourist crowd ( the prices are not rock bottom) is still frequented by locals and is still retains its Spanish vibe.Pinotxo BarHence when you sit for your breakfast at Pinotxo Bar ( the first bar to your right at the entrance of the Mercat ) for example, you will be brushing shoulders with the locals who are having a quick coffee with Spanish pastries or sausages before rushing off to work. You will also meet Mr Pinotxo who beside making very good coffee is an institution himself. He was very friendly and this was apparent although he did not speak much English . The food was simply heaven.El Quim De La BoqueriaThe other unforgettable meal we had in the Mercat was at El Quim De La Boqueria. After a tiring morning of sight seeing, we went there to look for lunch. We decided to try another tapas bar although Pinotxo was open. We discovered El Quim nestled amongst the meat stalls in the middle of the Mercat. The long queue of locals waiting patiently for a bar stool convinced us to try.We tried dishes which sounded impossible, like baby squids grilled in their ink and some flaked salted fish served on soft scrambled eggs on the suggestion of a new found friend, he himself a restaurant owner from out of town. Everything was fresh and scrumptious. Hardly surprising as the cooks just stepped next door to get the fish , meat and vegetable whenever they ran out!We also had our breakfast at El Quim on our last day in Barcelona which evolved from coffee with churros to a full blown meal as we could not resist the fresh produce !Next door, there is an ice cream stall that sold scrumptious gelatos!Definitely a must for foodies and aspiring cooks! Please see more photos and information on the Mercat de la Boqueria and Barcelona at http:// sunlifeshinefree.blogspot.com/

Really fun and bustling market!. This market was very fun! We ate at Pinotxo Bar, which was delicious (just as everyone recommended). The market itself has everything from Iberian ham and seafood to exotic fruits and vegetables. One stall actually had truffles! This bustling market is just one of those experiences in Barcelona that are not to be missed!

A food marked, not a restaurant. I don't know why La Boqueria is listed as a restaurant, and not as an attraction. There are three or four small bars serving food there, but La Boqueria is mainly a food marked, with sections dedicated to fruit, sea food and fish, meat (beware of the offals sold there, if your stomach is weak look away as you risk seeing tongues, sheep heads, cow stomachs etc.), nuts and sweets. I loved the smoothies (but don't buy those by the entrance, those are cheaper but watery, walk two-three rows into the marked to buy real ones, with no water added) and fruit salads. In the afternoon the fruit stalls sell out the salads at reduced prices. Don't buy the chocolates, they are overpriced! The same chocolates, 50% cheaper, are sold all over the town at specialist shops or cafes. Don't visit at lunch time, the marked is horribly overcrowded then. Forget about getting a seat at one of the bars, unless you wait a long time.

Mercat de la Boqueria is an open food market not a restaurant, that you don't want to miss!. This place is great! While there are a several stalls to buy prepared food like a restaurant it is really an open market selling everything from fresh fruit to sheep heads. Yes, I said sheep heads, complete with eyeballs! It is totally amazing and should not be missed. You could spend a good 2 hours there just wandering around and still not see everything. I highly recommend it.

>What to do when it snows in Barcelona!!!!!. We just couldn't believe we picked 4 days to be in Barcelona and it snows! What to do - go to the market and have lunch at Pintoxa Bar - it is just so much better than all of the reviews I have read. Can´t wait to go back tomorrow!

A charming, bustling market. Full of colour and delightful foods.. Not a restaurant - this is an open market, just off of Las Ramblas.My boyfriend took me to Barcelona for a long weekend and Las Ramblas was one of our planned visits. I wasn't aware of the Mercat de la Boqueria beforehand, so it was a wonderful surprise to come across it whilst strolling along Las Ramblas.Above the entrance is a lovely stained glass arch and directly underneath are rows of stalls full of fruit and vegetables, meats, cheeses, chocolates, ice cream, seafood, sweets, nuts and oils. Also dotted about are a couple of coffee bars and tapas bars, which were very popular, especially with the locals.We bought some ice cream which was delicious and we also bought some melt in the mouth homemade chocolates from the stall that is the first one you see when you enter the market, under the stained glass arch.It's a wonderful, busy, colourful, bustling environment full of wonderful smells and tastes. Well worth checking out when your strolling along Las Ramblas.

Spain via all the senses. A brutal assault on all the senses. Fantastic. Sit at any one of the food stalls and order a still squirming mixed fish and shellfish grill. Just fantastic. Particularly the razor clams. Staff very friendly and waiting time minimal even though it is busy. The place is a heady mix of anything you want - fish, meats, cheeses, wines but thankfully no tat. If you come to Barcelona and don't come here you have missed out.

Open air market, with raw foods and some prepared foods. Open air market located on Las Ramblas. Mostly produce, bread, seafood and meat stands selling raw foods, but there are some stands with prepared foods. There are also a couple of bars! Wander around, get some bread, fruit, cheese and a drink for breakfast or lunch. Some of the bread stands also sell sandwiches. Some of the produce stands had blended fruit drinks that were DELICIOUS! Cheapest way to eat in Barcelona, and you get to rub elbows with the locals and soak up atmosphere to boot. One caution, there's VERY few seats and it is considered rude to walk and eat at the same time. So take your food to a bench on Las Ramblas, or stand and eat, using a barrel from the wine shop as a table, like we did.

Amazing fruit everywhere you look. Absolutely loved this market. When you go, check out the stalls selling fresh fruit. They'll make sure you get your 5 a day! Freshly pressed fruit juices everywhere you look, huge range of exotic fruit and great for photos. There's also a good place at the back of the market called Bar Boqueria with a good selection of freshly prepared tapas.
Best market in Europe. Here you find quality at it's best, from fresh fruit to fresh fish, aged cheese to cured ham, oasi of colours, fresh cooking.......if you're a food lover, you cannot miss it.

You cannot visit Barcelona and not go!!!. I have read another trip advisor person suggest that the Boqueria is actually just another market like any other. I can assure you ANYONE who knows ANYTHING about food would be transported with delight at the beautiful displays of the best and freshest food to be found in Europe. Seafood, much of it live, is unbeatable but there are many things to purchase to take home eg. dried mushrooms, saffron, vacumn packed charcuterie and chocolate truffles. There are many places to eat, counter style around the market where most of the staff speak some English, so don't be intimidated if your Catalan is not fluent, pull up a stool and get ordering. For keen photographers the place is fantastic.

Great place to check out... We went to Mercat de la boqueria hungry. Just to walk around and look at the different food they offer is overwhelming...But just a heads up...all bars that serves food closes at 5pm.We wish we knew beforehand but it was worth a visit.

We loved it!. We went to a small bar in the Boqueria on the recommendation of one of the guides we were on.The bar was called the Pinotxo which translates as Pinocchio, we are led to believe that it is run by Brothers of a michelin star chef who goes there when he is in Barcelona.Even at nine in the morning it was very busy and serving everything from tripe to doughnuts!A group of tourists had the tripe and loved it, we stuck to a glass of cava, coffee and a delicious custard doughnut all for 6 euros.We went back in the hope of lunch but no chance the bar was thronging..........what more can you sayYou will find this place just on the right as you enter the market

Your eyes will widen at the display and hurt from the colours .... Metro station to exit: LiceuWe wanted to go somewhere that is not a museum or is artistically inclined. We wanted somewhere with living objects where we can see moving things, hear and feel the surroundings, smell food, titillate our senses and yet carry a Barcelonian flavour. We found it in St. Josep La Boqueria.La Boqueria was a robust combustion of sounds and colours that lit up our morning. The colourful stalls were classified by categories - fruit, candies, chocolates, nuts, mushrooms, poultry, seafood etc. As you trudged through the scores of stalls, it was impossible not to be impressed by the selections displayed right before your eyes. In my country, no one sells chocolates or gummies in a marketplace and certainly not one that has as much mouthwatering effect as this. A word of warning - in places like these where everything turned out gorgeous on the camera, you might want to prepare an extra battery as more likely than not, you will definitely go trigger-happy! (It will be sad when you find out that you suddenly run out of lithium battery halfway through other places of interest)Since I come from Asia where euros are more than twice my own currency, things are expensive but it did not stop me from buying some chocolates (calculated by weight), trying the freshly squeezed juice to say I've been there and done that! For those who are planning the itinerary, Museu de l'erotica is just opposite the La Boqueria.

Favorite places in Barcelona. If you like the fun and unusual, two places not to miss in Barcelona, are La Boqueria and Zim. I live in Southern California where great farmer's markets are just around the corner, but we stumbled across the best market ever - La Bouqueria. The place looks like an incredible painting. There must have been every size, shape and color of mushrooms, meats of every kind, exotic fresh fruit (and fresh juices of every variety. I had the fresh-squeezed, iced cold kiwi-mango for about $1.50) and every kind of vegetable imaginable. If you're not into buying, go for the amazing photo ops. It's located at Placa Bouqueria, right off the Las Rumbas. Ask anyone for directions. Then, make sure to walk the medieval section (Barri Gotic) of Barcelona. No cars can be driven there as the streets are quite narrow. It's amazingly beautiful. Again, we stumbled into another great place - Zim. It's small, no tiny is a better word, the proprietor is so hospitable and the wines are fantastic - all small batch wines, carefully selected. Reasonable prices also.We couldn't resist bringing home a bottle by the name of Zorzal.

Mercat Boqueria - A must !. We had the pleasure of visiting this little gem in the midde of the Rambla. Boqueria has a lot to offer from fresh fishes to a variety of fruit juices and pastries for people on the go. I would recommend you to visit this place. Such a great location to take amazing pictures too !

Unbelievable!. If you want to see the "Farmer's Market Of All Farmer's Markets", this is the place. Fresh everything. All the fruits, vegitables,mushrooms, nuts, flowers, fish, shellfish, meats, even candies are at this place. And, there are several eateries in it that serve foods from this market. The market closes at 3:00pm so get there before lunch or better yet, for lunch. The Picasso Museum is just blocks away.

Boqueria... not for me thanks.. Boqueria, Boqueria, Boqueia,,, I was told a must see but nothing but a large market really. Nice, colourful, loud, nice building and all but no really my thing. I hit the Mercat rather hungrily but was a little dissapointed. Tapas were fine, however the whole place smelled rather strongly of fish. Maybe it was just an off day for me but genuinely too noisey and smelly for my liking.
See and taste - mmm. Nice fruit displays (take photos) and the prices are cheap (eat a fruit salad from EU 1 - EU 2.5). The fruits in Spain are very tasty.

disappointing. this market doesnt hold a candle to Farmers Market in Los Angeles. There are few eateries, mostly fruit and fish to buy. Its interesting to see and thats about it, not the cleanest place either.

The fishbar at the back's good!!!!. We had some pulpitos and navaja, worth every penny.
Another restaurant alone the left side to the entrance, is also good.
Some sites recommended different restaurants, we also tried them; but i personally think these 2 are the best
The price is comparable to any restaurant along La Ramblas with a set lunch, but you get fresh seafood!

Seafood at the bar restaurants are fine. It's just a market, nothing special about it.There are several restaurants inside the market, which we had an enjoyable meal, and would like to share.Some are famous for their tapas, as can be seen on some websites; but we went to the one at the back for some seafood.All were fresh and delicious.the price was comparable to a set lunch with 2 tapas and a paella on any restaurant along La Rambla, but the experience is very different - also, the seafood is definitely worth the money!

If you like food, this is a MUST. This is such a great food market. The food is beautiful and it's really neat to see it all. We ate at a vegetarian place in the back and it was so very good. We also bought fresh fruit and nuts for snacks.

Tasty organic vegatarian food and delicious fresh fruit drinks. Had a variety platter at the "Organic" stand at the back of the Mercat -- really good. The highlight was the strawberry/banana, strawberry/coconut and orange/papaya smoothies sold at numerous stands. The atmosphere was lively and the way each vendor's wares were displayed made me want to buy everything!

Not a restaurant, but a huge, awesome market.. One of the very coolest things to do in Barcelona, especially if you love food, is to come to this market, a feast for all of the senses. An astounding array of meats, fruits, cheeses, seafood, spices, nuts, wine, oil, and prepared foods to boot. Crazy amounts of color, bring your camera!We had a lunch at the Bar Pinxto, one of the little tapas bars inside the Market, that was highly recommended on many blogs and also on Mario Batali's "Spain show". Let me tell you, it was the best food we had in Barcelona, simply unbelievable! There's no menu, you just sit down and point to dishes that other people are eating or that you see behind the glass. But they are all amazing, so you can't go wrong. And you can wash it down with a three Euro glass of Cava. The lunch was kinda pricey, but sooooo worth it. Come to the Boqueria for your souvenir and gift shopping the day you leave. Best of all, stock up on bread, good spanish cheese like Manchego, and some unforgettable Jamon (a nice vendor, and there are about 40 jamon vendors here, you can sample different types to pick your favorite) so that you can make yourself one last awesome spanish meal on the plane ride home!

Comprehensive. How good is this place! Any type of food you could want (or in some cases not want) all available in the one place. We just wandered around and picked up bits and pieces for an extremely cheap mobile lunch. Great for the stomach but probably even better for the eyes!

Markety Fresh, and wonderful. We ate each morning during our stay at the market - what a wonderful way to start the day - great market atmosphere and the pick of the days best, fresh produce to choose from. Great fish for breakfast, Tapas favourites such as Padron peppers, wild mushrooms, Tortilla, Jamon, Tomato bread - wonderful. We chose a stall near the front of the market on the left hand side, but these were others offering a similar choiceWorth going to Barcelona just for the breakfasts...

Fun, great food, and cheap. Lunch at the boqueria is an experience that should not be missed. We grabbed a table at Pinocchio (or whatever that is in Spanish) and let them bring food for about an hour. Two bottles of Cava, everything from razor clams to garbanzos and chorizo, and even a cafe. Just don't look down, and avoid the butcher's window on the way to lunch.

Beware the ham and meat store at the Boqueria main entrance on the Right side. On my last day in Barcelona (second trip there in two years) I made the mistake of buying Jamon Serrano and some Lomo at the store that sits directly in the entrance of the Boqueria - on the right hand side as you walk in. The gentleman behind the counter gave me a couple of samples and then vacuum-packed the jamon and lomo I purchased. When I got back to New York City, I found that the jamon (about $40 worth) was so full of gristle and tendon that it was literally not chewable. It was also horribly over salted. I took the lomo to work a couple of days after I got back. The folks I shared it with thought it smelled funny. Now, I've been to Barcelona several times in the last few years. I know the Boqueria is a rip-off to purchase things like olive oil (you'll find the same bottles in El Cortes Ingels for almost half the price). But this was a real shock - to go through what I'm guessing was a bait and switch operation - from a key store in the Boqueria. I ended up throwing out the entire chunk of jamon. It was disgusting and literally inedible. Spain has been hit hard by the worldwide economic recession. But there is no excuse for selling junk like this. I wouldn't take the time to seek out travel boards to warn other customers unless this was truly a situation to avoid at all costs. The sad thing is that a few feet further into the Boqueria, you'll encounter Pinnochio's Bar (Pinoxtle). There you will find some of the best food you can get in the entire city.

Careful where you eat!. We ate at the fishbar at the back of the market and had the 30 euro mixed selection for 2 which is well worth every penny. On another morning we went to Bar Pinotxo as recommended on foodandwine.com (http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/where-to-go-next-in-barcelona). That was a very costly mistake! We had 2 coffees, one water, one plate of their speciality "beef cheek", and one plate of their speciality "baby octopus" and the bill was 25 euros - A COMPLETE RIP-OFF!!! The guy behind the counter should wear a balaclava!

Cool, Crowded Place. This is undeniably an exciting place and a foodie's dream, but understand that as a fixture just steps from Las Ramblas -- the premium tourist promenade in Barcelona -- this market is packed, more expensive than other markets, and the quality of what you purchase may in some instances not be what you would find for a cheaper price in a less touristy part of the city (Gracia, for example, has a few very good markets that are similar to La Boqueria and feel more like authentic Barcelona.) Having said that, you will find all kinds of cool photo ops in La Boqueria -- from the mountain of deep red tomatoes to the lamb's head with the eyes bulging out. It would be crazy to visit Barcelona and not stop by this market -- fight for a seat at one of the stands and order something adventurous. Wash it down with an Estrella, Barcelona's official beer. If you love the food, terrific. If you don't, your'e still on vacation.
A great market in las ramblas! fresh food, amazing fruts!. A great market in las ramblas! fresh food, amazing fruts!
Crowded and don't buy close to the entrance!. Very crowded and warm.Don't buy close to the entrance, very very expensive there. Good quality fruit though.

yeh it's ok but it's just a food market, people. I hope I don't sound negative. I do like it but if you're used to food markets (Brixton in London etc.) then it's just any old market, really. If you're not used to it then I guess it's quite nice to experience. I wouldn't make it the highlight of your trip but definitely go and see it anyway and it's very good for fresh fruit (that has already been sliced and prepared too). It's worth the money I think. One or two of the women on the stalls are a little aggressive if you accidentally bump into a stall but that's all part of the experience I guess.

I love the Boqueria!. A great place to visit and to get something to eat! The atmosphere is great, with so many different vendors selling fruits, vegetables, fish, meat, cheese, chocolate, bread, etc. Fruit was cheap and plentiful. We also ate at El Quim de la Boqueria, a counter towards the back. The food was excellent. I cannot even properly describe what a great experience the Boqueria was! We went everyday! Food and atmosphere are great! Our only regret was not getting to eat at Juan's Pinoxto bar (the day we went back to do so it was shut for a local holiday).

A Great Place to Spend a Morning. Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria was a great place to spend a morning or two. . . Recommended to go there in the morning at about 10 when all the stalls are open and arrive back at closing time to see the amount of stock left (very very little). . . All food products were displayed very well including fruit and chocolate. . . . If you have a local market in your home town prepare to be blown away. . .

Perfect for a quick breakfast!. If you want to feel like a local, stop in for breakfast at one of the counters. The food is fresh and good, and you can soak in some of the local culture. After breakfast check out the artistically arranged fruits, veggies, meats, etc. It's a great place to pick up some fixings for a picnic lunch in the park.

Pinotxo - don't order too quickly!. Arrived for breakfast and ordered too fast - gorgeous jamon sandwiches. However, we then spent 30 minutes drooling over what all the locals were eating; a lovely looking chick pea dish and some kind of meat in a tomato sauce. Looked fabuous. I wish we'd ordered drinks first!
The perfect spot for fresh and healthy food.. Try the salad fruit that you pick up right from the fresh market. A big bowl for only 2 or 3 euros.

A Must-See, but Not for a Long Visit. We went to La Boqueria, and we're glad we did...but we felt that it was overly recommended by guidebooks. It's cool, but after you walk down 3 or 4 aisles, they begin to look the same.There are fruit sellers, nut stands, seafood counters, bakeries, and a few stands I wish we had missed - including some sheep heads and things of that nature! Prices vary slightly between the first stands you see when you enter (more expensive) and when you are deeper into the middle of the market (cheaper). However, the price variation is minimal, perhaps 25 cents difference on a fruit salad.We had a "picnic" style lunch, grazing as we wandered down the aisles and snacking on fruits, fresh squeezed juices, nuts, cheese, bread...you'll have plenty to eat for only 10€. There are also cafes with bar-style seating if you'd like a hot dish prepared for you (more expensive) - some smelled great.We did not spend long here because every fruit stand looked the same as the next (and similar for every seafood stand...). Planning a "meal" here made it much more fun, giving you a chance to sample the different foods instead of just browsing.Just a tip: before you enter, put about 10 euro in coins in your pocket in order to easily access to pay for your snacks. La Boqueria is VERY crowded and if you are fiddling with a wallet or purse, you could easily be pickpocketed. Keep one hand in your pocket with the coins and the other hand on your bag.

Great place to buy fruits. We agree that La Boqueria is a must visit at least once to see all the variety and magnificent arrays of colours of fruits, vegies, nuts, spices, lollies, fish, meat, etc. However when we do actually buy something we got mixed experience, some taste as good as they looked, some were really dud.The strawberries and watermelons we bought were absolutely delicious, we must have come at the right season for those. The cherries were also pretty good but you do get more of a mix bag, some really good, some not so.Don't expect to get what you see on the displayed stack. They put the perfect looking ones for display and give you something else from a different batch including ones that weren't so good. They're cheeky those sellers. They're there to make money I guess.The fruit bowls are also pretty good way to taste different kinds of fruits, but again they always include some dud ones in the pack. The fruit juices were good but not always.Don't bother with the chocolates stand near the entrance. They charge €65/kg and the price sign wasn't displayed properly either. We picked only 3 items and was charged over €7! We didn't end up buying them, but there will be those who get sucked in feeling bad for not paying.There were no real restaurants per se when we were there. Only a bar at the back of the market which seems to always be packed with people and long queues. After waiting a long while for seats, when there were seats vacated, we were rudely told that those are reserved for the staff who at that time hadn't had lunch yet. But they had no courtesy of telling us beforehand and spare us the wait, so we left and never come back.Overall, mixed experience, not always good, but the fruits were pretty good and reasonably priced.

I had no idea there were so many kinds of seafood!. This market is overflowing with fresh fruits, vegetables, cheeses, meats and seafood, and despite the hustle and bustle it's well worth walking through simply for the ambience. I was particularly impressed by the seafood - even more different kinds of unknown shelled or tentacled creature than I've seen in paellas... The fruit is actually cheaper than in the supermarket, so a good place to stock up on snacks!
Mercat de la Boqueria. Love this place! I wish we had similar markets in the US.

sit down or carry out - you can't go wrong!. If you want a super breakfast, lunch, snack, or food for a picnic, you can't go wrong at Mercat de la Boqueria. There are at least two outstanding sit-down counter restaurants - we kept going to the Central, but Pinoxt (sp?) is also really popular. We had fresh grilled seafood with grilled peppers - for breakfast or lunch - almost every day. At the stands and bakeries, you can buy anything from fresh fruit salads and smoothies to the best ham you have ever eaten to an incredible array of cheeses. And the breads are great. If you want to picnic nearby, the former hospital has a delightful courtyard - about a block away towards the (other) Ramblas de Raval.

breathtaking and delicious!. I don't know if you are allowed to call a food market breathtaking, but if you are, this is it. The entire place is swimming with fresh fruit, vegetables, raw meats, small hot food places, nuts, candy, wine...and everything is delicious. It is also easy to get to it again and again because its located right off las ramblas (the main street in barcelona). It's not to be missed!

Food heaven. This place was amazing! Food and colour everywhere. The are places to eat and lots of food to buy. You will be amazed. The only problem for me was that there were heads with eyes in them in the butcher counters, not good if you're a bit screamish like me!

One of the best lunches we have ever had. My 21 year old son and I tracked down 'El Quim de la Boqueria' tapas bar. After a 10m wait to secure two seats at the bar, we trusted ourselves to whatever they recommended and went on to enjoy a memorable meal. Very fresh, cooked in front of us. Sea food dominated (baby squid, tuna steak) livened with chilli and egg (really!) Highly recommended.

Food heaven. We shopped at the Mercat Boqueria every day during our trip to Barcelona. It's a big covered market where you can find all sorts of food: fruit, vegetables, bread, meat, pasta, ... You can even see how the fresh fish gets delivered and prepared in the morning.

A must-see if you like food and people-watching. There is so much to see at this market and the photo opportunities are endless. The colors are bright, the chocolates look tempting, and the prices for veggies, cheese and breads are very affordable. We went here almost every day during our 2-week stay in Barcelona, to stock up on food to take back to our apartment and cook our evening meals. The characters on Las Ramblas are worth the trip, as well.

Good Tapas with hustle and bustle all around. Mercat de la Boqueria – if you want hustle and bustle, this is the place. There is obviously a knack of getting a seat, but we didn’t have it and had to wait a while! The food could not be fresher and prices seem reasonable, but don’t expect a comprehensive bill detailing what you ate/drank, as you just get a slip of paper with a figure – our bill seemed a little arbitrary but still OK. The market is great, but there are many signs warning of pickpockets and a Tapas bar is probably high on the hit list

Possibly the Best Market in the World. Hustle and bustle at its best. Meat, fish and vegetables piled high and looking very good, with photo opportunities at every corner. Be careful though as there are signs all around warning of pick pockets. None the less, we will return when we come back to the city again.
A place to visit in Barcelona.. A place to visit in Barcelona.
everything OK. everything OK

A Must-See For Any Foodie. If you do nothing else in Barcelona, don't miss La Boqueria! My favorite thing to do in Eueope is visit central markets, and I rate this one as numero uno. Go early to see it at its best. Many of the vendors close up and go home after noon. This place is the experience of a lifetime for any foodie. Take your time, and bring your camera; there's a lot to see.
Wonderful little market area. We love this little market in the Placa de Pi. Art market on Saturdays and there are other little markets around it. We make a point to go everytime we are in Barcelona.
Great. Loved the La Boqueria, buzzing, lots going on and amazing fruit jucies. Also at the back of the market they do lovely fresh food. Great picture opportunities.

A market to visit,colourfull, here you can buy anything to eat, and lots of little bistrot to taste, one of my.... A market to visit,colourfull, here you can buy anything to eat, and lots of little bistrot to taste, one of my favourites "El Quim".
utterly gorgeous. Whether you want to buy fruit, take an edible gift home, take photos or just people watch & eat this is the place to go (the cafe & clothes boutique behind it is low key good too)

Superb. this place is a real gem and will overload your senses of sight, smell and taste. the array of food and the quality is amazing and leaves you feeling envious when you think you have to go shopping in tesco back home, the market is surrounged by small restaurants and we had the best sea food platter ever here in one of these tiny cafes, and when they run out of something they just run into the market and come back with more supplies

No Barcelona trip without a boqueria visit !. This wonderful market is my favourite place in Barcelona.Always busy with an overwhelming offering of delicious seafood, Jamones , cheeses and vegetables.Just walk around and admire the always fresh products presented in eye catching settings. And don´t forget to stop at the central bar of boqueria for your tapas rounded up with the best Cava we were served with in town.

fun little (big) market!. Fresh fruit, veggies, meat, eggs, fish...all over the place! The new thing is fresh juice in individual cups for 1 euro -- lots of fun combos, so take lots of coins. Toward the middle-lower end of Las Ramblas, it makes for a fun stopping place. Watch your purse/wallet -- this area does get crowded, and with so many distracted people looking at the fun food, pickpocketers can get lucky.
A great place to wander.... A great place to wander thru and then have lunch.

A myriad of sights and smells. All sorts of market shops in here selling everything to seafood, meat and jamon, produce, spices, nuts and candy. I'm especially impressed with the variety of zumos (fresh fruit juices) and pre-cut fruit available ready to eat. A couple of bar-type eateries are available to sample the "catch" of the day.

Great experience!. I am a huge foodie, so this was like heaven. All the beautiful colors, displays, smells...heaven! There are places to pay for full takeaway meals-even one stand for organic vegetarians! There's wine stands, candy stands, fruit and vegetables, fish and meats-bakeries-just great. Feel free to take pictures, but it gets busy-watch for pickpockets, although we had no trouble here.
lovely. What a wonderful market! Really great and the thing that amazed me the most was that it was very very clean.

La Boqueria--A Must See Attraction of Barcelona. Do not miss this incredible city market on your visit to Barcelona. City markets give you great insights into the way a city's citizens live and this must be one of the great food markets in the world. The array of food stalls is astounding and the food is just beautiful. While locals shop there every day, as a tourist you'll very easily be able to participate by buying a snack, a meal, your cafe con leche, a beer or drink--whatever strikes your fancy at the moment. Spanish food is fantastic and if you're a food buff you will love this place. To see the meat stalls with the Serrano (and other) hams hanging there awaiting consumers ready to pay anywhere from 15 Euros to 155 Euros per kilo gives you an appreciation of how much Catalans and Spaniards love their wonderful cuisine.

Splendid. Go on your first morning ... you may want to go back every day. Wonderful produce, fish, etc., etc. etc. Have a coffee and pastry at one of the stands and just soak in the atmosphere and the scene. I've never been anywhere like it.

If you love food. If you love food, this is a must on your list to visit. The market is bustling with people and merchants. From the moment you enter the market there is much to desire. We ate at one of the lunch counters in the back of the market and enjoyed a great seafood platter. However, be prepared to wait! it is worth it. the famous Pinotxo lunch counter is harder to get a seat at and was always crowded even in november when the number of tourists are smaller. Don't go to a restaurant when you can come here for one of the best lunches Barcelona has to offer.

Beautiful to the eye and mouth. Right off Las Ramblas, this food market is great fun. Well stocked with fruits, vegetables, meats, seafoods, cheeses, nuts, and much more. It actually feels very artistic, with arranging the freshest food in the most aesthetically pleasing way, to appeal to the customer. So I'd recommend a walk through even if you THINK you aren't going to buy anything (but the fresh fruit is so tempting...). Buying fresh healthy food like this is probably why the Catalonians seem so beautiful and healthy themselves!

A place to explore your senses.. One of our most enjoyable activities while travelling is to visit various marketplaces. La Boqueria is probably one of the most enjoyable and impressive markets we have visited. Focused on food, this market will entice, and possibly assault, one or all of your senses. Through the 100+ stalls, you will see virtually every kind of food stuff know to people. A rainbow of fruit and veggies. Meats of almost any kinds - some of which you will recognize in their natural form. If it comes from the sea and can be eaten, it will probably be found here. I've known about barnacles, but did not know you can eat them. Yup, you can. Spices, prepared foods, nuts, candies, wine, beer and much more. I recommend that everyone visiting Barcelona take some time and visit the market. Sit down at one of the cafes' in the back and have a coffee and some snacks. This market will not only entertain you, but you will probably learn something as well.

Why not?. Just off Ramblas, it's another touristy stop in Barcelona. It's definitely pretty to look at, given the fruitstands. The prices are good, the fruit is about average, sometimes below average. However, there are lots of other nice food joints, esp. a seafood stand which was very crowded (avg prices). There's a tapas style restaurant in the back which was good, and the seafood seemed very fresh.All in all, if you're at Ramblas, make a stop. It's not a must-see or must-eat.
Exciting and full of life. It was en explosion to the senses. Loads of veggies, fruits, nuts, hams, chocolate and a cheap lunches made from really fresh ingredients. Great for a walk through.
